description: STEVE TASKER, the Buffalo Bills' special teams ace, has agreed to a new three-year deal that will increase his pay to a reported $750,000 a year. The Bills struck the deal Wednesday with Tasker, an unrestricted free agent who is considered among the league's top special teams players.

title: No Headline
description: "If you dig hard enough in any kid, you'll find a problem. If you want to have something to write down, you'll find something to write down." JEANNIE WANG, a former teacher at the Dalton School [ B6:1. ]

title: Rome Off the Hook
description: ESPN said yesterday that it will not discipline an interviewer, JIM ROME, for taunting New Orleans Saints quarterback JIM EVERETT during a live broadcast, prompting Everett to physically attack him. During the interview on ESPN2 broadcast Wednesday night, Everett lost his temper when Rome called him "Chris Evert" several times, even after the quarterback asked him stop. (AP)

title: When the I.R.S. Is a Soft Touch
description: Despite its reputation among most taxpayers as a fierce bill collector, the Internal Revenue Service is proving in many cases to be a most patient and forgiving creditor.

title: Canwest Global reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Collective Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 2,642,000, or 13 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Giuliani and Cortines in Accord On Jobs Cuts, Mayor's Aides Say
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, meeting late last night with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, agreed to the Mayor's demand that he cut 2,500 jobs from the Board of Education administration, aides to the Mayor said. It was more than double the reduction that Mr. Cortines had previously agreed to, and apparently ended a budgetary confrontation between the two men.

title: Not Being 'Stupid' Looks Smart On a Tough Day at the Masters
description: It was a giddy first round of the Masters today, featuring the sort of taut theatrics and odd explosions usually reserved for the back nine on Sunday. There were eagles and triple bogeys, chip shots into the lake, putts off the green and one tee shot that traveled about 50 yards.

title: Review/Film; The New Boy in a Town Ruled by Coincidence
description: A dusty, desolate Wyoming town is a logical setting for an updated film noir. The first of many gleeful twists in "Red Rock West" is that Nicolas Cage arrives, as the man least likely to survive a tangle of murder, greed and infidelity. Michael is not stupid; he just has the hapless luck of the terminally honest.

title: A Mid-City Arcadia of Forests and Flowers
description: Spring-starved New Yorkers (where are those daffodils?) will find it busting out all over at Rockefeller Center tomorrow at 8 A.M., when the second annual Rockefeller Center Flower and Garden Show flings open its figurative doors.

title: Mayor Giuliani's Policing Strategy; Rounding Up City Truants
description: On Tuesday, police officers swept 70 truants off the streets of downtown Brooklyn and sent them back to school. On Wednesday the police spread a wider net across New York City, rounding up 216 truants.

title: Not a Pretty Ending At the Finishing Hole
description: Pat Summerall, calling his final golf tournament for CBS this weekend at the Masters, is still stung by the management decision that forced him to choose between calling football for Fox Sports and continuing with CBS golf.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about links between large medical centers in Manhattan and other hospitals misstated the current academic affiliation of Lenox Hill Hospital. It is affiliated with New York University Medical Center, no longer with New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Review/Jazz; Happy Anniversary, Verve Records
description: Verve Records' 50th anniversary show at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was lucky to have been as successful, in its own functional way, as it was. Musicians work better warmed up, and performances build not in the chronology of sound bites, but at length. The show, which was meant to be packaged for PBS, kept the performances short and sandwiched between simple introductions read by the hosts Vanessa Williams and Herbie Hancock. And musicians were hustled on and off stage for virtually every tune, destroying any sense of continuity.

title: Starks Pushing For Playoffs
description: Less than a month after undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his left knee, John Starks was on the Madison Square Garden court, gingerly taking jump shots before last night's Knicks-Cavaliers game.

title: Inquiry Upgraded on Possible Ford Defect
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has upgraded its investigation of a suspected defect in the steering system of 3.4 million Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable and Lincoln Continental sedans built from 1987 to 1993.

title: Review/Theater; Amid Pain and Din, A Mighty Medea
description: MOUNTAIN climbers have Everest. Swimmers have the English Channel. Actresses have "Medea."

title: A Collision Course To Playoffs
description: Early in the second half of the Nets-Hawks game tonight, P. J. Brown, the New Jersey forward who weighs about 210 pounds, ran smack into Atlanta's 250-pound center Jon Koncak. The collision sent Brown crashing to the floor, and when he got up, dazed, Brown looked as if he had just seen Elvis.

title: Why Newspapers Watch Their Language
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; Another British Classic Is Imported
description: The BBC's six-and-a-half hour production of "Middlemarch" has been something of a sensation in England, reaping hefty ratings and pushing George Eliot's 1872 novel onto the best-seller lists. Period costume drama, elegantly produced, has returned triumphantly to British television, which in turn, of course, means our own "Masterpiece Theater." "Middlemarch" begins a six-week run Sunday on the PBS series.

title: Fed Shares In Chief's Rate Power
description: Without a vote or even a formal discussion, the Federal Reserve's top policy makers are taking over the process of raising and lowering rates, rather than allowing their chairman, Alan Greenspan, to act on his own between meetings, as he often has in the past.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: John Hicks

title: MOLECULAR DYNAMICS STOCK REACHES A LOW
description: The stock of Molecular Dynamics Inc. fell 38 percent and hit its lowest level ever yesterday after the company said late Wednesday that it expected to report a "substantial" first-quarter loss. The company's stock was down $3.875, to $6.125, in Nasdaq trading. Molecular Dynamics, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., also reported a 20 percent drop in revenue from the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The company said it expected its poor first-quarter results to carry over to the second quarter. The maker of instruments for life-science research attributed the weak forecast to economic weakness in Europe and the Pacific Rim and spending cuts in the United States pharmaceutical market linked to proposed health care changes.

title: Nottingham Journal; Who's Merry Now? Sherwood Forest May Be Sold
description: There isn't much left of Sherwood Forest, and what there is, Robin Hood would hardly recognize.

title: Wingfield Goes Pro
description: DONTONIO WINGFIELD thinks he is ready at 19 for the National Basketball Association, so he left the University of Cincinnati after one year and is making himself available for the draft. Wingfield led his high school in Albany, Ga., to four state championships. At 6 feet 8 inches and 250 pounds, he was the Bearcats' leading rebounder with 9 a game and second leading scorer with 16 points. (AP)

title: Word of Plans for Additional Tax Cuts Puts Albany Lobbyists in a Frenzy
description: With a proposal to cut $400 million in taxes on the budget negotiating table, but no decision on which taxes to cut, the State Capitol was filled today with furious lobbying by companies large and small seeking reductions for their industries.

title: Goldman Sachs Signs Major New Lease
description: In a reflection of financial vigor and an uptick in hiring on Wall Street, Goldman Sachs and Company, one of the nation's biggest brokerage concerns, has leased a large block of office space in lower Manhattan to expand its staff.

title: Luther S. Cressman, Anthropologist, 96, Expert on Northwest
description: Dr. Luther S. Cressman, an anthropologist whose discoveries helped revolutionize thinking about prehistoric cultures in the Pacific Northwest, died on Monday at his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 96.

title: Again, Massacre in the Mideast
description: The enemies of Mideast peace have struck again, slaughtering yet more innocents and threatening new disruption of negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Helped by an Early Easter, Sales Surge for Retailers
description: Sales at the country's retail-store chains leaped ahead in March, driven by the arrival of spring and an earlier Easter that inspired consumers to buy warm-weather clothes and products for their homes and yards.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A New Temple

title: But in Singapore Peaceful Citizens Feel Safe; Privy Council Recourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Project in Furor About Guns and the Law
description: When the shooting gets bad at the Robert Taylor Homes public housing development, tenants ask the security guard who lives next door where he bought his bullet proof vest. They want one for trips to the corner store where they buy their babies milk.

title: Executive Changes
description: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES, Peabody, Mass., named Wolfgang Schweim president of the Saucony athletic footwear division, effective June 1. NOVO NORDISK OF NORTH AMERICA INC., New York, a unit of Novo Nordisk A.S. of Denmark, named Henrik Aagaard president.

title: Western Digital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
In Maryland, Taking Free Papers in Protest May Soon Be a Crime
description: In cities and towns across the country, neighborhood and alternative city newspapers and campus dailies sit stacked in public places so that anyone can grab a free copy. But increasingly, those doing the grabbing are taking entire stacks because they disagree with the editorial content.

title: Review/Film; Family as Revolution in Microcosm
description: "The Blue Kite" was shown as part of the 1993 New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film -- in Mandarin with English subtitles -- opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway and 63d Street.

title: Books of The Times; Forster's Life, Neatly Divided at 45
description: E. M. Forster A Biography By Nicola Beauman Illustrated. 404 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Trosch Jose Freire Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through May 4

title: What of Smoking's Costs in Office Time?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disabilities Program That 'Got Out of Hand'
description: Emily Fisher Landau, a member of a wealthy New York City real estate family, had long wanted to create a model educational program for bright youngsters with learning disabilities. Mrs. Landau herself experienced trouble reading as a girl, and it wasn't until she was 56 years old that she was diagnosed as dyslexic.

title: Nuclear Plant Shut Down After Quick Power Surge
description: A nuclear plant in southern New Jersey, trying to reduce power after grass clogged its cooling-water intake yesterday, went through a power swing before an automatic system shut the plant down, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said.

title: Bronx Leaders Boycott Ceremony on Federal Aid
description: Borough President Fernando Ferrer and other elected officials from the Bronx boycotted a ceremony announcing an agreement on a Federal inner-city development program yesterday, saying they were upset that the program would benefit only a small portion of the borough around Yankee Stadium.

title: Family Dollar Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a benefit of $ 1,139,153, or 2 cents a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Review/Film; A Life Colored by AIDS
description: Derek Jarman's "Blue" was shown as part of the 1993 New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2, 1993. Mr. Jarman died on Feb. 19. The film opens today at Film Forum 2, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Holocaust Lamentations Echo at Vatican
description: Pope John Paul II welcomed the Chief Rabbi of Rome to the Vatican today as guest of honor at a concert to honor the memory of the victims of the Holocaust.

title: Manning Still Has a Level to Climb
description: Danny Manning slipped the white pad onto his right elbow. Between the pad and his skin, there was green piece of foam. Manning, a finesse player with a delicate shooting touch, didn't like the idea of the extra baggage on his shooting arm.

title: Inside Art
description: Related by Money

title: Dow Jones's Earnings Rise 29.8%
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 29.8 percent as a result of increased profitability in all of its businesses.

title: McCann-Erickson Executive Promoted
description: John Fitzgerald, the vice chairman and chief operating officer of McCann-Erickson North America in New York, was promoted yesterday to president and chief executive of McCann-Erickson Japan.

title: Review/Film; Reliving a Past of Slavery
description: In "Sankofa," a contemporary African-American woman travels back in time and experiences slavery. Haile Gerima's poetic and precisely detailed film takes its audience into its heroine's life and mind as her moral sense is challenged and changed. No viewer can avoid the discomforting questions the film so eloquently raises.

title: Ex-Partner Of Clintons To Sell Papers
description: The Clintons' former partner in the Whitewater land deal, James B. McDougal, has come up with a new way to raise money for his legal bills.

title: Review/Music; Carmichael Songs in Revue
description: Hoagy Carmichael's music has more implicit jazz in it than the tunes of any other major American songwriter of the pre-rock era except Duke Ellington. The sultry, swinging melodies of Carmichael, the self-taught pianist and composer from Bloomington, Ind., were spun from the same spiritual thread as the music of his idol, the great cornetist Bix Beiderbecke. And "Hoagy on My Mind," a new revue of Carmichael's music that plays through April 16 at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street, Chelsea) honors his work with an easygoing charm that accentuates the deep strain of Americana in his songs.

title: Bill Clinton's Arteries -- and Ours
description: Ask around Little Rock and they tell it to you straight: Bill Clinton when he was Governor could really chow down. Jalapeno cheeseburgers, mammoth steaks, chicken enchiladas swimming in cream and melted cheese -- artery-clogging fat by the mouthful, with roughage nowhere to be seen.

title: Rise in Capital Outlay Is Projected at 8% for '94
description: Businesses plan to increase spending on their factories and equipment by 8 percent this year, the largest gain in five years, as they scramble to meet stronger demand from consumers, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Met Is Filled With Memories of Tatiana Troyanos
description: Tatiana Troyanos, the excellent American mezzo-soprano, showed great loyalty to the Metropolitan Opera after her debut there in 1976, and her fans repaid it last evening, filling much of the house for a memorial concert in her honor. Miss Troyanos died of cancer last August, at 54, only weeks after her last performances.

title: AIDS Virus May Directly Cause a Cancer of the Immune System
description: Researchers in San Francisco say the AIDS virus may directly cause a cancer of the immune system by inserting itself into a cell's DNA and switching on a dormant cancer gene.

title: Art in Review
description: Annie Leibovitz James Danziger Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through April 16

title: For Children
description: It's time to dash outdoors! But can April, with its showers, be trusted? Here are activities that can be enjoyed indoors, not only when it's raining but also after dinner, in the miraculous lull before bedtime. 'Growler' Tapes Recommended ages: 3 to 10

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MAYOR AND CORTINES IN ACCORD, AIDES SAY

title: Hanover Direct
description: Shares of Hanover Direct, the catalogue retailer formerly named Horn & Hardart, rose sharply this week after it concluded a $46.8 million secondary offering on March 31. On Wednesday, Merrill Lynch projected annual sales growth of 50 percent for the company and rated the stock a long-term buy.

title: Ralph James, Rear Admiral, Is Dead at 87
description: Rear Adm. Ralph K. James, who headed the Navy's Bureau of Ships from 1959 to 1963 and oversaw repairs to battle-damaged American warships in World War II, died on March 31 at the Ginger Cove retirement community in Annapolis, Md. He was 87.

title: Power Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mayor Giuliani's Policing Strategy; Drug Busts by Beat Cops
description: Rudolph Giuliani campaigned for mayor on a promise to fight crime and disorder with a zeal that would reassure worried New Yorkers. Mayor Giuliani's new plans for increasing drug arrests and cracking down on teen-age truants are clearly an attempt to make good on that promise.

title: Justice Aide Leaves Today
description: Webster L. Hubbell, who announced last month that he would resign as the No. 3 official at the Justice Department, will leave on Friday, Deputy Attorney General Jamie S. Gorelick said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 JAPANESE PREMIER TO RESIGN Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, who took office last year promising political reform and economic deregulation, said he would resign amid a scandal surrounding his own finances in the 1980's. A1 U.S. RESTATES POLICY ON BOSNIA The White House essentially repudiated remarks by two senior military officials that the United States was not prepared to use military power now to prevent a Bosnian town from being overrun by Serbs. A1

title: The Spoken Word
description: "HOLLYWOOD AND THE FRENCH NEW WAVE," Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. The final programs in a five-weekend series on the relationship between Hollywood films and the French New Wave. Tomorrow at 12:30 P.M., "Femmes Fatales" is to feature the film critic Molly Haskell and screenings of Fritz Lang's "Woman in the Window" and Eric Rohmer's "My Night at Maud's." On Sunday at 12:30 P.M., Hollywood films that drew from the French New Wave are to be discussed by Ralph Rosenblum, a professor of film at Columbia University. There will be screenings of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour," by Alain Resnais, and "The Pawnbroker," by Sidney Lumet. Admission: $6; $4 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 638-5000. "ASIAN ENCOUNTERS: RECENT WORKS BY ASIAN-AMERICAN AND BRITISH-ASIAN FILM MAKERS," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. A weeklong series of screenings and discussions featuring film makers and writers. Tomorrow from 1 to 3:30 P.M., a panel discussion on Asian identity in the British and American press, with the film makers Gurinder Chadha, Shu Lea Cheang and Hanif Kureishi and the writer Daryl Chin, and screenings of three short films; admission, $10. On Sunday at noon, Mr. Kureishi, the director of "My Beautiful Laundrette," is to discuss the art of the screenplay with the writer Jessica Hagedorn; screenings at 3 and 5 P.M. Admission to the discussion and screenings: $25, which includes brunch; discussion only, $20; screenings only, $9. Information: (212) 517-2742.

title: 'If' Mitchell Is Nominated to Supreme Court Is Grist for Speculation at the White House
description: The White House said today that it saw no problem with George J. Mitchell's remaining as Senate majority leader for some time if President Clinton nominated the Senator to fill the impending vacancy on the Supreme Court.

title: P.L.O. Called Unready to Take Over
description: As Israel prepares to turn Gaza and Jericho over to the Palestinians, there are mounting fears among Palestinian and Israeli leaders, and foreign diplomats, that the dearth of planning and preparation by the P.L.O. leadership could be the prelude to chaos in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Knicks Saved by Harper's Late 3-Pointer
description: On paper, it was expected to be an easy victory for the Knicks.

title: Burlington Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 633,000.

title: Resignation News Jolts Japan Stocks
description: The shocking announcement today that Japan's embattled Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, intends to resign put stock prices into a temporary tailspin.

title: Acclaim Entertainment (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Gooden's Big Toe Holds Up Rotation
description: One day after the Mets announced that Dwight Gooden would start the home opener Monday at Shea Stadium, they learned that Gooden's big toe was still soar.

title: Music? Romance? Try a Museum
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT would not approve. At the Museum of Modern Art, where his life's work is on display in a special exhibition, visitors who come to worship at the shrine of architecture have been sneaking off on Friday evenings to the Garden Cafe for free jazz. There, over a drink and perhaps a cheeseburger or slice of lasagna, dozens of reprobates actually seem to be enjoying the vastly inferior art of music. Sacrilege.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Dixie Carter

title: Facing Suits, Askin Funds Seek Chapter 11 Protection
description: Three investment funds run by Askin Capital Management filed for protection from the funds' creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code yesterday after lawsuits were filed by at least two brokerage firms from which the funds had borrowed money, David J. Askin, the company's president, said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A frog can turn into a prince, but can a President turn into a frog?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the recall of Chinese-made crayons found to contain lead included an incomplete identification of one importer, supplied by the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The importer is Fred Baum Imports Inc., the consumer agency said later.

title: No. 3 Justice Official to Step Down Today
description: Webster L. Hubbell, who announced last month that he would resign as the No. 3 official at the Justice Department, will leave on Friday, a senior department official said today.

title: Dickson's Yacht Loses Its Mast
description: Chris Dickson's hopes of winning the Whitbread Round the World Race toppled late Wednesday along with his sailboat's 85-foot mast. The towering spar on Tokio broke apart in two places and fell overboard into the South Atlantic Ocean. The 60-foot yacht had been facing 25-knot headwinds and pounding seas off the coast of Brazil since leaving Uruguay last Saturday.

title: From Death's Grasp A Torah Is Reborn
description: Just before noon tomorrow in a synagogue in Queens, a young girl will say a blessing over a 300-year-old Torah that, in accordance with Jewish law and in defiance of evil, has been restored to life.

title: Departures at Wasserstein
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it had hired three investment bankers from Wasserstein, Perella & Company, including its co-president, Gary Parr.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Mangold Pace Gallery 142 Greene Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through April 23

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Visa charge card may be, as the commercial says, "everywhere you want to be," but it wasn't where the PRINCESS OF WALES was when she went on a shopping expedition the other day in Salisbury, England.

title: Rangers' Thoughts Turn To Possible Clincher
description: With four games to go in the 84-game National Hockey League season, the Rangers are a victory away from clinching the Atlantic Division title, the Devils are a loss away from settling for second place and the Islanders are still riding a four-team playoff bubble so complicated that the idle Islanders had trouble deciding which team to root for in last night's game between the Florida Panthers and the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included charges of $ 6.9 million for reorganization costs, and $ 4.2 million in income tax expenses to reflect adjustment to deferred tax assets, in the quarter; the year included special charge of $ 35.1 million to reduce carrying value of inventory and certain leasehold improvements and accelerate recognition of certain lease obligations. Period also included $ 5 million charge for reorganization costs.c-Net income(Loss)

title: On My Mind; Land on Credit
description: In Cairo, Yasir Arafat is asked for comment on the slaughter of the bus passengers in Israel by a Palestinian terrorist. He turns and walks away.

title: But in Singapore Peaceful Citizens Feel Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria's Endgame
description: However anxious millions of South Africans may be at the moment, this country has good leadership for the first time since white men settled at the tip of Africa 342 years ago -- if "good leadership" means leaders who face up to the fundamental issue, which is of course relations between blacks and whites.

title: No Economic Index
description: To the Editor:

title: Harding Won't Receive White House Invitation
description: A black-tie dinner and White House ceremony next week is expected to draw 150 athletes who competed in the Lillehammer Winter Olympics. TONYA HARDING won't be one of them. The United States Olympic Committee, which lost a court battle to hold hearings on whether Harding could skate in the Olympics, decided not to invite her to the event, a U.S.O.C. spokesman, MIKE MORAN, said yesterday. "This is a social event we are sponsoring for the Olympic team and we thought we would be well advised not to create a distraction in Washington for this series of events," Moran said. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., said its aerospace division had received a 10-year contract valued at $280 million to supply the General Electric Co. with jet engine components. ASA INTERNATIONAL LTD., has agreed to acquire Profitkey International Inc. of Salem, N.H., for an undisclosed amount of stock.

title: Yeltsin's On-and-Off Decrees on Bases Cloud the Policy Outlook
description: Conflicts between President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Government have confused diplomats and complicated the West's efforts to gauge the intentions behind Russia's more assertive foreign policy, especially in former republics of the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Gains Trade Forum For Labor-Equity Issues
description: Sidestepping opposition from some developing nations, the United States won approval today for labor-related issues to be taken up by the new World Trade Organization that will be created when a global trade-liberalization package is formally signed on April 15.

title: INSIDE
description: New Social Security Rules Urged on Disability Benefits

title: Sports of The Times; 'You Can Still Hear My Stomach'
description: IN his first Masters, Jim McGovern had opened with a steady-as-she-blows par 72, but now, standing under the sprawling oak tree outside the Augusta National clubhouse, he was talking about how nervous he had been.

title: USAir Agrees To Lift Rules On the Weight Of Attendants
description: USAir yesterday became the latest airline to drop its weight standards for flight attendants, settling a 1992 lawsuit filed by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Paving the Road for a Firefighter's Recovery
description: The funerals are over. The blaze that killed two New York City firefighters last week is slipping into memory. But in a Manhattan hospital room, a third casualty lies motionless, hovering between death and an unknown future.

title: Bosnia Fighting Rages as U.N. Tries to Broker Cease-Fire
description: Serbian nationalists shelled the United Nations-declared safe area of Gorazde for the 10th day running today as the United Nations commander here shuttled between Bosnian Government and Serbian commanders in a new bid to broker a lasting, nationwide cease-fire.

title: Eric Holtzman Is Dead at 54; Biology Professor at Columbia
description: Prof. Eric Holtzman, chairman of the department of biological sciences at Columbia University, was found dead in his office on Wednesday. He was 54 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Art in Review
description: Byron Kim Max Protetch Gallery 560 Broadway (at Prince Street) SoHo Through April 16

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the career of Justice Harry A. Blackmun misspelled the names of two previous nominees for the Supreme Court seat he ultimately filled. They are Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. and G. Harrold Carswell. A related news analysis article, about Supreme Court nominations by past presidents, misspelled the given name of a Constitutional scholar at Harvard Law School. He is Laurence H. Tribe.

title: Police Seek Ex-Boyfriend After Slaying Of Executive
description: A Brooklyn Heights woman who had stopped at a local dry cleaner's before going to work at Salomon Brothers was killed yesterday morning when a man followed her into the store, whipped out a 9-millimeter semiautomatic weapon, and shot her six times in the head.

title: Which Total Is Greater: Yanks' Runs Or Fans?
description: Memories from the first game of any baseball season are very special, with legends such as Joe DiMaggio throwing out the first pitch, with the wintry chill dissipating as the game is reborn and with empty seats as rare as manageable lines at the concession stands.

title: Islamic Banking: Faith and Creativity
description: Dr. Ala-ud-Din, a dentist in San Jose, Calif., had two choices: save for years to buy a house with cash, or take out a mortgage and violate the law of the Koran.

title: 'Memory Therapy' on Trial: Healing or Hokum?
description: Gary Ramona had everything, or so it seemed: a wife and three children, a $300,000-a-year vice presidency at the Robert Mondavi Winery, a million-dollar dream house here in wine country.

title: Market Place; An offering in a British phone and cable TV venture shapes up.
description: FOR investors following the much-touted convergence of the telephone and cable television industries, the next few weeks may bring an opportunity. U S West, the Denver-based telecommunications company, and Tele-Communications Inc., the cable television giant, are expected to decide whether to make a public offering of shares in TeleWest, their joint venture in Britain.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: On, Off and Around the Ballot

title: BanPonce Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 6,185,000, or 19 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.BanPonce said that the 1994 quarter reflected an increase of $ 7.6 million in net interest income, an increase of $ 4.9 million in other revenues and a rise of $ 3.7 million in operating expenses. Income tax expense rose $ 7.2 million.

title: Astronauts Prepare for Shuttle Launching Today
description: A space shuttle mission to test a radar mapping system is scheduled for lift-off on Friday morning, but the weather could interfere .

title: Lazare Kaplan Int'l reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss, and the quarter included an extraordinary charge of $ 226,000, or 4 cents a share, from the reversal of extraordinary item which represented utilization of net operating loss carryforward from prior period.(Loss)

title: U.S. Seeks to Ease Process of Getting Disability Benefits
description: Deluged with new applications, Social Security officials today proposed sweeping changes in how decisions are made on who gets disability benefits. But advocates for the disabled said the changes would leave hundreds of thousands of disabled people ineligible for benefits.

title: U.S. Says Force Is Still a Choice In Bosnia Crisis
description: Seeking to restore credibility to American diplomacy in the Balkans, the White House today essentially repudiated remarks by two senior military officials that the United States was not prepared to use military power now to prevent the Bosnian town of Gorazde from being overrun by Serbian nationalists.

title: Review/ Dance; Joffrey Revives Legendary Ballet By Massine
description: LIKE carrots and spinach, there are legendary ballets in the international repertory that are good for you even if they are not to your taste. "Les Presages" ("Omens"), which Leonide Massine choreographed in 1933 as the first of his celebrated "symphonic ballets" is -- trust me -- one of those.

title: Troops Rampage in Rwanda; Dead Said to Include Premier
description: One day after the Presidents of Rwanda and Burundi were killed in an apparent rocket attack on their plane, the Rwandan capital of Kigali dissolved into terror and chaos today as disparate army and police forces went on a rampage, reportedly killing the country's interim Prime Minister and at least 10 Belgian peacekeeping soldiers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Acclaim Entertainment Deal For Comics Publisher Near
description: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. said today that it planned to buy Voyager Communications Inc., the publisher of Valiant Comics, for $65 million in cash and stock.

title: Review/Music; Masur's 'Jeanne d'Arc' Gives Life to a Long-Ago Feminist
description: Kurt Masur's stirring success with Arthur Honegger's dramatic oratorio "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher" ("Joan of Arc at the Stake") on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall came as no surprise. In his three seasons with the New York Philharmonic, Mr. Masur has shown a special talent in a fiendishly difficult genre -- works that mix music with the spoken word -- as well as an admirable ability to rise to big occasions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Panthers Tie Flyers Gord Murphy's slow, 40-foot backhand shot beat Philadelphia goalie Tommy Soderstrom at 6 minutes 11 seconds of the third period and pulled the visiting Florida Panthers into a 3-3 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers last night. The lazy backhand capped a comeback from a two-goal deficit. "I lost it on the way," said Soderstrom. The Flyers were without Eric Lindros, their leader and top goal-scorer. He suffered a sprain and ligament tears in his right shoulder Monday and probably will miss the final four regular-season games. (AP) Blues 6, Kings 2: Brendan Shanahan scored twice for the second consecutive game at St. Louis. The Blues star has seven goals in his last six games and is zeroing in on his second consecutive 50-goal season, with 47 goals and four games remaining. (AP) N.B.A. Nuggets Boost Chances Dikembe Mutombo had 11 blocked shots for the second straight game and also had 13 points and 13 rebounds as Denver broke Seattle's nine-game winning streak and improved its playoff chances with a 104-90 home victory last night. The Nuggets now have a three-game lead over the Los Angeles Lakers for the eighth and final Western Conference playoff spot. Reggie Williams led all scorers with 24 points as the Nuggets broke their four-game losing streak. (AP) Rockets 134, Warriors 102: The Houston Rockets set a franchise record for 3-point shooting, and Hakeem Olajuwon got his eighth career triple double in a victory over the visiting Golden State Warriors. Houston made 75 percent (12 of 16) of its long-range shots. Olajuwon had 26 points, 13 rebounds and 10 assists. (AP) Jazz 99, Mavericks 82: Karl Malone scored 25 points, and Felton Spencer 17 with 14 rebounds as Utah beat Dallas at Salt Lake City. (AP) TENNIS Sunshine for Sabatini After fumbling through a first set in which her serve failed four times, fourth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini won 10 straight games and 12 of the last 13, producing a 4-6, 6-0, 6-1 victory over Amanda Coetzer in the Bausch & Lomb Championships yesterday in Amelia Island, Fla. "The good thing was, I maintained my mind in the match, kept my mind tough," said Sabatini. In an upset of minor proportions, eighth-seeded Magadelena Maleeva, last year's most improved player but this year's most erratic, was eliminated, 7-6 (7-3), 6-4, by 19th-ranked Sabine Hack of Germany. But top-seeded Arantxa Sanchez Vicario made swift work of Belgium's Laurence Courtois, 6-1, 6-2, and second-seeded Conchita Martinez downed Leila Meskhi, 6-2, 6-3. Also advancing to the quarterfinals were Lindsay Davenport and Chanda Rubin.

title: The New South Americans: Friends and Partners
description: On Rio's bay, two huge Brazilian cannons have been waiting for Argentine warships for decades, monuments to the long enmity between South America's two regional powers. But today the guns are frozen with rust, visited by tourists, many of them Argentines.

title: Europeans to Build Supersonic Plane
description: With Europe and the United States increasingly jockeying for leadership in efforts to build a new generation of supersonic passenger aircraft, the leading French and British aerospace companies said today that they would link up with their German counterpart to step up development of a successor to the Concorde.

title: 2d African Film Festival
description: One of last year's landmark film series is now an annual event. The second New York African Film Festival, co-sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and African Film Festival Inc., begins tonight and will run for more than two weeks at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. An African film festival is especially welcome because of the infrequency with which African films are shown here commercially. (The Ethiopian-financed "Sankofa," opening today at the Harlem Victoria Five Theater, is a notable exception.) It's also welcome because Africa's diverse cultures offer such a wealth of thematic possibilities and because so many of these little-known works happen to be so good.

title: Some Macy Creditors Raise Disclosure Issue
description: Junior creditors of R. H. Macy & Company want to know why Weil, Gotshal & Manges, the law firm representing the retailer in its bankruptcy case, did not disclose its relationship with Fidelity Investments, one of Macy's most powerful senior creditors.

title: Trenton Panel Offers Plan On School Aid
description: A special commission named by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today recommended solving New Jersey's nettlesome school financing problems by making all but the very poorest districts pick up substantially more of the costs of running their schools.

title: Before You Believe in a Litigation Explosion
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Dark Side of the American Psyche
description: In the five years since Cady Noland's last New York show, she has become something of an international art star, known for seemingly chaotic installation pieces that probe the dark side of the nation's psyche.

title: Dow Gains 13.53 Points in Subdued Trading
description: Stocks ended higher yesterday, moving from early losses to their strongest point at the close of the session. Trading was subdued after a huge gain on Tuesday and mixed results on Wednesday.

title: Atmel Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share and per share amounts have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective March 21, 1994.

title: Roy Smeck, Banjoist And Guitarist, 94
description: Roy Smeck, a leading guitarist, banjoist and ukulele player since the days of vaudeville, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 94 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clinton Goes To Heartland Seeking Help On Health Bill
description: President Clinton has found that the farther he gets from Washington these days, the better he likes it.

title: Mexican Suspect Denies Link to 4 Held in Killing of Candidate
description: As the Government presses its investigation into a possible conspiracy in the assassination of the heavily favored presidential candidate of the governing party, the man who investigators say has confessed to the murder has insisted that four other men charged with complicity are innocent.

title: At the Bar; A pillar of the law laments that a 'noble profession' has become just another business.
description: For more than 50 years, the law has been spectacularly good to Sol M. Linowitz. But more recently, the state of the legal profession has nearly broken his heart.

title: Japanese Market Uncertain
description: When the Prime Minister announced his plans to resign, the Tokyo Stock Excahnge plunged, but it later leveled off. Page D1.

title: For Many in Arab Town, Israelis 'Should Feel What We Feel'
description: As a siren marking Holocaust remembrance day in Israel wailed over a radio and army gunfire echoed in the streets here, Khaled Abdullah viewed the car-bomb attack in Afula, Israel, on Wednesday through a prism of Palestinian pain.

title: Medicinal Marijuana Has Many Drawbacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Harbaugh Joins Colts
description: The Indianapolis Colts came to terms with the free-agent quarterback JIM HARBAUGH and released JACK TRUDEAU. The Colts were believed to have offered the former Chicago quarterback a two-year contract worth $1.75 million, The Indianapolis Star reported yesterday. (AP)

title: JAPANESE PREMIER SAYS HE WILL QUIT AS SCANDAL GROWS
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who took office last year promising to clean up Japan's corrupt political system and bring about the broad deregulation of the country, said this afternoon that he would resign. His announcement came amid a growing scandal surrounding his own finances during the 1980's.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Dollar Gains on Speculation That Rates Will Rise Again
description: The dollar rose against several leading currencies yesterday amid speculation in the currency markets that American interest rates were likely to rise again soon.

title: Review/Film; Menage a Trois With Hip Pretensions
description: Groaning and eye-rolling aren't possible for inanimate objects, but if they were, the portrait of Jack Kerouac seen in "Threesome" wouldn't keep a straight face. Kerouac decorates a bedroom in the college dormitory apartment where Eddy (Josh Charles), Stuart (Stephen Baldwin) and Alex (Lara Flynn Boyle) flatter themselves into thinking they are a boldly bohemian trio. The film is so proud of its alleged daring that it even begins with a dictionary definition of the word "deviant." "Sitcom" would have been more like it.

title: Man Admits Subway Killing of Student, 16
description: The man whom the police have accused of killing a 16-year-old student on a Brooklyn subway platform Sunday night surrendered yesterday, saying he had opened fire on a gang of youths to protect his younger brother.

title: WESTERN PUBLISHING TO SELL ITS GAMES UNIT TO HASBRO
description: Western Publishing Group Inc., removing itself as a possible takeover target, said it would sell its games and puzzles business to Hasbro Inc. for $105 million and concentrate on its core publishing operations. As part of its plan, Western Publishing, the nation's largest children's publisher, said it would lay off an unspecified number of employees. In a statement, Western Publishing acknowledged that it had held "extensive discussions" with third parties interested in acquiring it, but had ended the talks after the sale to Hasbro was "determined to be the best means for maximizing shareholder value." Western Publishing's stock rose 37.5 cents, to $14.25, in Nasdaq trading. The news came after the market closed.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "A LITTLE MORE MAGIC," Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, Manhattan. A presentation by the Famous People Players, with life-size puppets. Through Sunday. Performances: today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $25 to $40. Information: (212) 239-6200.

title: Broad Study Says Home-Based Day Care, Even if by Relatives, Often Fails Children
description: Family child care, the most widely used form of child care by employed mothers in the United States, is often of poor quality, according to a broad study released yesterday.

title:
About Real Estate;
Mentally Ill Residents Share a Project
description: For 22 residents of a 51-unit rental project on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the sound of children in the hallways is an important part of their first step toward a normal way of life.

title: Israelis' Faith In Peace Is Put Under Strain by Bombing and New Attack
description: As this scarred and bitter town buried its dead from a suicide car bombing, Israel reeled today from a new attack by militant Islamic forces that killed a man, wounded four people and strained the faith of countless Israelis in the chances for peace with the Palestinians.

title: Board Seeks Action On Nynex Mailing
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board urged the State Public Service Commission yesterday to take "appropriate steps" to insure that the costs of a soured sweepstakes mailing promotion, sponsored by New York Telephone, would be absorbed entirely by the shareholders of its parent, Nynex, and not charged to customers.

title: Valiant Nature Passes Santa Anita Derby
description: Nine horses were entered yesterday in the $500,000 Santa Anita Derby tomorrow, the major West Coast milestone on the road to the Kentucky Derby. But Valiant Nature was not among them, and he will run instead one week later against the best Eastern horses in the $500,000 Blue Grass Stakes in Lexington, Ky.

title: A Dash of Africa To Start the Day
description: Byron Lars started yesterday with a high-voltage show that was better than a pot of espresso for waking up his audience. His theme was Africa, and he knew how to play it.

title: Cowboys Sign Johnston
description: The Dallas Cowboys signed fullback DARRYL JOHNSTON to a three-year, $4.2 million contract yesterday and announced that the Pro Bowl guard NATE NEWTON has agreed to a contract. Johnston, who received a $1.8 million signing bonus, becomes the highest-paid fullback in N.F.L. history, the Cowboys said. No details were announced on Newton's deal. (AP)

title: Patent Dispute Brewing On Software Use of Ads
description: The apparent conflict between the software industry and the United States Patent and Trademark Office just keeps going, and going, and going.

title: Foote, Cone Official Will Join a Client
description: Brian J. Gail, president and chief executive of the Philadelphia office of Foote, Cone & Belding, said yesterday that he would leave to join a client, effective May 2.

title: Like Light Bulb Going On, Hospital Will Computerize; Driven by New Trends in Health Care, One Institution Decides to Change in a Day
description: Anthony R. Macaluso's delicately timed techno-ballet of batch files and interface gates will reach its moment of truth at exactly 1 P.M. on Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center. That's when technicians will throw the switch to take the hospital's new computerized patient-records network fully on line for the first time.

title: After Teachers Attacked, Hall Patrols Set
description: After three teachers at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the South Bronx were assaulted by students in two days, the school administration yesterday instituted hall patrols to stop students from loitering.

title: Left Exposed on Waiver Wire, Schourek Is Claimed by Reds
description: They have always tried to keep it from being an awkward situation. Eric Hillman and Pete Schourek met in 1987 in an instructional league in St. Petersburg. Both left-handed pitchers with potential, they became close friends and roommates that fall -- their first in the Mets' system -- and, in many ways, they have been lumped together ever since.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: STAC ELECTRONICS SHARES RISE 26% ON I.B.M. DEAL
description: Shares of Stac Electronics surged 26 percent yesterday after I.B.M. said it would include in its PC software Stac technology that would roughly double the capacity of a personal computer's hard drive. Shares of Stac, based in Carlsbad, Calif., rose $1.375, to $6.625, in Nasdaq trading. Stac also licensed its Stacker data compression software to the Compaq Computer Corporation two weeks ago. The software will be shipped with Compaq's personal computers. On Wednesday, the International Business Machines Corporation said it would license the technology in all its PC software. Stac has not released the financial terms of either agreement.

title: Art in Review
description: Ruth Orkin Witkin Gallery 415 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through April 17

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was one of those transcendent moments for Cantor HOWARD NEVISON of Temple Emanu-El in New York when he stepped up yesterday to sing Franz Schubert's setting of the 92d Psalm.

title: Justice Done
description: When Harry Blackmun joined the Supreme Court in 1970, he was dismissed as a conservative nonentity. He leaves as a liberal champion, widely hailed by legal scholars. Who changed, the Justice or the Court?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In big-city schoolyards, basketball backboards may become billboards.
description: A COMPANY that specializes in outdoor advertising is seeking to bring advertising to a new outdoor venue: basketball backboards in schoolyards.

title: Restaurants
description: "Do you think the cuisine of my country will finally become popular in yours?" asked my Colombian guest as she dipped a piece of oyster croquette into horseradish sauce and chewed thoughtfully. There was a long silence. Finally she said, "This is not anything I recognize but it is one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten." And she passed the plate.

title: Treasury Prices Rise Moderately
description: The prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday, partly on buying related to rallies in the mortgage-backed and municipal securities markets.

title: After a Money Hunt, a Library's Real Treasures Are in Tatters
description: Classics by James Joyce, Alexandre Dumas and Zane Grey lay atop stacks of irreparably damaged books at the Fort Worth Central Library today. Their spines cracked, covers ripped and pages torn, they seemed unlikely victims of a frenzied mob.

title: Lelyveld Will Succeed Frankel As The Times's Executive Editor
description: Max Frankel, the executive editor of The New York Times for the last eight years, will step down on July 1 and be succeeded by Joseph Lelyveld, the newspaper's managing editor. The change was announced yesterday by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times.

title: Company Stops Pursuit Of City Work
description: A company that New York City investigators said last year had received special treatment from members of the Dinkins administration agreed yesterday not to seek any city contracts for the next four years.

title: Home Video
description: Calling on 'Mrs. Doubtfire'

title: Bernard R. Bell, 82, World Bank Official
description: Bernard Raymond Bell, an economist and a former deputy director of the World Bank, died on March 29 at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Abroad at Home; The Blackmun Legacy
description: Years ago I met Justice Harry Blackmun and his wife, Dottie, at a judicial conference in Colorado. Mrs. Blackmun asked how I had traveled there and said they had come by car.

title: Food Lion Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
Reviews/Fashion; Virginia Woolf, Meet Anne Klein
description: Richard Tyler, the Australian who made his reputation as a fashion designer in Los Angeles, brought a fresh twist to American sportswear in his collection for Anne Klein. The clothes, introduced yesterday morning, were part of the Seventh Avenue fall showings presented in the Bryant Park tents.

title: Review/Art; Taking It Personally: Putting Emotions to Paper
description: As the tide of didactic, agenda-driven art begins to recede, and the complex, personal voice comes to the fore, an artist like Joan Snyder is starting to get the attention she deserves. Now in her mid-50's, she has been exhibiting for 25 years, though only fairly recently have midcareer laurels begun to be thrown in her direction.

title: 3 Students Are Charged After Officer Is Attacked at a High School
description: Three young women were charged yesterday with attacking a police officer outside a Brooklyn high school. The police said a group of teen-agers, all thought to be students at the school, punched the officer, pulled her hair, beat her with her own nightstick and tried to goad each other into taking her gun.

title: Article 715590 -- No Title
description: Chinese food is not the only cuisine of Chinatown these days. People also go there for some of the best Vietnamese food in New York City. And now there is eight-month-old Malaysia and Indonesia, a single restaurant specializing in the diverse, spicy, vibrant foods of these two Southeast Asian countries.

title: Secretary of Defense Wins Few Points for His Candor
description: When William J. Perry was picked in January to replace Les Aspin as Defense Secretary, the engineer and high-technology entrepreneur was billed as just the man to manage the Pentagon.

title: In Chicago, It's Michael Jordan, .400 Hitter
description: Michael Jordan, the 31-year-old rookie right fielder for the White Sox, spoke with a few reporters before the exhibition game against the Cubs in Wrigley Field this afternoon. "What if I got a hit today?" he said. "You guys would fall over, wouldn't you?"

title: APPLIED EXTRUSION ACQUIRES HERCULES DIVISION
description: Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc. has completed the acquisition of the Packaging Film Group of Hercules Inc. for $161 million in cash. The Packaging Film Group produces film used for consumer product packaging. Applied Extrusion, based in Middletown, Del., makes thermoplastic nets that are used for a variety of purposes. Hercules, based in Wilmington, Del., makes chemicals and related products, as well as solid fuel systems.

title: Art in Review
description: Nicole Eisenman Jack Tilton Gallery 47-49 Greene Street SoHo Through May 7

title: Mets Swallow Dose of Reality In Astrodome
description: The Mets tried not to get too excited about their 3-0 start to the 1994 season. Manager Dallas Green shrugged off questions about what it might mean to the team's seasonlong potential. Jeff Kent laughed at the joking suggestion that his three-game, six-r.b.i. total projected to 324 runs batted in for the year. Most players simply took it in stride.

title: Melba J. Kgositsile, Civil Rights Advocate, 54
description: Melba Johnson Kgositsile, a civil rights and anti-apartheid advocate, died on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 54.

title: Reitman's (Canada) reports earnings for Year to Jan 29
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 670,000, or 7 cents a share, from settlement of a prior year's capital tax assessment, and income from discontinued operations of $ 3,895,000, or 42 cents a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Computer Data Systems Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Q & A
description: Husband-Wife Pensions Q. My wife and I are both employees of my professional medical corporation. Is it true that we cannot both contribute to the pension and profit-sharing plans provided by the corporation? DR. DAVID E. KNOOP, Mendham, N.J. A. Both you and your wife can participate in the corporation's qualified plan. But an Internal Revenue Service rule could limit the amount of your contributions and the corporation's deductions, so that the full benefits would not be available to you both.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lumber Hits 5-Month Low On Bearish Housing View
description: Lumber prices plunged their daily trading limit yesterday, setting a five-month low, amid speculation that housing demand would not be as robust this year as thought.

title: Whitman Approves Pay Raises for State's Middle Managers
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman authorized pay increases of up to 5 percent today for as many as 6,000 middle managers -- including those now earning less than their subordinates.

title: What if My Daughter Had Died?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Russian Heavy Industry Strains to Become Flexible
description: Inside the Kirov factory gates, rows of unsold K-700 tractors, once the workhorse of Soviet collective farms, have been gathering snow through the Russian winter. In late March, the factory announced that it was ending production of its tractors for lack of customers.

title: Japanese Coalition Scrambles to Replace Premier
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's announcement today that he would resign sent his governing coalition scrambling to form a new government and to salvage at least some of the economic and political reforms Mr. Hosokawa promised when he took office last year.

title: A Defense By Banker
description: Gustavo Gomez Lopez, the man at the center of the collapse of Banco Latino C.A. of Venezuela, emerged in New York yesterday to deny the Venezuelan Government's accusations of fraud.

title: Blue Book Of Trends Is Yellow
description: ALL right, phone book fans, it's time to take a close look at the Nynex Manhattan Yellow pages now being distributed to 1.2 million customers.

title: Downdraft Pushes Bank Stocks to the Fore
description: Interest rates have been going up. Stock prices have been going down. Cash returns remain pretty low. Where can an investor make some money?

title: Special Inspection Team Rushes to Nuclear Plant
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission rushed a special inspection team to the Salem nuclear plant in southern New Jersey yesterday to investigate why the reactor experienced a power surge and two inappropriate start-ups of an emergency cooling system during a shutdown on Thursday.

title: U.S. Goals on Trade Ebbing With Japan Reformer Gone
description: The res ignation of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan has deprived the Clinton Administration of the agent of change it was counting on to open Japan's closed markets, and it has left the White House uncertain it will achieve its trade objectives with Tokyo anytime soon.

title: An MCI Vice President Is Named to No. 2 Post
description: The MCI Communications Corporation elevated Gerald H. Taylor today to be president of its worldwide communications business, a move that solidifies him as the most important person in the company after its chairman, Bert C. Roberts Jr.

title: Liftoff Delayed Till Today
description: High winds caused a one-day postponement of the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour today. Another launching attempt has been scheduled for 7:05 A.M. on Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6 GLOOMY JOCKEYING IN TOKYO

title: Israeli Bars Entry to Palestinians of West Bank and Gaza
description: Israel took measures today to rid itself of Arab labor from the occupied territories by imposing an indefinite ban on Palestinian entry and by deciding to bring in thousands of foreign construction workers and farm hands.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is something to be said for loyalty. DEBRA WINGER, who was romantically involved with Nebraska Senator BOB KERREY about a decade ago, is going to Omaha to be hostess of a $1,000-a-head reception for his re-election campaign tomorrow.

title: Arming Pakistan Doesn't Promote Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Owners Get Break on Health Plans
description: OWNERS of small businesses who are struggling with rising health care costs just got a good reason to put their spouses on the payroll. The Internal Revenue Service will now permit such couples to pay all their family medical expenses with pretax dollars.

title: Religion Notes
description: Messengers of Peace

title: Ford Auction Of S.& L. Is Near an End
description: The auction of the Ford Motor Company's First Nationwide Bank unit heads into its final days with three bidders in the running.

title: New Claims in Tyson Case
description: The Indiana Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a judge must review claims that a woman MIKE TYSON was convicted of raping had earlier falsely accused a high school classmate of rape. The appeals court said Marion (Ind.) Superior Court Judge PATRICIA GIFFORD, who presided over Tyson's rape trial, must consider Tyson's second motion for post-conviction relief, originally filed Feb. 26, 1993.

title: How Norfolk, Va., Put Workfare to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Jogger Raped by 5 Teens on Coney Island
description: A 43-year-old Russian immigrant was raped by a gang of five teen-agers after being attacked while jogging Thursday evening near the beach in Coney Island, Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The youths attacked the woman about 8:15 P.M. as she ran on a desolate section of the boardwalk between Fifth and Eighth Streets, the police said. She was dragged under the boardwalk and beaten and raped. The youths, whose ages range from 16 to 18, fled with the woman's watch, the police said. There were no arrests.

title: Teamsters Set Talks With Small Haulers
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters agreed today to meet with representatives of 18 small trucking companies on Saturday. The agreement held out the possibility that union employees of those companies might return to work under temporary accords while the union's strike against four large truckers continues.

title: Turmoil in the Schools; 'My Integrity Is Not for Sale,' Cortines Says in His Statement
description: Following is the statement made yesterday by Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines on the appointment of a fiscal monitor for the New York City public schools.

title: Cost of Malpractice: A Special Report; Medical Incompetence: A Whispered Factor in Rising Costs
description: When John L. Rounsaville Jr., a 44-year-old father of three, checked into a hospital here for routine lower-back surgery, he expected to be released within a day or so and be back at work soon after that. But when he did get out, almost six months later, he was strapped in a wheelchair.

title: Race at This Masters Goes to the Slickest, And So Far, It's Mize
description: On Augusta National greens that were as hard and slick as Formica, the table was set today for a classic Masters weekend. Larry Mize, one of the game's best putters, continued to display his prowess in that department. He shot 71 that put him at 139, five under par, and gave him a one-stroke lead over Greg Norman, Dan Forsman and Tom Lehman.

title: Salzburg Factions Seeking Peace
description: Until Herbert von Karajan's death in 1989, the upper-crust musical life of this gorgeous Alpine city hummed with pearly precision. There were occasional off-season events that redounded to his and the city's glory. But basically there were the venerable summer Salzburg Festival, which he ran, and the newer Salzburg Easter Festival, which he founded in 1967.

title: Turmoil in the Schools; Excerpts Of Remarks By the Mayor
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's remarks in answer to questions from reporters throughout the day about Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines's announcement of his resignation:

title: Don't Let Up On Japan
description: Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's resignation amid allegations of financial misconduct will do little to boost foreign confidence in the Japanese economy. Coming on top of reports of deep-seated malaise in Japanese industry, the latest crisis will doubtless put pressure on the Clinton Administration to back off from its demands that Japan to import more American products.

title: Genetically Altered Tomato Moves Toward U.S. Approval
description: A Federal panel today cleared the way for Government approval of the first genetically engineered food, a firmer tomato that can ripen longer on the vine before being picked for shipment.

title: Another Setback for Gooden
description: After his last start of spring training, Dwight Gooden said his goal for the season was to stay healthy and not miss a start. He can throw that dream out the window.

title: Editorial Notebook; Justice Blackmun's Voice
description: If Roe v. Wade defined Justice Harry Blackmun's jurisprudence in the popular mind, there was another landmark that should have told the world about his independent spirit. It was a speech he delivered, a lay sermon actually, in August 1973, six months after the famous abortion ruling at the close of his third full term on the Supreme Court. Though already the author of one of history's major decisions, he was just beginning to speak out boldly in his personal voice.

title: Review/Dance; A Mexican Choreographer Devises Puzzling Fragments
description: Four Latin American choreographers were featured in "Muevete," the program arranged by Merian Soto that was presented on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. It was an evening dominated by solos.

title: Hornets Move Closer To the Nets
description: Sometimes it just doesn't pay to get out of bed. Tonight it didn't even pay for New Jersey to get off the airplane.

title: Knicks Miss Ewing, and Their Big Shot to Clinch
description: Unfortunately for the Knicks, there were no last-second heroics. Rolando Blackman missed what would have been a game-tying 3-pointer from 24 feet with three seconds to play. Derek Harper deflected the rebound to Hubert Davis, who also missed a top-of-the-key jumper that would have been ruled a 2-pointer as the final buzzer sounded.

title: The State of the State, Proudly Restated; Cuomo Writes the Book on New York's Strengths, and (Surprise!) Finds Much to Like
description: It is only in the next-to-last paragraph of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's new book, "The New York Idea: An Experiment in Democracy," that he explains why he decided to write a 250-page treatise about the programs, policies and philosophical underpinnings of New York State government.

title: Bulls Gain One, Lose One
description: The Chicago Bulls yesterday activated guard JOHN PAXSON from the injured list and replaced him with center BILL CARTWRIGHT. Paxson had been placed on the injured list because of tendinitis in the left knee. He has missed 15 games because of the injury. Paxson began the season on the injured list because of the tendinitis and missed the first 31 games of the season. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 10 about Lawrence E. Spivak, originator of the NBC News program "Meet the Press," misidentified the occasion on which Whitaker Chambers first accused Alger Hiss of being a Communist. It was on Aug. 3, 1948, before the House Un-American Activities Committee; the charge was repeated two weeks later on "Meet the Press."

title: Turmoil in the Schools: Profiles; 2 Figures Familiar With Political Battles
description: Leonard Hellenbrand, whose job as the New York City school system's budget director has put him at the center of a political battle between City Hall and the Board of Education, is the sort of career official alternately praised as an insider with vital institutional knowledge or condemned as a bureaucrat bent on perpetuating the status quo.

title: Abbott Near-Perfect; Yankees Are
description: The expectations arrived from Anaheim, Calif., before Jim Abbott ever did. Reaching them was the trouble. Sometimes last season they overwhelmed him, sometimes they aggravated him, but sometimes he reached the zenith and was the precise pitcher the Yankees drooled over. Last night was one of those rare, nearly perfect, nights.

title: New York Gives Everyone Access to Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Accused of Running Network for Pirated Software
description: A Federal grand jury has accused a student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of using university computers to distribute more than $1 million worth of pirated software over the Internet, the global computer network.

title: Yankees Ask Guarantees Against Relocation Loss
description: In the latest round of bargaining over New York City's efforts to keep the Yankees in the Bronx, the team has demanded financial guarantees from the city to guard against losses if a proposed $275 million renovation to Yankee Stadium requires a temporary relocation to Shea Stadium.

title: India Unmoved in Arms Talks With U.S.
description: A visit to India by the United States Deputy Secretary of State ended today with no sign of a breakthrough in the Clinton Administration's effort to prevent an intensified nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan.

title: Adjustable Mortgage Group Holds Ground
description: The group of adjustable-rate mortgage funds is very young -- of 53 funds, only eight have track records of three years or more.

title: Walter Industries' Bondholders in Accord
description: Bondholders of Walter Industries Inc. said yesterday that they had reached an agreement that would let them proceed with a bankruptcy reorganization plan for the home builder.

title: Long Bond Price Dips; Yield 7.25%
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as the bond market began to brace for two important reports on its growing obsession: inflation.

title: Kurt Cobain, Hesitant Poet Of 'Grunge Rock,' Dead at 27
description: Kurt Cobain, the ragged-voiced product of a Pacific Northwest timber town who helped to create the grunge rock sound that has dominated popular music for the last four years, was found dead today at his home here. The police said they believed that Mr. Cobain, the lead singer, guitarist and songwriter for the influential band Nirvana, killed himself with a single shotgun blast to the head.

title: Murmansk Journal; Port Is Dying, but You Need a Tuxedo
description: If not for all the platinum blondes in little black dresses, it would be tempting to say that the world's largest Arctic city is dying.

title: The Nightmare in Central Africa
description: The neighboring African countries of Rwanda and Burundi have been plunged into unimaginable anarchy and bloodshed. This week's violence -- the plane crash that killed the two nations' Presidents, the police and army rampage that has killed over a thousand people in Kigali, the Rwandan capital -- was only the latest convulsion in decades of ethnic warfare. Relief agencies estimate that 100,000 people have died in Burundi since October.

title: Turmoil in the Schools: The Relationship; Meeting Turns Into Last Straw
description: The frustration that led Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines to tender his resignation yesterday began to build two months ago, when the Mayor started to issue budget demands and Mr. Cortines shot back, "I was not hired to be in anybody's hip pocket."

title: Review/Television; A Weighty New Entree On the Public-Affairs Menu
description: People who look forward to Saturday afternoons in spring so they can stay home and watch the public-affairs lineup on Channel 13 have a new treat this year. Ben Wattenberg now occupies the 1:30 P.M. slot with "Think Tank," an intelligently conceived pro-and-con half-hour on matters of moment.

title: SPLIT WITH MAYOR PROMTS CORTINES TO SAY HE'LL QUIT
description: Ramon C. Cortines, who became Chancellor of the New York City schools seven months ago, said yesterday that he was resigning because Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was interfering in the management of the school system. He announced his resignation, effective July 1, an hour after the Mayor appointed a political ally as an outside monitor of Board of Education finances.

title: White House Asks: Can Member of Congress Join the Court?
description: With Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine in mind, the White House asked the Justice Department today for advice about whether the Constitution would prevent a member of Congress from moving to the Supreme Court.

title: Aluminum Co. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included after-tax one-time charges totaling $ 117.9 million, or $ 1.32 a share, including a special charge of $ 50 million, or 56 cents a share, for closing a forgings and extrusion plant in Vernon, Calif.; and an extraordinary loss of $ 67.9 million, or 76 cents a share, for the early redemption of 7 percent debentures due 2011 that carried an effective interest rate of 14.7 percent.c-Net income(Loss)Revenue represented sales, operating revenues and other income.

title: Seaway Food Town (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-After a charge of $ 256,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: 2 Nations Joined by Common History of Genocide
description: Rwanda and Burundi are like twins -- landlocked neighbors in the heart of Africa with common histories, languages and ethnicity.

title: Sports of The Times; Fruit Picked Before Its Time
description: UNTIL this season, college basketball, men's basketball in particular, was becoming wearisome: the tired cliches, the coaches' manipulative, controlling tactics, even the single-minded focus of the players.

title: Reviews/Fashion; 2 Designers Recall A Glamorous Past
description: If you're young, have a great body and like to be noticed at parties, you could do worse than scour the stores for evening clothes by Todd Oldham or Bradley Bayou.

title: Results Plus
description: BASKETBALL Magic Clinches Playoff Spot for First Time The Orlando Magic clinched the first National Basketball Association playoff berth in franchise history at home last night as Shaquille O'Neal had 40 points and 16 rebounds in a 117-103 victory over the Detroit Pistons. O'Neal's first dunk, 1 minute 38 seconds into the game, shook the shot clock so violently that it quit working for the rest of the half.

title: Robinson Honored Again
description: Purdue forward GLENN ROBINSON completed a sweep of college basketball's player of the year honors yesterday when he received the Classic Games John Wooden Award. Purdue Coach GENE KEADY accepted on behalf of Robinson, who was delayed en route to Los Angeles. JOHN WOODEN, the 83-year-old former U.C.L.A. coach who directed the Bruins to 10 National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in a 12-year span, presented the award at the Los Angeles Athletic Club. (AP)

title: Bridge
description: Many young experts have the talent to make a mark on the national scene, but demands of work and family limit their tournament appearances. One of them is Martin Fleisher, who learned his bridge in New Jersey and now lives in Northampton, Mass. On the diagramed deal, played in the New York Winter Regional Championships during the New Year's weekend, he brought home an "impossible" three no-trump contract by skillful play.

title: Expatriates in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Envoys Urge a Truce as Bosnia Fighting Eases
description: United States diplomats and United Nations officials worked here today to arrange a comprehensive cease-fire between Bosnian Army and Serbian nationalist forces as the intensity of fighting reportedly dropped off in the eastern Bosnian enclave of Gorazde.

title: Horse May Miss Santa Anita Derby
description: One day after Valiant Nature was pulled from the Santa Anita Derby, California's major Kentucky Derby prep race was in danger of losing another highly regarded runner today when it was announced that Soul of the Matter had a blister just above the hoof on his left foreleg.

title: Forced Circumcision Is Alien to Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Brief Romance, Growing Fears, Then 2 Deaths
description: In a city of disconnected lives and romantic possibility, it was hardly a remarkable beginning: a wine tasting on a spring evening, a swirl of Beaujolais and conversation, a lovely separated woman and a lonely divorced man, strangers with savoir faire and talent, bruised but still open to a relationship.

title: Review/Pop; Reaching Out to the World
description: When Angelique Kidjo danced across the stage of S.O.B.'s on Wednesday night, her outfit proclaimed her ambitions. On her wrists were spiky golden bracelets, akin to ancient West African ornaments; she wore black tights and, at her waist, ankle-length tassels that looked like a grass skirt but were apparently made of a synthetic fiber. As in her music, modern materials transform traditional designs.

title: Sonia Raiziss, A Poet, Critic And Editor, 85
description: Sonia Raiziss, a New York literary figure for many years, died on March 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85 and also had a home in Bucks County, Pa.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Reviews/Fashion; The Rise of the Fashion Stylist
description: At some point over the last few years, fashion stylists, with soothing smiles on their faces but whitened knuckles, began wresting creative control from fashion designers.

title: Rangers Lock Up Best Record. Next?
description: When a team wins the Presidents' Trophy in the National Hockey League, it doesn't get a trip to the White House or even a phone call from the President. The Rangers clinched this award, for being the best team in the regular season, last night when they beat Toronto by 5-3 at Madison Square Garden. They accepted the cheers of their fans and the congratulations of their employers and held a modest celebration among themselves.

title: Review/Music; How to Play Famously on the Fringes of Fame
description: Russell Sherman keeps reappearing at the edges of the concert world. On Wednesday, it was at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater, where he played Brahms, Beethoven, Bartok and Schumann for a small, devoted audience.

title: Dow Declines 19 Points, Ending a 3-Day Run-Up
description: Breaking a three-day winning streak, stock traders bid down the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday by 19 points, to 3,674.26, in restrained trading. Still, the Dow finished ahead for the week by some 38 points.

title: Clinton Says Health Plan Isn't Politics
description: President Clinton today angrily assailed critics who suggested that he was more interested in politics than policy in his plans to overhaul the nation's health care system.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred Int'l(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net lossc-After a charge of $ 16,969,000, or 19 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: We'd Better Sign On To Law of the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the new pricing policy of an on-line computer service misstated the company's name. It is Dialog Information Services Inc., not Dialog Information Systems.

title: Ex-Chief's Pay From Borden
description: Borden Inc., the troubled food conglomerate, paid its former chairman and chief executive, Anthony D'Amato, a severance package that the company valued at $4.42 million, company filings with regulators show.

title: Hebron Killer's Wife Says Massacre Is a 'Riddle'
