description: THE bridges that cross the Connecticut River, from Long Island Sound to its headwaters in northern New Hampshire, are celebrated in an exhibition at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex. The show, "By Design: Bridges Over the Connecticut River," features photographs, historic prints and maps, books, blueprints, vintage newspapers, scale models and a delightful home movie taken 60 years ago.

title: Thanks, I'll Walk
description: DOWN THE ASPHALT PATHThe Automobile and the American City.By Clay McShane.Illustrated. 288 pp. New York:Columbia University Press. $29.50.

title: Turning On the Juice
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the puckish French-born chef and owner of the Jo Jo and Vong restaurants in Manhattan, is the enfant terrible of modern French cooking. A decade ago, he turned his back on traditional meat stocks and glazes and built a vibrant and spare cuisine from juices, vinaigrettes, flavored oils and light broths.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AVIATION PAINTINGS

title: Ravens Team Up With a Renewed Yale Field
description: BABE RUTH played there, as did Lou Gehrig, Ted Williams, Ron Darling and a first baseman from Greenwich named George Bush. So, too, did the old Brooklyn Dodgers and Boston Braves, along with Albie Booth and Larry Kelley, Yale football immortals who also starred in baseball. Indeed, no other ball park in Connecticut is as steeped in history as Yale Field.

title: Commodities Danced in the Go-Go Years; Clintons and Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers to the (Child) Stars
description: There are two teachers and three students inside a three-room house trailer parked in the shadow of Dopey Drive at the Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif. -- hardly an educational quorum, under normal circumstances. The situation, however, is decidedly out of the ordinary, because the pupils in the well-appointed mobile home classroom are the juvenile stars of the popular television comdey series "Home Improvement."

title: POSTINGS: $10 Million Gift; Columbia's Audubon Center Is Picking Up Momentum
description: Thanks to a $10 million gift, construction can begin later this year on the second building of the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park in Washington Heights, Columbia University officials said last week.

title: Mutual Funds; Tax Free Doesn't Mean Risk Free
description: MILLIONS of mutual fund investors are buying municipal bond funds for the tax-free income, which looks better and better as tax rates keep creeping higher.

title: Like Firefighters, They Risk Their Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Spookspeak: How to Get Witting
description: Since the arrest of Aldrich H. Ames, the Central Intelligence Agency official accused of being a Soviet mole (a spy within the C.I.A.), agency officials have been reported to be walking the cat back (trying to understand what has happened by working backward from the present). It's spookspeak. And it's back in style. Here's a sampling:

title: Strong Profiles
description: "AT THE BOTTOM OF EVERYTHING THERE IS STILL THE cube," declares the furniture designer Dakota Jackson. His four-story Manhattan town house off Gramercy Park is filled with prototypes of his geometrically inspired work. A leather chaise sits on legs bent like a folded paper chopsticks wrapper, and his latest library chair, of laminated sweet-gum poplar faced in maple, has a back made of a rectangular block pressed into a curve. In Jackson's hands, everything solid seems to melt into movement, a trick he learned as much from his days as a magician and a dancer as from his deep appreciation for Cubist art. Modernism's ability to bring motion to form has helped make it "the theme of the century," he says. In his home, form is also infused with emotion, thanks to richly hued walls and rooms filled with artwork by his children and his friends.

title: Michael S. Shower, Unicef Adviser, 44
description: Michael S. Shower, a senior adviser at the United Nations Children's Fund, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: Q and A
description: Biking in Tuscany

title: Technology; Quietly, Hand-Powered Lawn Mowers Make a Comeback
description: JUST wait. The pleasant sounds of spring -- birds chirping, children playing outside after the winter's confinement -- will soon be interrupted by the insistent snarl of unmuffled gasoline engines. It's almost lawn-mowing season again.

title: U.N. Warns Serbs on Gorazde; Move Could Lead to Air Strikes
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali warned Serbian forces today to pull back from Gorazde, setting in motion a process that could lead to NATO air strikes against the Serbian positions in the eastern Bosnian town, which is a United Nations safe area.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter from Prof. Marc Linder last Sunday about the Labor Department's enforcement efforts in the garment industry misstated the writer's views on the misclassification of workers. Professor Linder quoted Labor officials to the effect that 38 percent of apparel employers had misclassified workers as independent contractors, not that 38 percent of apparel employers had been misclassified as independent contractors.

title: Pamela Orthwein, Colby Jensen
description: Pamela Ann Orthwein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolphus Busch Orthwein Jr. of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Christopher Colby Jensen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert David Jensen of Old Saybrook, Conn. The Rev. Foley Beach, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Philip in Atlanta.

title: Israel and Settlers Must Practice Understanding
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Erdman, Peter F. Rizzo
description: Charlotte Eve Erdman, a daughter of Eldred P. Erdman of Hopewell, N.J., and David Erdman of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Foley Rizzo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Rizzo of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Edward F. Maloney performed the ceremony at St. William's Catholic Church on St. Simon's Island, Ga.

title: Fleeing Vietnam
description: SOUTH WIND CHANGING By Jade Ngoc Quang Huynh. 305 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. $20.

title: One Man's Legal Odyssey
description: AS HE SAT in the living room of his white-frame home on this city's hardscrabble, mostly Hispanic west side, Demetrio P. Rodriguez spoke intensely about how poor schoolchildren have been robbed by the Texas Legislature.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Peter R. Roach;
Safety's His Subject; School Is His Turf
description: A GLANCE into Peter R. Roach's office at the Hartford school system's headquarters tells much about his job as security administrator. In one corner lies a hand-held metal detector, used mostly to screen those attending special events like high-school sports; on the floor sits a carton of walkie-talkies, the kind that the police carry on their belts. So much paraphernalia crowds the room, in fact, that Mr. Roach has trouble finding his cup of coffee.

title:
Viewpoints;
The Department Store, Revitalized
description: THE continuing Macy bankruptcy has a cast of glittering power brokers that rivals "Miracle on 34th Street." There is Cyrus R. Vance, the mediator and former Secretary of State; big-money players like Fidelity Investments, GE Capital and Prudential; larger-than-life society tycoons like A. Alfred Taubman and Laurence A. Tisch; and Federated Department Stores, the owner of Bloomingdale's, which is trying as hard as it can to merge with its fabled competitor.

title: Rights Chief Upsets Board Of N.A.A.C.P
description: The new director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People held a closed meeting on Friday with black militants and leftists to discuss increasing their influence in the organization. The session has angered N.A.A.C.P. board members, who learned of it only afterward.

title: The Great Phil Rizzuto Debate
description: THE POLITICS OF GLORY How Baseball's Hall of Fame Really Works. By Bill James. 464 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: Barbarians at the Ball Park
description: LORDS OF THE REALMThe Real History of Baseball.By John Helyar.592 pp. New York: Villard Books. $24.

title: 50 Years of Serving God, With an Attitude
description: "CELIBACY was never a problem," said the Rev. Vincent J. Termine, "and I didn't take a vow of poverty. But obedience, ah. . ."

title:
END PAPER;
A Writer's College Homecoming
description: Writing about a college is like writing about your parents while they are still alive. I was warned about this from the beginning, warned that love and loyalty wouldn't help once I attempted a nonfiction account of a year at Kenyon College, my alma mater, my current employer. It was a no-win proposition, a kamikaze flight, an untenured professor's invitation to his own career suicide. And an irresistible idea.

title: HOW DO TOBACCO EXECUTIVES LIVE WITH THEMSELVES?
description: The freedom-of-choice mantra that Philip Morris spokespeople intone loses legitimacy when you think of the carcinogens to which nonsmokers are exposed every time someone lights up. Smoking is no more a matter of freedom of choice than is driving drunk on a crowded highway. SCOTT DOUGLAS Wilton, Conn.

title: Wall Street; Utilities: Way Down and Likely to Be Out a While
description: HOW bleak is the outlook for utility stocks? The group, whose fortunes in the market move inversely with interest rates, managed to get a rock-bottom 96 out of 96 rating by Value Line last month. And little wonder. The Dow Jones utility average finished on Friday at 194.63, a drop of more than 20 percent over the last six months, and analysts aren't expecting any big turn.

title: Prison Boot Camps Prove No Sure Cure
description: No one complained at 5:45 this morning when a drill instructor shouted for another round of push-ups on the cold and wet pavement wriggling with worms that crawled from the newly thawed earth. But a few hours later, 38 young inmates sat in a circle and spoke uneasily about the final task in this grueling boot camp prison: they had to go home.

title: JUST TAKE AWAY THEIR GUNS
description: What a radical idea -- take guns away from criminals, instead of from law-abiding citizens! Why hasn't anyone thought of this before? Wilson makes so much sense that, in our confused system of justice, his proposal probably will never become reality.

title: Antonio Pagan: A Lightning Rod Gathers Storms
description: On the Lower East Side, political discourse can get ugly. But even by its tough standards, the reaction to Antonio Pagan has been nasty. One local paper regularly portrays him as as a cockroach. A bloody syringe was once stuck on his office door.

title: The Arts of India
description: To the Editor: It was with great pleasure that we read Edward A. Gargan's article about Kerala, "Where Monsoons and Sea Rule" (March 6), since it reflected the experiences we had while spending three weeks driving through Southern India in March 1993.

title: Is Knight a Saint or Sinner? Recruits Willing to Find Out
description: Neil Reed is a coach's son. Andrae Patterson is an Air Force brat. Reed is a 6-foot-2-inch point guard, Patterson a 6-9 power forward. Reed is white; Patterson is black. They became fast friends last summer when their lives intersected at Bob Knight.

title: Double Tragedy in Africa
description: So great is the crisis overload on the world's news circuits that many Americans have been only fleetingly aware of continuing massacres in Burundi. Since last October, more than 100,000 people have been killed while 700,000 people have fled this central African country. A civil war between the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi tribes has spilled over into neighboring Rwanda -- and now both countries teeter on anarchy.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL: NONFICTION
description: CRACKING THE SHOW By Thomas Boswell. Doubleday, $23.

title: 4 Are Killed as 2 Small Planes Collide and Fall Into a Factory
description: Two small planes trying to land at Republic Airport collided over Farmingdale in Suffolk County yesterday morning and crashed into a factory, setting it ablaze, authorities said. All four people aboard the two planes died.

title: Navy Prepares a Manual About Sexual Harassment
description: With its penchant for by-the-book precision, the military has manuals for just about everything -- legal manuals to punish lawbreakers, technical manuals to assemble weapons. Now, the Navy has prepared a new manual on how to recognize, prevent and deal with sexual harassment.

title: Losers by the Lake
description: THE CURSE OF ROCKY COLAVITOA Loving Look at a Thirty-Year Slump.By Terry Pluto.Illustrated. 300 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $22.50.

title: Back to the Future
description: MODERN ARCHITEC- ture, it is sometimes said, took a wrong turn in the years after World War II. A movement that had started out in the 1920's with an idealistic agenda for social change had transformed itself into the slick style of American corporate culture. But there was a time when the modern movement and corporate America were not thought to be opposed in their aims. From the late 1940's to the early 1960's, the industrialist and the designer were commonly viewed as partners, allies in the pursuit of humane goals. General Electric and the disciples of the Bauhaus were of one mind in supposing that progress was the 20th century's most important product.

title:
STYLE;
Oracle on 34th Street
description: I often confer with a pint-sized, fortyish, eccentrically stylish woman who guides me through the turbulent trends of fashion. She's disputatious to be sure, but also uncanny and usually right. I ignore her counsel at my own peril. Once, though, I was smitten with a reversible gold and loden anorak by Moschino; on its final markdown, I sent her an S O S.

title: Around Midtown, Luxurious Lunch
description: ADRIENNE ** (212) 903-3918; 700 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street in the Peninsula Hotel; $$$$; all major credit cards

title: Author, Artist and, Suddenly, Activist
description: LIKE the young hero who learns to care in one of one his books, "Pierre: A Cautionary Tale," Maurice Sendak these days is expressing a new social and political awareness. And what he cares about most is children.

title: When Living for Baseball Is Second; Cancer Gives Phillies First Baseman a New Perspective on the Game
description: John Kruk has used many a person as a straight man. Teammates. Managers. Coaches. Reporters. David Letterman.

title: Lehman A Surprise At Hostile Masters
description: When nerves are exposed and throats are dry on Sunday down in Amen Corner, experience might yet prove to be the key element for winning the Masters. But after three rounds, the leader of the season's first major championship is a player who has never won on the PGA Tour and who is playing in just his second Masters.

title: Louise Klebanoff, Peter Fleischman
description: Dr. Louise Michelle Klebanoff, a daughter of Gail G. Klebanoff of Verona, N.J., and the late Michael Klebanoff, was married last evening to Peter Norman Fleischman, the son of Harry Fleischman of Wantagh, L.I., and the late Natalie Fleischman. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Jeh Johnson and Susan DiMarco
description: Dr. Susan DiMarco and Jeh Johnson grew up across the street from each other on Cottam Hill in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. He remembers her Hula-Hooping in the driveway for hours and rolling up the skirt of her uniform on the way to the school bus; she remembers that he was too shy to talk to girls.

title: NEWS ABOUT THE MAGAZINE
description: One topic has stood out from the reader response to the Magazine redesign that started Oct. 31. Many readers have taken favorable notice of new features and formats and increased editorial content and color. But the most frequent reaction has been a complaint, epitomized by a five-word letter from Daniel S. Woloshen of Fairfield, Conn.: "Your print is too small."

title: Suicidal in Venice Beach
description: SO WHAT'S WITH NORA Ephron and Christmas? Her last movie, last summer's romantic hit "Sleepless in Seattle," included a number of Christmas scenes, one of them a Dec. 24 phone call to a radio psychiatrist that sets the whole plot in motion.

title: Finding the Perfect Place for the Perfect Plant
description: IT'S funny how you bump into a plant at exactly the right moment. I'd just come back from a weekend on the family farm in Maryland, where I expected to find more winter damage. We'd had our share of bitter nights down there, and plenty of snow. And I was relieved to see that my fig tree survived. (I think. The tips of the branches look scorched, but there are buds. We'll see how well they leaf out.)

title: An Incorrigibly Adorable Thief
description: THE BURGLAR WHO TRADED TED WILLIAMS By Lawrence Block. 258 pp. New York: Dutton. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL: NONFICTION
description: FIELD OF SCREAMS The Dark Underside of America's National Pastime. By Richard Scheinin. Norton, paper, $14.95.

title: Still Water
description: IN A SUBURBAN TOronto garden, the architects Brigitte Shim and Howard Sutcliffe have demonstrated that the modernist vocabulary is not an affront to nature, but a rich means to echo it. "We wanted to create a space of metaphysical calm," says Shim. To symbolize time's passage, they chose materials -- wood, steel and granite -- that weather at varying rates. A crushed-stone path leads to the centerpiece of the design, a painted steel pavilion cantilevered over a forested ravine. Its stone base seems to float on a serene reflecting pool. Columns as slender as spring saplings, painted in Mies van der Rohe's favorite graphite black, support the wing-shaped roof. For all its angular modernity, the design recalls traditional Japanese tea gardens, where a twisting route serves as a symbol of our passage through life.

title: Should Preservation Count for Everything?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Expanding Vernon Resort Area
description: Like many Sussex Countyans, I was shocked by an incredibly unbalanced front-page article, "Vernon Resort Expansion Plan Meets Criticism," on March 6. In addition to unjustly damaging the image and accomplishments of Gene Mulvihill, chairman of Great American Recreation, and his many Sussex County enterprises, the article has also slandered our area State Senator, several Vernon Township officials, local business people and, in effect, our county itself.

title: Manager's Profile
description: Eric E. Ryback Fund: Lindner Dividend, $1.5 billion in assets. Manager since 1984. (Sponsor: Ryback Management Corp., St. Louis.) Born: March 19, 1952; Detroit.

title: Shuttle Embarks on High-Tech Scrutiny of Environment
description: Six astronauts set out today on a space shuttle mission to test an advanced radar technology that may enable people to manage the environment better in the future -- and perhaps catch some tantalizing glimpses of life in the past.

title: A Plant Closes, To Little Note
description: On March 22, Berger Industries made the kind of announcement that might have been expected to shock a community. The company said it was closing its steel fittings division at 74-16 Grand Avenue, eliminating 100 jobs.

title: JERSEYANA
description: CHARLES FORT, who was born 120 years ago, was a very odd chap. A reclusive, pudgy man with thick glasses and a walrus mustache, he spent his days in musty libraries poring through old newspapers and books, searching for accounts of weird events that seemed to defy the laws of science.

title: Free Coaching For McEnroe
description: To The Editor:

title: Trans-Atlantic Flights To Dublin Now Nonstop
description: FROM 1945 until the late 1950's, 80 percent of trans-Atlantic air traffic went through Shannon Airport in western Ireland, a refueling station for planes that did not have the range to travel nonstop between North America and the European capitals. It was at Shannon, in 1947, that the first duty-free shop opened, giving travelers somewhere to spend their money during the stopover.

title: Helping Way Stations on New York's Greenway Trail
description: IT'S spring, and an appropriate time for thoughts to turn to the Greenway, the 300-mile system of trails that was supposed to stretch from Westchester to Albany, linking communities on both sides of the Hudson River. Whatever happened to it?

title: Hodges, Once a Met, Always a Dodger, Should Be in Hall
description: Now that the former Yankees shortstop Phil Rizzuto and the late Leo Durocher, the manager with 2,010 major league victories in 24 seasons, have entered baseball's Hall of Fame via the recommendation of the Veterans Committee, thoughts arise about those who haven't made it yet. One player, in particular, comes to mind: Gil Hodges.

title: Judge Blocks Reopening of Exploded Pipeline
description: A state judge ordered a natural gas company today to halt its plans to reopen a pipeline that exploded near an apartment complex in Edison, N.J., last month.

title: Apply to College (Hold the Paper)
description: THOSE aren't just computer nerds applying for college via the high school's modem.

title: Biltmore Hotel
description: To the Editor: It was refreshing to read William Grimes's excellent article "The Biltmore Bounces Back in Florida" (Jan. 23).

title: Bossy's Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The View From: New London; A House for the Future Finally Lives Up to Its Billing
description: THE Winslow Ames house at Connecticut College in New London has a flat roof, a modular plan, factory-made steel frame sections and tidy built-in bookcases. Erected in the 1930's as a house for the future, it nearly became a thing of the past in the 1980's. Now it is again a place for the future.

title: Melissa Schorr and David Condo
description: Melissa Ann Schorr, who was until recently the national sales manager of the Berkley Shirt Company in New York, and David Crittenden Condo, the president of the Hathaway Shirt Company in New York, were married yesterday in Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Otis Young officiated at the First Plymouth Congregational Church.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Maxwell Paces Rockets Hakeem Olajuwon tried to respond to shouts of "m.v.p.! m.v.p.!" but the Rockets' guard Vernon Maxwell stole the show with 27 points yesterday as Houston beat visiting San Antonio, 100-89, in a Midwest Division showdown. Houston increased its lead over San Antonio to two games. (AP)

title: Evening Hours; Avedon In Person And Image
description: An exhibition opens with parties, March 23 and 29, at the Whitney Museum.

title: JOHN MACK'S ABDUCTEES
description: If enormous energy could be harnessed to transport beings across entire worlds, then why would these spectacular travelers be so limited in their genetic technology that they needed an unending stream of human abductees to fiddle around with? If there were life forms capable of a technology that could propel them across the universe, is it likely that such wondrous creatures would need to snatch and probe like a bunch of clumsy proctologists? And wouldn't such extraordinary encounters provoke more original stories? EDWARD DOOLEY Needham, Mass.

title: CURRENCY
A Gathering Of the Clan
description: WHEN the invitation to a reunion of my husband's family came last year in the form of a five-page missive from his parents, Marjorie and Karl Ackerman, I greeted it with some trepidation. The English novelist Anthony Hope once wrote that "good families are generally worse than any others," and my husband's family, a large, congenial group, is a very good family. Like most American families, it is diverse -- its numbers include artists and mortgage bankers, builders and businessmen, a geographer and an elephant trainer -- and, like most, it has no familial homestead. Its members are scattered across the points of the compass, as far west as Oklahoma and Texas and as far east as Japan. So early in 1993, Marjorie and Karl rolled out a map, push-pinned the location of family members in the United States, and picked a point roughly midway between: Tennessee. Then they set out from their home in Washington on a 1,200-mile pilgrimage in search of a park in that state that might satisfy the brood. They deliberately sidestepped any place near Nashville -- they wanted the family together for the whole weekend, not wandering off on side trips to the Grand Ole Opry. They settled on Fall Creek Falls, on the western edge of the Cumberland Plateau in eastern Tennessee, a 16,800-acre park that has an inn, cabins, tennis courts, an 18-hole championship golf course, horseback-riding, an Olympic pool, boating on a 350-acre lake stocked with largemouth bass, channel cat and bluegill, all surrounded by some spectacular natural scenery.

title: Rosedale In Spring Exhibition
description: THE Taylors have been thinking spring since last summer. The family, for three generations as the owners and operators of Rosedale Nurseries here, are major contributors to the Rockefeller Center Flower and Garden Show, which started yesterday and runs through next Sunday. Rosedale's plans for this year's show, the second yearly, began in accord with Rockefeller Center's wishes as early as mid-1993.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Lee Roy Parnell: 'On the Road'Arista 18739-2; CD and cassette.

title: In Battle Over Toxic Waste, The Question Is: Cap or Dig?
description: Seven years after a metal refiner agreed to rid a piece of its property in Maspeth of toxic waste, the project remains stalled as a constellation of combatants -- including the company, state officials, community leaders and the United States Post Office -- struggle over its future.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15 EVACUATIONS FROM RWANDA BEGIN Troops from the United States, France and Belgium moved in to start evacuating foreign nationals from Rwanda, where thousands of people have been reported killed in three days of tribal warfare. 1 The U.S. Ambassador in Rwanda decided on overland evacuation. 6

title: A Writer Who Sees Humor In the Fear of Commitment
description: AN INORDINATE PROPORTION OF "Four Weddings and a Funeral" takes place in churches. But then Richard Curtis, who wrote the screenplay, lives in a church, in the Ladbroke Grove section of London. It's a converted Baptist chapel, with a full-immersion font, which Mr. Curtis and his companion, Emma Freud, a London broadcaster, plan to convert into a fish pond. For now, their only sacrilege is the altarpiece, a giant photograph of Miranda Richardson as Queen Elizabeth I in the wildly popular BBC series "Blackadder," which Mr. Curtis co-wrote.

title:
In the Region/New Jersey;
Linking Tax Relief for Offices to Asbestos Problems
description: SHOULD the cost of removing asbestos be taken into account in determining the assessed value of a commercial property? Last July, the State Supreme Court upheld a State Tax Court ruling permitting a reduction in valuation for a 25-year-old structure in Hackensack. The decision was the first in which the state's highest court ruled that asbestos conditions should be considered in determining value.

title: Bearing Kimchi, A Dodger Is a First
description: Baseball is a game of firsts, mosts and longests, and though his major league career has been brief, Chan Ho Park has already amassed his share.

title: POSTINGS: Third Manhattan Office; Driver's License Express
description: Spending an afternoon waiting to get a driver's license renewed has never been fun. In the hope of making the process less painful, the State Department of Motor Vehicles has been opening satellite offices in business locations.

title: Don't Worry, Be Peppy
description: Lloyd Cutler, the 76-year-old Washington legal establishmentarian, was asked by a reporter if he would consider staying on as President Clinton's White House counsel beyond the short period that had been announced. Mr. Cutler replied that he limited his planned stay "in part because I'm married fairly recently to a very young and peppy wife and I want to spend some more time with her."

title: Illinois Wants Grant's Tomb
description: If State Senator Judy Baar Topinka of Illinois had her way, Grant's Tomb would be packed up and shipped out of New York City on the next train.

title: Cantor's Vision Inspires Synagogue Choir
description: AFTER several modest attempts to achieve order in the chapel of M'Kor Shalom Synagogue on a recent evening, Cantor Anita Hochman became serious. "What is this -- a party?" she demanded of the men and women who were clustered in small groups.

title: Shouldn't Art Support Start at Home?
description: Your frequent articles on the Westchester Arts Council (the latest, "Art Advocates Troop to Albany to Seek a Piece of the Pie," March 20) and its attempts to seek public funds omit a crucial reality: that the council evidently sees itself as a quasi-public agency with more and more financing from the public rather than the private sector.

title: The Fundamental Things Apply
description: PURE BASEBALLPitch by Pitch for the Advanced Fan.By Keith Hernandez and Mike Bryan.259 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $21.

title: Views on Co-op Sublets and Seller Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Eva Lindholm, Iraj Ispahani
description: Eva-Kristiina Lindholm and Mirza Iraj Ispahani, vice presidents in the global asset management division of J. P. Morgan & Company in Geneva, were married on Friday in a civil ceremony at the Registry Office in Geneva.

title:
A LA CARTE;
2 Guides to Finding Smoke-Free Eating Places
description: ALTHOUGH New York City requires restaurants seating more than 50 diners to offer no-smoking sections, New Jersey restaurants are not compelled to do so. But they are required by law to post signs stating whether they have nonsmoking sections.

title: Most Writers Love New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits
description: To Benefit Creativity MONDAY -- Now in its 23d season, Playwrights Horizons, which presents the works of contemporary playwrights, composers and lyricists, will hold a benefit party at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. Martin Short, Blair Brown, Michael Moriarty and several other entertainment figures are expected at the event along with music by the Red Hot Charlie Peppers, a 14-piece swing orchestra. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $500, from (212) 564-1235.

title: Oedipal Opera
description: To the Editor:

title: Berkoff Directs a Quirky, Stylish 'Richard II'
description: RICHARD II (1367-1400) WAS NOT A good king. He wasn't always a bad king either. As characterized by W. C. Sellar and R. J. Yeatman in their classic parody of English history, "1066 and All That," Richard was an "unbalanced king." This is why he was so easily toppled by his first cousin Bolingbroke, who "quickly mounted the throne and said he was Henry IV, Part I."

title: Las Vegas Stakes Claim in 90's Water War
description: The mirage that grew out of Bugsy Siegel's mid-century vision of showgirls and slot machines is now a metropolitan area of nearly one million people. But the nation's fastest-growing city, stitched to a Mojave Desert valley that receives only four inches of rain a year, is running out of water.

title: 'The Tyranny Of the Majority'
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Innovation for Commuting: Extra Car-Pool Lanes on the L.I.E.
description: IF it seems that the roads are more clogged than ever, it is not your imagination. Even with the population essentially unchanged since 1980, the number of households with three or more cars has increased 56 percent, according to the Long Island Regional Planning Board. And car pooling has declined nearly one-third in those 14 years.

title: Broom Brigade Will March on Montague Street
description: On Earth Day, an annual celebration of the environment, hundreds of volunteers will be pruning and painting in some of the city's parks, but a group of Brooklyn Heights residents has found another way to mark the day. Armed with brooms, they will be sweeping down Montague Street, the area's unofficial Main Street.

title: Political Notes; Green's Town Meetings Off and Running, Either Way
description: Taking a cue from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Public Advocate Mark J. Green launched a series of town meetings last week to hear the complaints and concerns of New Yorkers. And it did not go unnoticed in political circles that the first place he went was where Mr. Giuliani is politically weakest: to the heart of black Brooklyn.

title: Still Bewitched by the Mystery of Melted Sand
description: WHEN SCANDINAVIA dominated furnishings design in the 1950's, Timo Sarpaneva of Finland changed glass: He frosted surfaces, tinted thin-walled vessels and revived bubbles. In the 1960's, he went further, introducing chunky shapes and rough textures to modern glass.

title: About Automobiles
description: A freestanding weekly section of automobile news features and advertising begins today. Section 12.

title: When Tenants Become Owners: A Tale of Grass-Roots Redemption
description: On the night of March 1, 58 years into her life on Broadway Terrace, Lena Morais became a pioneer in the grassroots redemption of her home from America's savings-and-loan debacle.

title: When One Speaks of French, One Speaks of the National Soul
description: To the Editor:

title:
SOAPBOX;
We're Not Angels, but . . .
description: I WAS in the station at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street sometime around noon when the C train came in. The horn was blowing long and short, the call for police, and the conductor told me there was a homeless man smoking on the train. I found him and escorted him out of the car. But then I made a mistake, turning my back to the train as it started to move. The homeless man pushed me into it and then came after me -- all 6 feet, 3 inches and 200-plus pounds of him -- biting and kicking, and we wrestled all over the platform until some other officers arrived. Meanwhile some passengers were yelling, "My God, he's beating that poor man," and the person they were yelling at was me!

title:
ART;
Spanning Almost Five Centuries of Printmaking
description: AT the Katonah Museum of Art, it's back to basics. "Block/Plate/Stone: What a Print Is" educates the audience in the essentials of printmaking through examples dating from 1522 to the present. The purpose of the show is to challenge the common perception that print media are the stepchildren of painting. Intelligent viewing requires skill and connoisseurship, but the rudiments are easily demonstrated.

title: Light at the End Of the Chunnel?
description: FOR many car-conscious Americans awaiting the opening of the Channel Tunnel, the most disappointing thing to learn is, You won't be able to drive through it. Only trains -- some carrying cars -- will make the 31-mile trip between Calais, France, and Folkestone, England, and exactly when is not certain.

title: Elizabeth Hirsch, Jonathan Stern
description: Elizabeth Rhonda Hirsch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Hirsch of Lawrence, L.I., is to be married today to Jonathan Marc Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Stern of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Barry H. Greene is to perform the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title:
Your Own Account;
The Family That Gives Together
description: MANY families and individuals with substantial assets choose to give a portion of them to charity. A very effective way to do that is through a private foundation.

title: Trading Vacations For No Homework
description: AS SUMMER approaches, schoolchildren start to get restless; for most of them the school year is about to end. Their parents, on the other hand, start to worry. They fill out applications for summer camp and figure out vacations, but wonder just how their children will retain what they've learned until the fall.

title: The Quiz
description: They're ubiquitous! They pussyfoot and galumph around our/their homes. And on television they help sell cat and dog food and cat litter and togetherness. They scare and delight us in the movies and are securely entrenched in our mythology and fairy tales. So we should know a lot about these furry co-habitants, right? O.K., go for the quiz and see how canny you are about canis familiaris and felis catus. Fran Handman The Quiz 1. When were cats first domesticated? 10,000 B.C.; 3,500 B.C.; 1,500 B.C. When were dogs domesticated? 28,000 B.C.; 18,000 B.C.; 12,000 B.C.

title: In America; Abandoning Democracy
description: Under violent attack throughout Haiti, the struggling but unsubdued peasant organizations, representing 80 percent of the country's population, are making it clear that they are no longer fooled by the ruses and false promises of the Clinton Administration.

title: Ruth S. Sachs, David S. Kalvar
description: Ruth Schaff Sachs, the daughter of Manya S. Greif of Ruxton, Md., and Louis S. Sachs of Freeland, Md., was married last evening to David Seth Kalvar, the son of Stuart and Judith Kalvar of Hempstead, L.I. Rabbi Gila Colman Ruskin performed the ceremony at the George Peabody Library in Baltimore.

title: When Keeping in Fashion Can Become a Health Hazard
description: LAST month during a group-therapy session for young women battling eating disorders, an emaciated teen-ager brought in a magazine photograph of Kate Moss, the exceedingly thin fashion model, and thrust it at the nurse leading the discussion.

title: Ian Knows More Than He Says
description: OUT OF SILENCEA Journey Into Language.By Russell Martin.300 pp. New York:Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

title: Won-Ton Women
description: FRIENDS FOR LIFEBy Meg Wolitzer.213 pp. New York:Crown Publishers. $20.

title: Megabytes Are Important
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable TV: The Big Picture
description: You've read all the stories and heard all the buzzwords about the brave new electronic world out there: interactive cable, video on demand, fiber optics, cable television service over telephone lines, the marriage of video and voice technology.

title:
PROFILE;
Hands-On Philanthropy
description: FOR Robert B. Pamplin Jr., raising money for Lewis & Clark College here once involved doing 26 chin-ups, 116 pushups and 625 situps in 15 minutes and climbing a 16-foot gym rope in 7.9 seconds.

title: Sophomore Shutterbugs Abroad
description: THEY came with their cameras, 20 small black cameras, and at nearly any moment in our three-week tour through central Italy, you could hear the whir of miniature zoom lenses, the muffled clicks of shutters and the buzz of film rewinding. And at the really great spots, in front of the Colosseum, in the tepidarium of the Roman baths at Baia, on the sandy beaches of Sperlonga, I suddenly found myself with all those cameras draped around my neck and piled at my feet. Could you please? Would you mind? Of course, I acquiesced, as I dutifully photographed our group of 20 sophomores 20 times over. This was a January-term trip for students at Colby College in Maine, where my husband teaches art history. I was happy to lend a hand.

title: No Sweat
description: Uptown -- Almost nothing scares Evel Knievel, even now that he has been retired for 14 years from the business of slam-dancing with death.

title: Condemn Singapore's Brutality
description: If people were caned for vandalism in New York, would we have a safer city? That seems to be the conclusion from the talk shows, public opinion surveys and letters to editors across the country. Michael Fay, the 18-year-old American who has been sentenced to a caning in Singapore, is not doing well in the polls. At his hometown paper, The Dayton Daily News in Ohio, the calls and letters are running two-to-one in favor of inflicting this form of torture on a young man who spray painted a car. And the Singapore Government is pointing to American public opinion as vindication for its uncompromising policy. The comparison is made again and again: Singapore and New York. Clean streets vs. dirty ones. Safety vs. muggings. Order vs. chaos.

title: How a Ruling on Abortion Took On a Life of Its Own
description: SUPREME Court Justices can usually time their own departures, as Justice Harry A. Blackmun did with grace and good humor last week. "I know what the numbers are, and it's time," the 85-year-old Justice said in announcing his decision to leave the Court this summer after 24 years.

title: Portugal's Esthetics, Reflected in Old and New Ceramic Tiles
description: IT is fitting that the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, formerly a rest home for seamen, should be the scene of a show about Portugal, the first European power to rule, as it were, the waves.

title:
ART;
The Differences Between Men and Women's Roles
description: "Ancient Worlds: Gender Representation"Hillwood Art Museum, C. W.PostCampus, Brookville. To April 27.

title: The Psychedelic Cure
description: THE OLD, WHITE HOTEL SOUTH OF Amsterdam was the last stop on the junkie express, and most guests packed light. Nicola and Marcel brought only what they needed for the night: two syringes, a pink silk tourniquet, a Robert Ludlum novel and five grams of heroin. It was to be the young couple's last binge as addicts, for the next day they planned to kick drugs forever.

title: A Mirror Of the World
description: A silent auction at Sotheby's benefits the Gay Men's Health Crisis, March 28.

title:
TELEVISION;
Dave Lite: He's Bubbly, And No Bitter Aftertaste
description: MAYBE IT HAS TO DO WITH THE snub, or the wait. But with his new show at CBS making broadcast history, David Letterman, formerly a shy guy with a dark side, is a new Dave, a better Dave, a warm, emotive, yet still more-powerful-than-a-locomotive Dave.

title: Intimate Chamber Settings
description: THERE are many superb concert halls in Westchester, their numbers swelled by school auditoriums, churches and temples. On the other hand, there is nothing quite like the joy of hearing chamber music in the intimate surroundings for which much of it was written, a private home.

title: Discontent Mounts in China, Shaking the Leaders
description: With China's economy still in overdrive, a new surge in inflation, labor unrest and corruption appears to be rattling the Communist Party leadership.

title: McGovern Stays Cool As a Masters Rookie
description: Jim McGovern was skidding. Bogeys on the 10th and 11th holes today dropped him to one under par for the Masters through 47 holes. And now he was confronted with the treacherous 155-yard 12th in the winds above Rae's Creek, regarded by many golfers as the toughest par 3 in tournament golf.

title: The Dog Ate It
description: THERE'S the dog that decided to chew up the electric bill. The family that couldn't return its library books because of the children's busy social schedules. And the man who had no choice but to double-park his car. (He had to go to the bathroom.)

title: Mini Micro Nano
description: WHEN WE THINK MOD- ern we usually think big: big books (Joyce and Proust); big paintings (Picasso and Pollock); big structures (skyscrapers, bridges and dams). But modernism has another, quieter tradition, a shadow theme that in recent years has risen to the fore. It is the seduction of the compact and the compressed, of imagist poetry and Surrealist art, of small incendiary objects like Meret Oppenheim's fur-lined teacup, with its power to send shivers down the museumgoer's spine.

title:
MUSIC;
Paintings Created to Be Part of a Concert
description: RELATIONSHIPS betweenmusic and visual arts have long held a fascination for those involved in the arts. A concert called "Art From Music, Music From Music, and Music From Art" will explore these relationships in a program of Russian music and art, featuring the Central Jersey Symphony Orchestra of Raritan Valley Community College, on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the college.

title: April 3-9: Two Presidents Die; Peace Talks A Casualty of Tribal War In Rwandan Capital
description: Last week a plane crash killing two African presidents touched off bloody clashes between tribal factions in the Rwandan capital of Kigali. Estimates from observers in the capital put the death toll in the thousands.

title: MONSTERS TO BELIEVE IN
description: Dark and forbidding stretch the waters of Loch Ness, the strange lake that cuts deep through the mountains of Scotland. Some 3,000 witnesses have testified to seeing the furtive monster that lives there.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL: NONFICTION
description: MILE HIGH MADNESS A Year With the Colorado Rockies. By Bob Kravitz. Times Books/Random House, $22.

title: The Spreading Blight of Bridgeport's Plywood Stares
description: WHEN he drives the streets of Bridgeport's East Side, Charles Coviello said, he can always tell which of the buildings are owned by banks. They are the ones with the plywood stares.

title: All Eyes Are on 'the Show'
description: Three baseball seasons ago, Manny Ramirez, the pride of Washington Heights, was the best high school player in New York, a first-round pick in the professional draft. Today, with the new big-league season less than a week old, Manny Ramirez, the pride of Washington Heights, is, as they say, "in the show," the starting right fielder of the Cleveland Indians.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the killing of a Wall Street banker and her killer's subsequent suicide mislocated the site where the killer's body was found in some editions. It was on the Brooklyn Heights promenade, not on Columbia Heights.

title: Natchez to Remember Its Jewish History
description: Natchez, Miss., known for its antebellum mansions, will be the setting this spring for a weekend of tours and programs exploring the history of its Jewish community. "The Natchez Jewish Homecoming," sponsored by the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience from April 29 to May 1, traces the community from the first settlers, merchants and traders from Holland and Spain in the 1700's, through the height of Jewish settlement at the turn of the century. In 1906, the congregation at Temple B'nai Israel, a co-sponsor of the weekend, reached 140 families.

title: With Humor and Hardware, A New Generation
description: BURIED in a pile of long-discarded floppy disks were the very first versions of "Reader Rabbit" and "Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego?" A computer-savvy 5-year-old girl ("I'm almost 6!") sniffed in dismissal of the crude graphics and tinny sound quality. "Reader Rabbit" will celebrate its 10th anniversary this summer, and "Carmen" came out in 1985.

title: Foundation's Mission: 'Encouragement of Art'
description: THE Frank and Lydia Bergen Foundation, which is financing the computer composing seminar at Elizabeth High School, was created by Charlotte Bergen of Bernardsville, who died in 1982 at the age of 84.

title: Opera Tickets on Sale For Glyndebourne
description: Mail-order tickets are now on sale for performances at the rebuilt opera house at Glyndebourne, in the rolling hills of the Sussex countryside 54 miles from London, which will open with Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" on May 28. The $50 million building, designed by Michael Hopkins, was shown to the public on Jan. 31.

title: No Talking In Class
description: JOHN BRYAN is in the growing ranks of a relatively silent generation of professors. As an assistant professor of English at the University of Cincinnati, Dr. Bryan lets the computer and its software do most of the talking in his class on science writing.

title: Saudis Strip Citizenship From Backer Of Militants
description: Saudi Arabia has taken a highly unusual step in stripping a scion of one of its wealthiest merchant families of citizenship because he supports Muslim fundamentalist movements active in Arab countries.

title: Robert Massa; Writer and Editor, 36
description: Robert Massa, a writer about AIDS and an editor with The Village Voice, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Mr. Massa, who lived in Manhattan, was 36.

title: Gay Businesses Follow Influx of Gay People
description: On May 1, A Different Light will move from the West Village to 151 West 19th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: Seemingly Endless Quizzes
description: MOST students were nervous, and many had not had much sleep the night before. This was the state final competition of the Academic Decathlon.

title: Deal Brings BAM Artists To El Puente
description: El Puente, the Hispanic organization, has begun a partnership with an arts group that will give performers from the Brooklyn Academy of Music a second stage: a community center in Williamsburg.

title: Interview Jitters at Graduate School
description: SPRINGTIME for teen-agers and young adults awaiting word from colleges they sent applications to months ago is spelled a-n-x-i-e-t-y.

title: Whitewater and the Press
description: There is a kind of tidal rhythm to the attitude of the press -- and the public's attitude toward journalists -- when a political crisis is brewing. First come the revelations. Then follows a period of full media mobilization, with reporters scurrying everywhere. Then arrives the backlash. Officials complain that journalistic obsessions are derailing the nation's business. Politicians assert that the public is weary of incomprehensible details that, after all, give only an incomplete picture of events that would probably be innocuous if the full facts were available.

title: The Nation: The Bias Suits Are Piling Up; The Men in the Gray Federal Bureaucracy
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON promised to make his Administration "look like America." The Cabinet he chose surely does. But the permanent Government -- the top-tier bureaucrats who run the country no matter who is President -- looks more like the United States Senate. Roughly 90 percent of the positions in the Government's top pay grades are held by white men.

title: Moore's Sloppiness Outdoes Key's Finesse
description: Jimmy Key was the picture of precision for five innings yesterday, operating like a human pitching machine. Put a coin in the slot and watch pitches hum around the strike zone. They looked tantalizing until the Tigers flailed and produced out after out. This pitching machine was pretty clever.

title: April 3-9; Recalling Colors Of Innocence
description: Over the years children and their parents have faced a minefield of hazardous toys, flammable pajamas and unsafe cribs. Last week the list included a symbol of childish innocence -- the crayon.

title: MODERN ON THE EDGE
description: MODERN IS NOT WHAT YOU THINK IT IS. IN FACT, IT never was. The flat roofs, steel I-beams and characterless plate-glass windows that shout "modern" in every mall across America are but one facet of a design esthetic that, by definition, is constantly reinventing itself. For modern is not a style. It is an attitude that embraces a dynamic present and uses its innovations to improve everyday life. Now, a new generation of architects and designers is rediscovering its original revolutionary spirit.

title: Sleek Settings
description: MOST MODERN TABLEWARE HAS REFUSED TO GO OUT OF STYLE. AND FOR good reason. The designs are not only strong enough to withstand fickle tastes and trends but, more important, they have yet to wear out their welcome as useful domestic objects. Take Jean Puiforcat's Art Deco coffee and tea services: Some styles have been in continuous production at the Paris-based firm since the 1920's. Anything American from the 50's is so popular you would think everyone was still watching black-and-white television and eating TV dinners. And Finnish products from that same decade -- such as the designer Kaj Franck's unadorned pottery -- have been reintroduced and promoted industriously by the manufacturer. In fact, some items, such as the Viennese architect Josef Hoffmann's silver-plated bowl from 1906, have gone into production for the first time in the last decade.

title:
The View From: Katonah;
Federal Grant for Caramoor Arts Center a Welcome Challenge
description: WHEN representatives of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts seek funds this year, they will be able to provide potential donors with an extra incentive for giving: in March, Caramoor was awarded a $270,000 Challenge Grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Megabytes Are Important
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Goes To College
description: TWO afternoons a week, in the middle of her shift, Deborah Westfall sheds her blue work smock and heads for a pre-calculus class. But the 35-year-old parts inspector at Bailey Controls Company never leaves her Wickliffe, Ohio, workplace.

title: Business Diary: April 3-8
description: THE ECONOMY After a Merely Gray Monday, the Sun Burst Forth on Tuesday After unpleasant inflation signals a week ago, Wall Street was braced for a black Monday, with the President's economic advisers even piping in over the weekend with soothing words on interest rates. But in a day of yo-yo trading, with the Dow industrials down more than 80 points during the session, Monday was merely gray, as the Dow lost 42. Investors were so relieved not to witness the crash of '94 that the next day the Dow shot up 82, the biggest rally in two years. That done, it settled for small rises the next two days, before slipping back on Friday to end the week 38 ahead -- all the while, of course, acting as a faithful mirror to interest rates. The question now: having had a moderate "correction," then an upward correction to that correction, is the market now correct -- or is there still some tidying up to do after that long bull-market party? Hint: Watch interest rates.

title:
DINING OUT;
Food That's as Interesting as the Decor
description: FOR the last 14 years, La Cucina in the Somerset County seat of Somerville has been quietly improving in all areas. What began as a pizza parlor and progressed into a rather ordinary white-tablecloth place finally became an upscale, bilevel restaurant with gilt-framed oil paintings and lights hidden in faux marbre columns.

title: Sitting on Top Of the Tennis World; Sampras Has the Game for All Seasons
description: Pete Sampras, undisputed and currently unchallenged as the world's No. 1 tennis player, was minding his own business recently up in the first-class cabin on a flight between tour stops. Sampras couldn't help but notice the baseball ace Barry Bonds sitting across the aisle, and neither could a horde of autograph hounds who paid the slugger nonstop obeisance until the seat belt signs were illuminated.

title: A Display of Zairian Masks
description: An exhibition of masks created in the Zaire River Basin is scheduled to open April 20 at the National Museum of African Art in Washington.

title: To Get Attention In Albany, Enter The Lobbyists
description: EARLY this month, as budget negotiations in Albany reached a fever pitch and the clamor from a myriad of special-interest groups grew ever louder, Robert E. Biggerstaff, a lobbyist for the New York Association of Small City School Districts, scurried to earn his keep.

title: Virtual Home
description: OVER THE PAST TWO months, I have completed an attic studio, created a new home office, built a two-room vacation cabin and even drafted plans for the first floor of a house. My industriousness might raise eyebrows, considering that I can't draw and don't have an architecture degree. But the big catch is that none of the projects are real -- well, they're virtually real. They are the fruits of a foray into the world of CAD (short for Computer-Aided Design, though to me it sometimes stood for Crazy, Absurd Data). In the process, I have often felt like Alice falling down the tunnel to Wonderland, except that I haven't been following a rabbit, but a mouse.

title: U.S. Assails Crackdown
description: With President Clinton facing the issue of whether to extend China's preferential trade status this year, the White House bluntly warned Beijing today that it was "deeply troubled" by a new crackdown on dissidents. The White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, urged Beijing in a statement to release the dissidents immediately. China has flatly rejected any link between its trade orivileges and its human rights policy.

title: Clothes Made For Designers?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wait for Daycare: Two Years and Counting
description: City officials selected two sites in Fordham to offer affordable daycare to residents two years ago, but residents still have a few more months to wait before the new centers can get started.

title: Of Autism And Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Views on Co-op Sublets and Seller Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstarts In Uniform
description: The military is more alienated from its civilian leadership than at any time in American history -- and more vocal about it.

title: Marilynne Herbert Andrea McDermott, Robert Hyer Jr.
description: Andrea Karen McDermott, a vice president and the legal counsel in the New York office of Bank Brussels Lambert, was married yesterday to Robert Edward Hyer Jr., an investment banker in New York. The Rev. Gerard Steffener performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Madonna, Skin Deep
description: Madonna's body might be the most recognized in the world, but what she flaunts in the limelight is just a glimpse compared with what Delia Bernardino sees. Once a month, she waxes Madonna from head to toe.

title: I.R.A. Mounts More Attacks As Truce Ends
description: The Irish Republican Army resumed its attacks on British security forces early today after its self-imposed, three-day cease-fire expired.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Out of 42, a Mere 6

title: Commercial Property/Downtown Brooklyn; Space Tightening In Discounted Area
description: TRUE or false? No one wants to build new office buildings in New York City. Companies abandoning downtown Manhattan move only to Jersey City, midtown or a faraway state. Downtown Brooklyn is a you-can't-get-there-from-here place.

title: Helping the Wives Of the Unemployed
description: ANGER, depression, guilt: these are just some of the emotions nine women in a support group for wives of the unemployed feel every day. Their husbands are out of work, and nobody understands that spouses suffer too, they say.

title: For Baldessari, de Chirico Is Just One of the Guys
description: THERE IS A CERTAIN TYRANNY to the way museums are arranged according to medium, school and period. The Surrealists famously talked about the chance meeting on an operating table of a sewing machine and an umbrella. You wonder what might have happened, Surrealistically speaking, if one of them had gotten his hands on a museum and shaken it like a snow dome, so that French 18th-century paintings landed with netsukes and photographic archives with Persian carpets.

title: Mark R. Miller and Tonya Yong
description: Tonya Yong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Yong of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, was married last evening to Mark Raymond Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Robert A. Daum performed the ceremony at the Sherman House, a hotel in San Francisco.

title: Amy Rosenberg, John L. Slafsky
description: Amy Jill Rosenberg, an associate producer at NBC News, was married yesterday evening to John Lawrence Slafsky, an associate at Satterlee Stephens Burke & Burke, a law firm. Both work in New York. Rabbi Steven E. Foster officiated at Green Gables Country Club in Denver.

title: Rwanda Update
description: These were the major developments yesterday as fighting continued in RWANDA and foreign troops began to move into the area to help evacuate foreigners from the capital, KIGALI.

title: Whitaker Homecoming Is a Popular Decision
description: Pernell Whitaker scored a unanimous 12-round decision over Santos Cardona tonight before a crowd of 7,868 here at the Scope in his hometown. It was Whitaker's first fight since his hotly debated draw with Julio Cesar Chavez in September.

title: Insuring Vintage Homes
description: A HISTORIC home -- or any home that's more than 100 years old -- presents a special insurance challenge to homeowners hopeful of restoring something close to original conditions after a loss.

title: Next in Robotics: Praise For Connecticut's Own
description: WHERE are the leading centers of innovation in computers and robotics? Silicon Valley? Of course. Route 128 in Massachusetts? Ditto. But robotics experts say Connecticut should be added to the list.

title: The Man Who Swallowed Time Inc.
description: MASTER OF THE GAMESteve Ross and the Creation of Time Warner.By Connie Bruck.Illustrated. 395 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: An Enigmatic Morrissey Still Battles His Demons
description: If TWO WORDS COME CLOSE TO encapsulating Morrissey's sensibility, they are isolation and insularity. The singer once declared: "All those things like love, sex, sharing a life with somebody are actually quite vague. Being only with yourself can be much more intense." He rejects the idea that "no man is an island," finding perverse solace in a self-pity that's really narcissism turned inside out.

title: 'I Came to Save the Union'
description: THE 300 letters in "Upon the Tented Field," edited by Bernard A. Olsen, date from July 31, 1982, through June 10, 1865, two months after the end of the Civil War. They were written by six soldiers of the 14th New Jersey Volunteer Infantry to their families.

title: Political Memo; Clinton Plays the Outsider in Pushing His Health Plan
description: As Bill Clinton travels the country trying to stir up a groundswell of support for his health care plan, it becomes clear that he has settled on a very definite script.

title: The World; Singapore, the Tiger Whose Teeth Are Not Universally Scorned
description: FOR the large American community in Singapore, the laughter about this place has suddenly stopped. There is not much joking these days about Singapore as the city so clean that bubble gum is a controlled substance, so prudish that Cosmopolitan magazine is banned as a threat to common decency, so well planned that a traffic jam is all but unheard of.

title: Richard Kitchen; Home Furnishings Designer, 44
description: Richard Kitchen, a home furnishings designer in Manhattan, died on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 44 years old.

title: HOW DO TOBACCO EXECUTIVES LIVE WITH THEMSELVES?
description: I am a doctor, a former two-pack-a-day smoker who stopped in 1959. I was in charge of a 35-bed ward at the Cincinnati Veterans Hospital. All my patients smoked. In a six-week period, three died of lung cancer and five died of emphysema. I decided (as I smoked while writing the death summaries) that tobacco was not good for me. I was right. It is not good for anyone, and in a truly sane, caring world, those smart, cultured, rich hypocritical people pictured in your article would be out of work and possibly in jail for murder. C. KILGORE, M.D. Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Chamber Music Featured
description: IT'S another busy musical Sunday, with an abundance of solo and chamber concerts from which to choose.

title: Park Battle: For Dogs Or Toddlers?
description: On April 18, work is to begin on the Tudor City Playground, a tiny public park and former drug haven on the steps that lead to Tudor City from the south side of 42d Street. New play equipment and rubber matting for toddlers are on their way, and the sitting area, where no families sat for many years, will be refurbished.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living In/Woodbury;
A Sense of Spaciousness and Seclusion
description: IN the early part of the century, the hamlet of Woodbury, in north-central Nassau County, was known as a country retreat for some of the world's wealthiest people, among them Fords, Mellons and Winthrops. Although the grand estates are gone, most homes are on at least an acre and most residents are fairly well-to-do.

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures of birds on March 6, with the column "In the Natural State" -- about species of sparrows found in New Jersey -- were misidentified. The one at the upper right showed a song sparrow, not a common sparrow. The one at the lower right showed a house sparrow, formerly called an English sparrow. A third picture -- of a dusky seaside sparrow -- was printed in error. The bird, which is extinct, lived only in Florida, not in New Jersey.

title: Hauling as Much, for Much Less Pay
description: Behind the wheel of a groaning diesel rig hauling a 28-foot trailer, Tim Hart backed smoothly into the bay of a shipping warehouse, as deftly as an expert teamster.

title: Praising the Process
description: To the Editor

title: Threshold for Investor Class Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Q & A: Richard Matheson; An Influential Writer Returns to Fantasy
description: THE author Stephen King has said that Richard Matheson is the one author "who influenced me the most as a writer." Such an accolade is humbly received by Mr. Matheson, a native of Allendale, but he adds that influencing people is what good writing is all about.

title: BROOKLYN UPDATE
description: * BRIGHTON BEACH: In one of the longest-running land disputes in Brooklyn, State Supreme Court Justice Lewis Friedman has upheld a developer's rights to build a 15-acre, 1,400-unit condominium project in Brighton Beach.

title: The Lady Vanishes
description: NOW YOU SEE HERBy Whitney Otto.303 pp. New York:Villard Books. $20.

title: Simply Sumptuous
description: FANNIE MERRITT FARMER, WHO transformed recipe writing from the impressionistic descriptions of the 19th century into formulas with precise measurements and scientific instructions, was the mother of modern cooking. Like all mothers, she might well be horrified at how her progeny has evolved.

title: Serbs Take Key Area Above Bosnia Town
description: Nationalist Serbs overran strategic high ground above the eastern town of Gorazde on Friday with tanks, artillery and infantry attacks, United Nations officials said today.

title: Musical Family's Contributions to Society
description: LINDA RODGERS EMORY, a daughter of the composer Richard Rodgers, resembles her father musically and in her features. She, too, is a talented songwriter, and had she been born into a different generation -- one that nurtures the worldly ambitions of girls -- her own life might have taken a different turn.

title: NEW YORKER & CO.
description: New York Magazine Ponders Major Redesign

title: Bottom Line; This Much Is Clear: Taxes Just Aren't What They Seem
description: TENS of millions of Americans will file their income tax returns this week dead certain that their taxes are going up.

title: INSIDE
description: Hardball in the Melting Pot

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HARTFORD'S SYNAGOGUES

title: Threshold for Investor Class Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: April 3-9; At Last, A Chef Who Sees The Light
description: Ever since Thomas Jefferson showed a preference for French cuisine, more Presidents than not have employed French chefs. With its announcement of the appointment of an American chef last week, the White House signaled that haute cuisine is no longer an idee fixe in the President's home.

title: Resurgent Sabatini to Meet Sanchez Vicario in Final
description: From hangdog to hot dog, Gabriela Sabatini has reinvented herself here at the Bausch & Lomb Championships. With a barrage of playmaking that ranged from the instinctive to the incredible, she reached her first final in nearly a year with an assertive 6-2, 6-4 victory against sixth-seeded Lindsay Davenport this afternoon.

title: Scarsdale Painter Returns to His Roots
description: SOME critics have called Christopher Moser a major artist, comparing his work to that of Goya and Francis Bacon and the masters of the Renaissance. He has exhibited his paintings -- which combine elements of Classical composition with Expressionism -- throughout the United States and has traveled worldwide.

title: Why John Dewey Doesn't Work
description: THE PROMISE OF PRAGMATISM Modernism and the Crisis of Knowledge and Authority. By John Patrick Diggins. 515 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.

title: Laurie C. Nash, Mark Dursztman
description: Dr. Laurie Claire Nash, a daughter of Drs. Warner and Artemis Nash of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Mark Dursztman, the son of Joseph and Regina Dursztman of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: April 3-9: Judge Blocks Pentagon; 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' Gets a 'Don't Think So'
description: After the Clinton Administration struck a grudging compromise with Congress last year to allow homosexuals in the military so long as they kept their sexual orientation private, attention shifted to the courts and the legal challenges.

title: Now You Don't See It. Now
description: "Magic Eye" books by Tom Baccei -- best-sellers in Europe and Japan -- have computer-generated pictures that contain hidden 3-D images. (In this country, a second one is just out.) To find the image you hold the page close to your eyes and very slowly move it away while trying to keep your gaze unfocused. The hidden image may pop out after only two or three tries. Or it may take longer. "Don't worry," Baccei says. "It took my Dad six weeks to get it." (Above: look for a big butterfly.)

title: Where's The Harm?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Sunday; Cutting Chains That Still Bind Girls in School
description: THE way Angie Perez sees it, the best answer sometimes is silence. The Central Park East Secondary School freshman is quiet in some classes because the boys mock her wrong answers or call her a nerd for giving the right answers. At 14, she has teased out the gender calculus in which girls get points for pleasing boys and boys get points for being in charge.

title: Nasdaq Wants To Blackball Some Stocks
description: THE over-the-counter market for stocks was, only a few decades ago, widely viewed as a fairly seedy place where very dubious stocks were traded along with a few respectable but obscure ones. A company that wanted credibility fled from that market as soon as it could.

title: Views on Co-op Sublets and Seller Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheri Gouveia, Nicholas Marchi
description: Sheri Susan Gouveia, the daughter of George and Susan Gouveia of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Charles Marchi, the son of Nicholas and Carole Marchi of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Rayner W. Hesse Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison.

title: Wall Street; When Brokerage Chiefs Bail Out
description: IF it's true that it pays to hang on to stocks for the long haul, then why have brokerage-firm big shots been bailing out?

title: Don Simonelli; Clothing Designer, 56
description: Don Simonelli, a designer of women's clothing who also operated a catering business at one time, died on Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Simonelli, who lived in Manhattan and South Salem, N.Y., was 56.

title: Saberhagen Completes 5-Hitter and Suspension
description: Bret Saberhagen sat for seven days and waited for this moment. He sat on a rooftop on Sheffield Avenue in Chicago and watched the Mets open the season against the Cubs at Wrigley Field. He sat in the clubhouse for two days and laughed at his teammates when they sneaked into the locker room to warm their frozen hands. He went shopping on Michigan Avenue and organized a Masters' pool for the golf-loving members of the club.

title:
FILM;
Watched Sexpots Still Simmer
description: FOR Kathleen Turner, every encounter with the press is a performance, complete with transcontinental accents, prepackaged line readings and gestures that would have made Tallulah Bankhead proud. Today, in the dimly-lit bar of Cafe des Artistes, she seems to be impersonating a Venezuelan heiress, in New York on a shopping spree.

title: Disgusted Jordan Tosses Bat
description: Michael Jordan went hitless again tonight, in four at-bats, in this his second professional baseball game. In Hoover Metropolitan Stadium, the 31-year-old rookie right fielder and former all-universe basketball hero struck out three times and hit a soft grounder to shortstop in which the throw beat him by a step. In two games with the Birmingham Barons, Class AA affiliates of the White Sox, Jordan, in facing Chattanooga pitching, is 0 for 7.

title: Long Island Q&A: David G. Amaral; What Makes Memory Tick
description: THE ability to remember the words one is reading or other common daily events depends on the part of the brain called the hippocampus. It is literally the place that memories are made.

title: No Sex Is Good Sex
description: WOMEN, PASSION & CELIBACYBy Sally Cline.280 pp. New York:Carol Southern Books.

title: Knicks and Nets Turn the Page to Chapter 5
description: It could be the final chapter of the Knicks-Nets rivalry this season. Or they could meet again in a first-round playoff series.

title: Enter Spring, Dressed Vividly in Yellow
description: WHAT is it about the color yellow for spring? The bright sunny blossoms in various tones of gold seem to have a priority on the season. There are other flowers, of course, in all kinds of colors. But those with yellow petals dominate.

title: Tribe's Tribute
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Liza C. Verreault, Gregory G. Reiss
description: Liza Christine Verreault, a daughter of Rolland and Sylvia Verreault of Montreal, was married there yesterday to Gregory George Reiss, a son of Paul and Rosemary Reiss of Colchester, Vt. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien officiated at Mary Queen of the World Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Haiti Policy Brings Blast At Clinton
description: Two human rights groups assailed the Clinton Administration today, accusing the President of failing to support Haiti's ousted President fully and of embracing "a murderous armed force."

title: Of Autism And Critics
description: To the Editor:

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Leo L. Kornfeld;
Broadening the Student Loan Program
description: THE Federal Government already gives out about 3.5 million guaranteed student loans a year. Leo L. Kornfeld of Rye is overseeing changes in the program aimed at making the loans available to every college student in the country, but at less cost to the Government.

title: As Bad as Things Were, The Emptiness Is Worse
description: The third spring of the war has arrived in Sarajevo and a deadly quiet has overtaken the city. In the uncanny silence, as we walk those streets that had been marked earlier as places you could easily die from a sniper's bullet, the question arises in all its utter absurdity: Where the hell is our future -- if there is a future?

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN CHELSEA $230,000 161 West 15th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. co-op in a loft building; 12-ft.-ceilings, exposed-brick walls, live-in superintendent; maintenance $770, 65% tax deductible, listed at $249,000, 10 weeks on market (Broker: Delson-Ginsberg Real Estate)

title: Journal; Whitewater Drained
description: My Whitewater dependency was every bit as out of control as the next guy's, but about 10 days ago I slipped into remission. Suddenly it was hard to hyperventilate about the story that only recently had tempted me to master cattle futures (to no avail, since I have no broker named "Red" to save me from bum steers).

title:
HORSE RACING;
Far From Crowd, Lukas Is On Track to Recover
description: Most of the crowd at today's Santa Anita Derby came to see California's top contenders for next month's Kentucky Derby. Jeff Lukas wanted to see and root for the colt that nearly killed him.

title: The Nation; Inside Academia: Krazy Kat Meets the Lit Krits
description: In its 31-year run from 1913 to 1944, George Herriman's cartoon "Krazy Kat" may not have attracted the mass following of "Li'l Abner," "Gasoline Alley" or the "Katzenjammer Kids." But in its influence on the arts it has been second to none. Krazy Kat was the subject of a 1922 jazz ballet by John Alden Carpenter and a 1988 novel by Jay Kantor. Willem de Kooning and Jack Kerouac were both Krazy Kat fans. Critics have enthused over the cartoon strip's playful, "Joycean" language, Beckett-like dialogue, and the bleak, surreal setting of Herriman's Coconino County, an existentialist's dreamland where mesas can suddenly turn into mushrooms and day abruptly into night. It is never even clear whether Krazy is male or female.

title: 'The World Is One Vast Madhouse'
description: MESHUGAH By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Translated by the author and Nili Wachtel. 232 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.

title: Small Utilities Luring Away Customers
description: THE Butler Power and Light Company serves only a two-square-mile area with slightly more than 10,000 customers, but its officials swell with pride when recalling how it withstood the same tests that severely strained the largest utilities in the state.

title: A Storefront Exhibition Meant to Nurture the Nontraditional
description: ALTERNATIVE spaces directed by professionals appeared in the early 1970's, their purpose being to accommodate artists without gallery affiliations. Today, the overflow seems bigger than ever but these seedbeds of talent (or hotbeds of dissidents, depending on your view) have not increased in number.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about reaction to the resignation threat of the New York City Schools Chancellor misspelled the first name of the leader of a parent's group in some editions and named the organization incompletely. He is Jon Moscow; the group is the Parents Coalition for Education.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on March 20 about new projects at Newark International Airport reversed two sets of construction costs -- for the international terminal and for the monorail system. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is spending $110 million on the terminal and $378 million on the monorail.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL: FICTION
description: THE ELEMENTS OF HITTING By Matthew F. Jones. Hyperion, $22.95.

title: The Return of the Red Ribbon
description: In the history of the AIDS epidemic in New York, the Armory Ribbon Bee Project was only a poignant footnote. For Jackie McLean and the others at the Park Avenue Shelter, it was something of a life saver.

title: Curing Sick Stereotypes
description: A CHILD falls down a flight of stairs, and is immediately rushed to the hospital emergency room by his or her parents.

title: A Rail-and-Drive Pass For Eastern Europe
description: A new rail-and-drive pass for travel in central and eastern Europe has been introduced by Rail Europe, the North American distributor of Eurailpass and other European train packages. The packages offer visitors the opportunity to travel long distances via train and then use the car for shorter jaunts.

title: Tubbs Resigns And Joins T.C.U.
description: Billy Tubbs, Oklahoma's winningest basketball coach, left today after 14 seasons to take over the struggling Texas Christian program.

title: Fast Forward
description: Just when you finally figure out how to operate the VCR, the industry steps in and pulls a fast one. What's next? Movies on compact disks.

title: The Numbers
description: It may be wrapped in 160,000 square feet of tent fabric, but Bryant Park is not the site of the latest installation by Christo.
