Based on past experience, they figured about 2,000 kids would show up.

title: Commerce Bancorp Inc. (N.J.) (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books of The Times; Stiff Upper Lip Turns Into a Grimace
description: The Birthday Boys By Beryl Bainbridge 189 pages. Carroll & Graf. $18.95.

title: Women's Game Has Low Costs, No Checks
description: It is an upscale activity for college women, no cousin of mud wrestling and nothing like a slam-bang National Hockey League contest. Women's hockey has arrived.

title: Yale Hires Beckett
description: TOM BECKETT was appointed yesterday to a five-year term as Yale's director of athletics. Beckett, 47, will succeed ED WOODSUM, who resigned after serving six years and plans to practice law in Portland, Me.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES P.L.C., London, said it had bought Decatrend Paints, a California-based unit of Total Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, Paris, for an undisclosed sum. I.C.H. CORP., Louisville, Ky., will ask shareholders this spring to change its name to Southwestern Life Corp.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rwandan Rebels Reported Closing In on Capital
description: Rebel soldiers closed in on Rwanda's capital today, and French and Belgian military units raced to complete the evacuation of their nationals still inside the embattled central African country.

title: Ninth Whaler Arrested
description: BRYAN MARCHMENT, a defenseman with the Hartford Whalers, was arrested on a drunken driving charge on his way home from a charity event, a team official said on Sunday. He is the ninth member of the Whalers to be arrested on alcohol-related charges in the last three weeks.

title: Jersey City Scrap Metal Dealer Held in Garbage Truck Thefts
description: In New York City, it has been said, they'll steal anything.

title: Critic's Notebook; Two Playwrights Take On Film As (a) Dangerous; (b) Liberating
description: The American theater has never had a party line on how to deal with its richer, younger cousin, the movies. But at least since the advent of sound in cinema, when the talent drain from Broadway to Los Angeles really started to flow, it has felt compelled to address the subject.

title: Market Place; The choices are few for investing in software aimed at children.
description: SOFTWARE and hardware companies alike are going full bore after the home and family computing market, but there are precious few choices for investors who want to do the same.

title: American Freightways Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
At Masters, a Wacky Course of Events
description: When golfers in the 58th Masters arrived at the fourth tee Friday during the second round, some of them thought they were hallucinating. There in front of them, 205 yards away on the fourth green, was a pin position that looked like something out of a roadside goony golf club.

title: Viacom Said to Weigh Sales of Teams
description: Viacom Inc. is considering the sale of Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks and Rangers sports teams, a person with knowledge of Viacom said yesterday. But he added that no decision had been made.

title: Polishing Ferrari's Image
description: Ferrari North America has selected Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York to handle its account, previously at Hank Forssberg Inc. in Hackensack, N.J. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Kissinger Will Help Mediate Dispute Over Zulu Homeland
description: After 17 years on the diplomatic sidelines, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has agreed, along with Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary, to help mediate the fierce dispute in South Africa between the African National Congress and Zulus who want an autonomous homeland.

title: Q&A
description: Cat Allergy

title: Official Quits At Warner Unit
description: Michael Jay Solomon said today that he had resigned as Warner Brothers' president of international television to form his own international telecommunications company, after a five-year tenure at Warner Brothers.

title: H & R Block
description: The share price of H & R Block, the tax preparer, has languished recently despite a busy tax-filing season. It reported a large loss for the third quarter ended Jan. 31, mainly from sluggish revenue in its tax preparation business, but it saw strong earnings from its electronic filing division. Yesterday, it closed up 50 cents, to $44.625, in light trading.

title: Chess
description: Gary Kasparov was not in his best form in the elite Linares International Tournament in Spain, which ended on March 14. He seemed to have unaccustomed difficulty preventing lesser players from drawing with him and he had to struggle to win against players who would normally have gone down without much of a fight. Yet it was still a formidable task for anyone to beat him.

title: Matthew Feldman, 75, Mayor Of Teaneck and State Senator
description: Matthew Feldman, a New Jersey Democratic legislative leader who served as Mayor of Teaneck and then for 22 years in the State Senate, died yesterday in Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 75.

title: Lawrence Anderson; Architect and Dean At M.I.T. Was 87
description: Prof. Lawrence B. Anderson, an architect and former dean of the School of Architecture and Planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on Wednesday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. He was 87 and lived in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Phils' Kruk Makes Triumphant Return
description: Forget his three hits, and, for that matter, the Phillies' loss to the Colorado Rockies. John Kruk was the hero of yesterday's home opener in Philadelphia just by showing up.

title: Bracing for New Data, Stocks Quietly Rise
description: The stock market rallied slightly in modest trading yesterday as the bond market was encouraged by signs that rises in commodity prices, and therefore inflation, were subsiding.

title: Hillary Clinton Didn't Report $6,498 Profit In Commodities Account, White House Says
description: The White House said today that Hillary Rodham Clinton made $6,498 in a commodities-trading venture in 1980 and never reported the profit to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Yankees Wonder What Spells Relief
description: Xavier Hernandez shook his head the other day, playfully acted worried before any questions were even uttered and then laughingly told a reporter to proceed with the interrogation. A few days into the season, he already knew the routine. He knew the probing would concern the Yankee bullpen. What Hernandez and no other relievers know is when, if ever, those questions will cease.

title: French Leader's Trip To China Criticized
description: Returning home from a four-day trip to China to seek business opportunities for French companies, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur came under strong attack here today for not speaking out against China's human rights record.

title: CIT Group Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: CIT Group Holdings said that in the first quarter, it completed the purchase of Barclays Commercial Corp. The company said that the purchase added more than $ 700 million in finance receivables.CIT Group reported $ 7.6 million in gains on asset sales in the latest first quarter, including a gain from securitizing $ 150 million of recreational vehicle receivables. Gains from asset sales totaled $ 1.3 million in the year-ago first quarter.CIT Group Holdings is 60 percent owned by Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and 40 percent owned by Chemical Banking Corp.

title: Benefit Funds May Run Out Of Cash Soon, Reports Warn
description: If Congress takes no action, the Clinton Administration said today, the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly will run out of money in seven years and a separate trust fund that pays benefits to disabled workers will be exhausted next year.

title: The Strange Dark World of the Naked Mole Rat
description: IN complex burrows under the bricklike soil of East African deserts there lives a mammal more peculiar perhaps than any other on earth. More peculiar, in fact, than the creatures that have emerged from the wild imaginings of Maurice Sendak or the conjurers of otherworldly visitors.

title: A Similar Case in 1976: Mr. Fit
description: LAST month's revelation of falsification of data in breast cancer studies, through an article in The Chicago Tribune, reminded some of a similar revelation about a heart disease study almost two decades ago.

title: Premier Bancorp Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 43,921,000, or $ 1.58 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Gooden Tosses, Bonilla Sits
description: Dwight Gooden threw on the side and Bobby Bonilla sat in uniform on the bench. But the Mets were without the services of their top two marquee players for yesterday's home opener against the Cubs.

title: Accounts
description: * Gold's Gym, Venice, Calif., to Fattal & Collins, Marina del Rey, Calif., to handle its account, previously in-house. Billings were estimated at $9 million. * Janovic Plaza, New York, to AC& R Advertising and its Cason Wenman Nightingale unit, both New York, to handle the home decorating retailer's account, previously in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Bear, Stearns Hires Former Fed Governor
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, said yesterday that it was appointing Wayne D. Angell, a former Federal Reserve governor and inflation hawk, as its chief economist.

title: Pharmacists Create Plan To Compete
description: Seeking a share of a business dominated by pharmaceutical giants, chain and independent pharmacists have created a company to compete for prescription drug programs offered by corporate health care plans.

title: Review/Theater; Making Conversation in the Abstract
description: On a bare stage at the Kampo Cultural Center, eight people take their places on chairs arranged in a semicircle. They could be choral singers or members of a therapy group. But no, they are the actors in Edward Albee's newest work, "Fragments." They begin by exchanging proverbs, move on to more extended stories and reflections, then finish off the evening by going back to the proverbs.

title: Allow Nanny Employers More for Child Care; Lessening the Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Algerian Leader's Efforts Merit Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Mercantile Bankshares (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Figures adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a stock dividend in September 1993.

title: SHL Systemhouse (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Necessary Air Strikes in Bosnia
description: The Clinton Administration has been rightly cautious about approving any direct American military involvement in the war in Bosnia. But the dispatch of U.S. planes for NATO air strikes against Serbian tanks and command positions around Gorazde Sunday and again yesterday seems a risk emphatically worth taking. Serbian military pressure against the mostly Muslim city threatens to unravel the most promising international effort yet to end this murderous conflict.

title: Woolworth Is Paying Down Its Commercial Paper
description: The Woolworth Corporation is paying down its commercial paper lines from its bank loans because it may no longer be able to sell short-term debt at reasonable interest rates, industry and credit analysts said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Thomson at Bat
description: BOBBY THOMSON will be the master of ceremonies at Carnegie Hall in Manhattan on Friday night for a program titled "Baseball Blues."

title: Fleet, Bank Of New York Said to Talk
description: The Bank of New York Company and Fleet Financial Group Inc. have held discussions within the last month about a possible merger, an investment banker familiar with the talks says.

title: SOCCER
description: African Nations Cup

title: Russia Faults NATO Step
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin complained bitterly today that Moscow had not been consulted in advance on Sunday as NATO bombers prepared the first air strikes against Bosnian Serb positions near the besieged town of Gorazde.

title: Ex-East German Agent Guilty in Terror Bombing
description: A former officer in the East German secret police was sentenced today to four years in prison for his role in the fatal 1983 bombing of a French cultural center in West Berlin.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 NATO HITS SERBS AGAIN NATO conducted its second air strike against the Bosnian Serbs in two days after they failed to stop shelling the town of Gorazde, and the attacks finally stopped. A1 RESTRAINT IN BOSNIA ATTACKS The United States portrayed the bombing of Serb positions in Bosnia as a demonstration of its resolve to stop their attacks, but the NATO military operation was actually modest and restrained. A10 News analysis: The West is hoping that the Serbs bow to force. A10 SOUTH AFRICA, IN THE HUSTINGS South Africa has undertaken a vigorous voter education campaign leading up to its first all-race election, appealing to people's sense of historic duty and opportunity. A1 Troops have not halted Zulu violence in South Africa. A8 Henry Kissinger will help mediate in South Africa. A8 WILDLIFE TRADE PUNISHED The Clinton Administration said it was imposing trade sanctions on Taiwan for refusing to halt the sale of tiger and rhinoceros parts. D1 RWANDA REFUGEES LOOK BACK Westerners evacuated from Rwanda, many of them church workers, spoke with anguish of the fate of friends they had left behind and looked to the day when they would be able to return. A6 RWANDA REBELS CLOSE IN Rebels were closing in on the capital of Rwanda as Western nations struggled to complete the evacuation of their nationals. Reports said fighting continued both inside and outside the capital, Kigali. A6 The deadline for Palestinian self-rule will change. A7 Citing violence, the Pope has canceled a Lebanon visit. A7 NO SHOO-IN FOR MEXICO While the ruling party's presidential candidate is expected to win in Mexico, voter dissatisfaction and party infighting are expected to make the race a difficult challenge. A3 A former East German official was sentenced in a bombing. A11 A suicide was troubling for France's President. A11 Hanoi Journal: Fiction with a dissident's sting. A4 National A12-15 BLEAK VIEW OF CHILDREN A wide-ranging three-year study found a bleak picture for millions of American children: disintegrating families, poverty, child abuse and poor health care threatening their chances of growing to become whole adults. A1 CORPORATE-PAID THERAPY To curb costs of treating workers for mental illness and substance abuse, companies are measuring treatment in a way that cuts expenses but also tries to apply a precision to psychotherapy that worries therapists. A1 FREEWAY SUCCESS STORY The Santa Monica Freeway, a vital artery Southern California's road system, is reopening two months earlier than officials expected after repairs of its severe earthquake damage. A12 MEDICARE FUNDS IN PERIL The Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly will run out of money in seven years and a separate trust fund that pays benefits to disabled workers will be exhausted next year if Congress does not act. A12 INQUIRY IN AIR FORCE CRASH An especially volatile type of jet fuel is being investigated as a possible contributing factor to the high death toll in a crash at Pope Air Force Base last month. A13 RON BROWN IN ACTION Washington at Work: Commerce Secretary Ronald Brown was temporarily detoured from the Washington fast track, but now he is back, and doings things Democrats could scarcely have imagined: building alliances with business. A14 SELLING THE CRIME BILL President Clinton urged local and state law officers at a Justice Department rally to put pressure on members of Congress to pass anticrime legislation. A14 A CLINTON CORRECTION The White House said a 1980 profit of $6,498 for Hillary Rodham Clinton in commodities trades was not reported to the I.R.S., and the Clintons have paid more that $14,000 in back Federal and state taxes. A15 A trucking company closed, leaving striking Teamsters jobless. A12 Accusations of forged signatures in radiation experiments. A15 Metro Digest B1 SIDE EFFECTS OF MAYOR'S VICTORY Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani emerged from his weekend confrontation with the Schools Chancellor largely with what he wanted: a mayoral appointee to look into school finances. But his confrontational style may have used up some of the good will he needs for his long-term agenda. A1 WELFARE LURE SHIFTS The view of New York City as a place attracting waves of poor people with relatively generous welfare benefits, if ever true, exists no more, fresh census findings reveal. Instead, in the late 1980's, New York City appears to have become a net exporter of welfare families. A1 Obituaries B10 Dr. Jerome Lejeune, geneticist. Matthew Feldman, New Jersey Democratic legislative leader. Science Times C1-14 The secret underground world of the naked mole rat. C1 Hopes of restoring full weather satellite coverage. C1 A cancer researcher won't explain data problems to Congress. C1 Putting a dollar value on urban trees. C4 Cells' 'everlasting life' chemical opens way to attack cancer. C10 Broccoli is good for you, just as your mother said. C11 Peripherals C9 Q&A C11 Personal Computers C14 Fashion Pages B8-9 Fashion reviews: Calvin Klein. B8 Michael Kors and Betsey Johnson. B8 Geoffrey Beene, Carolina Herrera, Mary McFadden. B9 Business Digest D1 Arts/Entertainment C15-24 Eastern Europe loses art to thieves for the West. C15 A battle over "Showboat." C15 Theater: Film as subject. C15 "Fragments" by Albee. C16 Music: Classical reviews. C16 Dance: Miami City Ballet. C19 Small 'Romeo and Juliet.' C19 Books: "The Birthday Boys," by Beryl Bainbridge. C24 Television: "AIDS Research: The Story So Far." C24 A life of Sid Caesar. C24 Sports B11-17 Baseball: Mets revert to '93 form in home opener. B11 Kruk comes back from cancer. B12 Yanks bullpen still unsettled. B14 Columns: Vecsey on Mets. B11 TV Sports. B13 On Baseball. B13 Basketball: Knicks lose fourth game in last five. B11 Hockey: It's for women, too. B15 Sports People B14 Editorials/Op-Ed A16-17 Editorials Necessary air strikes in Bosnia. A cease-fire on schools. The Jordan effect. Letters Russell Baker: Been away too long. A. M. Rosenthal: Clinton in wartime. Robert I. Friedman: 25,000 saboteurs of peace. Brandon del Pozo: Everybody's corps. Chronicle B2 Chess C6 Crossword C16

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Young Polish Virtuosos The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts Lincoln Center

title: New Weather Satellite To Boost Ailing Fleet With Better Imagery
description: The nation's teetering system of weather satellites, for years held together by luck and borrowed equipment, hopes to receive new vitality on Wednesday with the launching of the most advanced weather sentinel ever placed above Earth.

title: Battle of the Big-Time Musicals: A Lively Overture
description: Half a year before their scheduled arrival on Broadway, next fall's two big musicals are already elbowing each other for attention. Last month, "Sunset Boulevard," the $12 million Andrew Lloyd Webber extravaganza, which isn't to open until Nov. 17, began a blitz of radio and newspaper ads. The radio spots featured the show's star, Glenn Close, saying, "And now, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up."

title: Allow Nanny Employers More for Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY BID FOR VALLEY BANCORP APPROVED
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday approved the Marshall & Ilsley Corporation's acquisition of Valley Bancorp Inc. of Appleton, Wis., in a $875 million stock swap that will create the largest banking company in Wisconsin. The vote was 5 to 0. Under the tax-free transaction, each share of Valley Bancorp will be exchanged for 1.72 shares of Marshall & Ilsley. The stock swap values each Valley Bancorp share at $34.83 a share. Marshall & Ilsley's stock was unchanged yesterday at $21 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Review/Dance; An Experiment in Scale With 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: There are only 21 dancers' names listed on the roster of Indianapolis Ballet Theater. Nevertheless, on Sunday afternoon at Queensborough Community College in Bayside, the troupe presented a convincing and often touching version of Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet," a work usually associated with large casts.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League SEATTLE MARINERS -- Placed Mackey Sasser, catcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Darren Bragg, outfielder, from Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. Designated Chris Howard, catcher, for assignment.

title: Fred Reinglas, Stage Manager, 58
description: Fred Reinglas, a stage manager for Broadway and Off Broadway shows for the last 30 years, died on March 31 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Deregulating Higher Education; Colleges Hail an Agency's Demise
description: Frank P. Merlo, a college education professor, sent a list of 20 money-saving ideas to Gov. Jim Florio in 1991, and nothing happened. Three years later Mr. Merlo sent the same list to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. The next thing he knew the Governor was taking one of his suggestions and abolishing the State Department of Higher Education. Her aides even called to ask if they could use his name in announcing the plan.

title: Israelis Set New Deadline With P.L.O.
description: Palestinian officials conceded today that Wednesday's deadline for an Israeli withdrawal from Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho could not be met, but accepted a proposal by Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, to set a new target date for the end of the month.

title: NATO's Balkan Gamble: Using Force Is the Best Way of Achieving Peace
description: In twice bombing Serbian positions around the Muslim enclave of Gorazde, the United States and its Western allies have wagered that force will bring the Serbs back to the negotiating table because force is the one thing Serbian soldiers in Bosnia understand.

title: 3M Will Pay $325 Million To Settle Implant Suits
description: The Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Company announced today that it had agreed to contribute $325 million to a fund to compensate women who received silicone breast implants.

title: Enzyme May Offer Target In Tumors
description: THROUGHOUT fiction and mythology, seekers of eternal youth pay a heavy price for finding it, as life refuses to be anything but finite. Cells that aspire to immortality face a desperate end as well: they become cancerous, replicating without ceasing until they kill their host.

title: INSIDE
description: Mrs. Clinton's Profit

title: Now You Can Dump Your Wallet Into a Database
description: AT the end of a full week, which included a trip to the thriving Silicon Valley metropolis of Milpitas, Calif., you have collected a stack of business cards. All those valuable names, addresses, phone and fax numbers, with comments, must be entered into a database or contact manager.

title: By Design; The Empire of the 90's
description: The fall shows are almost over, and the major trends are clear. Among them: the high-waisted dress, shown by designers as diverse as Bradley Bayou and Bill Blass. Happily, the Empire waist was also a trend for spring, so there are already lots of choices in the stores, for day and evening.

title: Review/Television; What Is Being Done About AIDS
description: As AIDS threatens tens of millions of people around the world, the pressure on researchers to come up with a vaccine like the ones that did away with polio and smallpox becomes ever more urgent. But as "AIDS Research: The Story So Far" cautions, hopes are not high, because, in one scientist's words, "This virus is not like anything we've seen before."

title: For a Hot Mutual Fund, Hard Issues
description: Thomas H. Bailey, the iconoclastic founder and chairman of the Janus Capital Corporation, a hot stock-picking mutual fund boutique, leads an enviable life. Three days a week, he works out of his Aspen office, right near the ski slopes. As the stock market began its nail-biting slide just before Easter, Mr. Bailey, a trim 56-year-old, was out-of-pocket on a sailboat in the Caribbean. Oh yes, and last year, he took home more than $9 million in salary and dividends.

title: Crackdown by Pretoria Barely Felt in Zulu Area
description: Almost two weeks after the South African Government sent troops to the Zulu heartland to stem factional violence and protect voters in the country's first nonracial elections, an increasingly insecure populace here views the crackdown has having done little.

title: Sports Playoffs Oust Circus
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus performances at Madison Square Garden scheduled for April 17 at 1 and 5:50 P.M. and May 1 at 10:30 A.M., 2 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. have been canceled because of the first-round playoff games of the New York Rangers and the New York Knicks. Tickets purchased at the Garden may be exchanged or refunded at the box office; tickets purchased at Ticketmaster remote outlets may be exchanged or refunded at the Garden box office or at the point of purchase; tickets charged by phone may be exchanged or refunded at the Garden box office or by calling Ticketmaster at (212) 307-7171; tickets purchased through Group Sales should be exchanged or refunded through Group Sales, (212) 465-6080.

title: Spectrum Suit Cites Family
description: The son and daughter of the president of Spectrum Information Technologies Inc. have been accused of illegal insider trading in a newly amended shareholder suit.

title: U.S. Puts Sanctions On Taiwan
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it was imposing trade sanctions on Taiwan for refusing to halt the sale of tiger bones and rhinoceros horns, the first time that Washington has deployed trade sanctions to protect the environment.

title: New York City Drawing Fewer In Need of Aid
description: In the late 1980's, according to fresh census findings, the flow of welfare applicants into New York City all but dried up. In stark contrast to the experience of a decade earlier, New York City appears to have become a net exporter of welfare families.

title: Through the Snow
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Welcoming the World

title: New Bosnia Debate: How Much Force?
description: The Clinton Administration tried today to portray NATO's two days of air strikes as a demonstration of its resolve to halt a Serbian offensive in eastern Bosnia. But the Pentagon described an extremely modest military operation that appeared to have been designed as much to avoid angering the Serbs as to stop their attacks on the besieged Muslim enclave of Gorazde.

title: Supervalu Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 26
description: Supervalu's equity in the earnings of Shopko Stores was $ 4,705,000 in the latest fourth quarter, down from $ 8,042,000 in year-ago period. For the latest full year, the company's equity in the earnings amounted to $ 14,789,000, compared with $ 23,072,000 in previous year.The results for the latest year included the acquisitions of Wetterau Properties Inc. and Sweet Life Foods Inc.

title: Inquiry Asks if Continued Use of a Fuel Worsened Toll in Fiery Air Base Crash
description: The Air Force is investigating whether its continued use of a particularly volatile jet fuel, long ago abandoned by the Navy and commercial airlines, may have increased the death toll in the plane crash and explosion that killed 23 soldiers at Pope Air Force Base last month.

title: Cal's Murray Joins Kidd On the Path to the Pros
description: LAMOND MURRAY, who became California's career leading scorer in three seasons at the school, announced yesterday that he would pass up his final year and enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Review/Fashion; From the Masterly Beene, Surprises
description: Clothes should look beautiful and move gracefully. By paying attention to these basic tenets, Geoffrey Beene secured his position as this country's most respected designer. He also won thunderous applause, shouts of "Bravo!" and a standing ovation yesterday morning, when he introduced his fall collection in the theater of the Equitable Building.

title: Risks Rise in North Sea as Price of Oil Declines
description: For oil companies, the North Sea has become a harsh climate in more ways than one.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEWCOMERS ON WELFARE DOWN SHARPLY

title: Last Train Shooting Victim Leaves Hospital
description: When Kevin McCarthy arrived at North Shore University Hospital on Dec. 7, one of the more than two dozen victims of a gunman on a Long Island Rail Road train, there did not seem much to hope for. The bullet that struck the 26-year-old broker passed through his right hand and into his right temple, shattering his skull and leading doctors to estimate his chances of survival about 1 in 10.

title: Chip Ratio Stays Steady
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association's closely watched book-to-bill ratio for March was 1.13, unchanged from the revised number for February. The February book-to-bill was revised downward from 1.15.

title: Brendle's Inc. reports earnings for Year to Jan 29
description: The latest year included restructuring costs of $ 16,090,000, compared with restructuring costs of $ 4,572,000 in previous year.(Loss)

title: Malakhov Remains Man of Mystery
description: Game to game, period to period, shift to shift, the Islanders never know exactly what they will get from Vladimir Malakhov, their second-year defenseman from Russia.

title: President Urges Law Officers To Press for an Anticrime Bill
description: Hoping to rob the Republicans of an election-year issue, President Clinton urged Congress today to act swiftly to pass an anticrime bill.

title: Everybody's Corps
description: On Friday, Dartmouth College's trustees will meet to decide the fate of the school's Army Reserve Officers Training Corps. The faculty has voted to cancel the program, and the school's president, James O. Freedman, has echoed the sentiment.

title: Bridge Column
description: The Bridge column now appears on Mondays, Thursdays and Saturdays. The location is shown at the bottom of the News Summary on page 2 of the first section.

title: The Regular Season Can't End Soon Enough
description: The Knicks closed last night, but couldn't finish. The lost their fourth game of their last five. They failed, again, to clinch the Atlantic Division. Atlanta and Chicago are back, really back, in the Eastern Conference home-court playoff race. Another Knick crisis is upon us, and to explain why, we bring you the following multiple choice:

title: Treasury Prices Mixed Ahead of Inflation Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in moderate trading, as investors awaited new inflation data today and tomorrow.

title: Now Pitching: No. 99
description: WAYNE GRETZKY wanted to play baseball more than hockey when he was growing up.

title: Washington at Work; Ron Brown Re-emerges in Halls of Power, and Thrives
description: During a breakfast meeting at which the Secretary of Commerce was communing with his senior staff last week, the topic drifted from Russia to Japan to China and then hovered, briefly, over his recent visit to the great state of Iowa.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 23 million in the quarter and $ 28.3 million in the 9 months from minority interest in partnership with Freeport-McMoRan Resource Partners L.P. The quarter also included tax provision which included charge of $ 5 million, or 20 cents a share, to reflect reduction of tax benefit recorded in first half.Latest year also included charges of $ 4.1 million for adjustment to net deferred tax liability and $ 20.3 million, or 51 cents a share, or $ 12.4 million after-tax, from write-down of investment in oil and gas partnership, and gain of $ 8.1 million for resolution of contract dispute with a major uranium oxide customer. The year was also after extraordinary charge of $ 23.8 million, or 98 cents a share, from retirement of debt.c-Net loss, which included pretax litigation charge of $ 169.1 million, or $ 109.1 million, or $ 4.94 a share, after tax.d-After a charge of $ 47.1 million, or $ 2.13 a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement benefits.(Loss)

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'Desert of Roses' An Opera By Robert Moran TriBeCa Performing Arts Center

title: CHRONICLE
description: Almost since the day it opened its doors in December 1962, La Grenouille, on East 52d Street, has been known not only for its cuisine but also for its lush profusion of flowers.

title: To Tell the (Playoff) Truth: Will Real Nets Stand Up?
description: Chuck Daly has a problem. He doesn't know which Nets team will show up from game to game. Will it be the one that shoots 34.1 percent against Charlotte and loses by 99-78? Or will it be the one that comes back two days later and crushes the Knicks by 107-88?

title: New Top Officer at Intuit Is Former Apple Executive
description: Intuit Inc., the fast-growing personal finances software company, said today that it had named William V. Campbell, a former executive of Apple Computer Inc., as its president and chief executive.

title: Struck Trucking Company Closes Business
description: One of the 22 trucking companies that the teamsters union struck last week went out of business today, leaving more than 2,000 employees, most of them teamsters, unemployed.

title: Bonner Rested After Accident
description: Anthony Bonner missed last night's Knicks-Magic game after sustaining bruises to his left arm in a car accident Sunday night. Knicks Coach Pat Riley said that Bonner was alone when the single-car crash occurred. John Cirillo, the Knicks' vice president for media relations, said that a tire blew on Bonner's car, causing the accident. The Knicks said they believed it occurred on the Hutchison River Parkway.

title: Electricity Stalls Power of Wind As a Statewide Source of Energy
description: With the cost of the technology dropping, windmills could help the Northeast meet its energy needs more cleanly, experts said today at a conference on renewable energy sources.

title: Yes, You Do Have to Be A Brain Surgeon to Get More Speed Cheaply
description: WHAT clown, facing multiple deadlines, would have the Frankensteinian nerve to delve into his primary computer, pluck out its brain and try to install a speedier, smarter model?

title: Quake-Damaged Freeway Reopening Ahead of Time
description: Less than three months after an earthquake shut it down and more than two months ahead of schedule, the Santa Monica Freeway, aorta of this city's circulatory system, reopens on Tuesday. And if every public official claiming credit for the rapid repair stood on them at once, the two newly restored bridges over La Cienega Boulevard and Fairfax Avenue might just collapse again.

title: Would Germans Elect Hitler's Daughter?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Mets-Cubs In Baseball Time Warp
description: GORGEOUS day for the home opener. Bright sunshine and hearty memories on the message board. Up there, good old Al Weis was sliding into second. Good old Ron Swoboda was running down good old Bud Harrelson in short left field, and that's why they called him Rocky. And there was good old Ernie Banks striking out.

title: 25,000 Saboteurs of Peace
description: The 160 monitors from Denmark, Italy and Norway arriving in Hebron will be hard-pressed to protect the Palestinians from Jewish militants. They have no police powers, and it is not yet clear if they will carry pistols.

title: From Y.& R. to TBS, Without Complaints
description: Steven J. Heyer, an executive vice president at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and president and chief operating officer of its Young & Rubicam Advertising subsidiary, has left to become president of Turner Broadcasting Sales in New York and corporate vice president for broadcasting sales, sales marketing and development at its parent, Turner Broadcasting System.

title: Caray and Kiner: Still Giving Spring Its Voice
description: Half an hour before game-time yesterday at Shea Stadium, Ha-REEE Ca-RAAAAY had not appeared in the Chicago Cubs' WGN-TV broadcast booth. That gave WGN staffers time for some heavy lifting without Harry in their hair.

title: SUSQUEHANNA BANCSHARES TO ACQUIRE 3 BALTIMORE BANKS
description: Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had signed agreements to acquire three banking companies in the Baltimore area for a total of $112.7 million in cash and stock. The acquisition ofAtlanfed Bancorp Inc., the Fairfax Financial Corporation and Reisterstown Holdings Inc., and the pending purchase of eight branches from First Maryland Bancorp, will almost double Susquehanna's assets to $2.9 billion and increase its network of branches in Pennsylvania and Maryland to 104 from 75. Susquehanna Bancshares plans to acquire Atlanfed Bancorp in a stock swap valued at $29.7 million, or about $20 a share. The company plans to pay $55 million in cash for Fairfax Financial and about $28 million in cash for Reistertown Holdings.

title: Scientists to Test State's Vulnerability to Earthquakes
description: Sometime this month, a team of state geologists equipped with steel plates, sledge hammers and listening devices will fan out through Columbia County to determine its vulnerability to earthquakes.

title: Dr. Jerome Lejeune Dies at 67; Found Cause of Down Syndrome
description: Jerome Lejeune, a French geneticist who discovered the chromosome abnormality in humans that causes Down syndrome, a common form of mental retardation, died on April 3 in Paris. He was 67 and lived in Paris.

title: Work Begins on Court Selection
description: President Clinton began his formal search for a Supreme Court nominee today and immediately began to focus on whether the White House could circumvent a Constitutional prohibition on appointing a lawmaker to a Federal office during a term in which Congress voted to increase the officeholder's pay.

title: Hanoi Journal; In This Author's Book, Villains Are Vietnamese
description: It is one thing for Duong Thu Huong to attack the Vietnamese Communist Party for what she considers to be its corruption, its incompetence and its frequent indifference to the misery of Vietnam's poor.

title: Hibernia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Hibernia said that its increased net income was the result of lower noninterest expense and higher noninterest income. Noninterest expense decreased to $ 48,031,000 in latest first quarter from $ 50,806,000 in year-ago period. Noninterest income rose to $ 17,200,000 in latest period from $ 15,696,000 in year-ago period.

title: Observer; Been Away Too Long
description: It's lovely to be back in New York after long absence. "The only real city," somebody said to me long ago, and he was not a New Yorker. Well, we don't have to be chauvinistic about it. Betty Comden and Adolph Green put it well enough in words for Leonard Bernstein's music to sing: "The Bronx is up, but the Battery's down, and people ride in a hole in the ground; New York, New York, it's a helluva town!" That's good enough.

title: Mayor Enters Hostile Zone On Henry St.
description: Faced with two competing camps of protesters at a town hall meeting on the Lower East Side last night, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was met with heckling so raucous that he and the neighborhood residents seeking to ask questions could barely be heard.

title: Edison Ready To Reopen Gas Pipeline
description: Town officials and the owners of a natural gas pipeline that burst apart in a terrifying fireball here on March 23 agreed today to reopen the now-repaired line on Wednesday evening, three weeks after the rupture.

title: El Paso Electric Co.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $ 19,539,000 in the quarter and $ 30,594,000 in the year for expenses associated with company's reorganization plan. The year was also after a charge of $ 96,044,000, or $ 2.70 a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting change for income taxes.c-Included charges of $ 8,437,000 in the quarter and $ 26,368,000 in the year for expenses associated with company's reorganization plan.(Loss)

title: Irish Return Man Gone?
description: MICHAEL MILLER, whose punt returns sparked Notre Dame to two key victories last season, may be finished with the Fighting Irish.

title: Mayor Wins, But at a Price; Battle With Cortines May Be Costly Victory
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani emerged from his weekend confrontation with the Schools Chancellor largely with what he wanted: a mayoral appointee empowered to look into the inner workings and finances of the Board of Education.

title: Public Libraries Would Love to Do Better, if They Had Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugee Missionaries From Rwanda Speak of Their Terror, Grief and Guilt
description: The worst part, says Phil Van Lanen, was not the constant crackle of gunfire around the house, or the trucks piled with corpses, or even the gangs of wild-eyed young men who were always outside, somewhere, waving clubs and machetes and looking for someone to kill.

title: Scientist Ousted From Cancer Study Declines to Testify to House Panel
description: In a surprising development, Dr. Bernard Fisher, the University of Pittsburgh scientist who for more than three decades directed a group of studies that helped change the way breast cancer is treated, will not appear before a Congressional subcommittee on Wednesday.

title: Allow Nanny Employers More for Child Care; Let Workers Pay In
description: To the Editor:

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Air France Unions Back Cost-Cutting Plan
description: Air France's unionized employees have overwhelmingly approved a cost-cutting plan by management intended to save the airline that freezes wages and could mean job cuts.

title: Mexican Candidate Visits Dubious Hometown
description: In another Mexico, it might have been a comforting political set piece: the governing party's new presidential candidate back to see his humble roots, the smiling neighbors, the church where he was an altar boy.

title: Woman's Nude Body Found in Levittown
description: The nude body of a woman was discovered by two cable television installers as they were working in the back yard of a house in Levittown late this afternoon, the Nassau County police said today.

title: Stress? Doughnuts? Hah! Officers Get Fit to Fight
description: BECAUSE of the doughnuts, all those doughnuts, and the pizza and cheeseburgers and mounds of french fries, there are police officers out there who can't seem to move with the greatest of ease.

title: A Pianist's New York Debut
description: Amir Katz, the first-prize winner in the 1993 Robert Casadesus International Piano Competition, is to make his New York debut on Monday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. On the program are the New York premiere of Tzvi Avni's "On the Verge of Time," Liszt's "Reminiscences of Don Juan" and works by Bach and Scriabin. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Bank Mutual Fund Saless Face Check
description: In a partial concession to Congressional critics, the Treasury Department announced today that its officials would begin making anonymous visits to banks to determine if bank officials were advising clients about the risks of putting their money into mutual funds.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 9,329,000, or 11 cents a share, in the latest first quarter and $ 42,202,000, or 47 cents a share, in year-ago period, from losses on debt extinguishment.

title: A Cease-Fire on Schools
description: The compromise between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines that resulted in the withdrawal of Mr. Cortines's threat to resign defuses the most serious crisis of Mr. Giuliani's young administration. The settlement is a welcome outcome for New York City's 1.1 million schoolchildren and for the two combatants. Though both men could claim some measure of victory on specific issues, their larger triumph was to find a face-saving solution to a potentially disruptive brawl.

title: Citizens Bancorp (Md.) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Money Growing on Trees? No, but Study Finds Next Best Thing
description: PLANTING trees in cities and suburbs can reap millions of dollars in long-term savings by making it less costly to heat and cool buildings, by absorbing air pollution and by conferring a range of other environmental benefits, according to a study by the United States Forest Service.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Western Wind Vocal Ensemble Kaye Playhouse

title: Eastern Europe Being Robbed Of Much of Its Artistic Legacy
description: With the opening of Eastern Europe's borders, its little-visited museums and poorly guarded churches are being stripped of paintings, manuscripts and religious objects by thieves.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Motorola Net Up as Share Prices Tumble
description: Shares of Motorola Inc. fell sharply in after-market trading yesterday after the company reported first-quarter earnings that were below some analysts' expectations.

title: Synoptics Communications Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: Per share figures reflected a 3-for-1 stock split effective June 1993.Synoptics Communications said that revenues and earnings in the latest first quarter were affected by a number of issues, including seasonal factors, competitive positioning, and a reduction of channel inventory levels.

title: French Ask If Suicide Was Message To Mitterrand
description: President Francois Mitterrand traveled to central France today to attend the funeral of an old friend and longtime aide who shot himself in Elysee Palace last week, but the mystery of what prompted Francois de Grossouvre to take his life remains unresolved.

title: Reviews/Dance; Created by Villella By Way of Balanchine
description: George Balanchine's spiritual heirs have spread out across the United States to head ballet troupes that are in some measure a response to what they received from this great choreographer and company director. Each troupe is different, colored by particulars of locale and personality. The Miami City Ballet, which danced this afternoon at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College here, was created in 1986 by Edward Villella. Mr. Villella was the gutsy, firebrand star of the New York City Ballet in the 1960's and 70's. And so unsurprisingly enough, the Miami company is filled with young firebrand dancers, many of them from Latin America. It dances with a Hispanic verve.

title: Knicks Keep Skidding Straight Toward Playoffs
description: At a time when they expected to peak, the Knicks have hit another slump.

title: Hilltoppers Hire Coach
description: Jacksonville basketball coach MATT KILCULLEN, whose Dolphins improved to 17-11 this season after going 5-22 a year ago, was named coach at Western Kentucky yesterday.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mets Single-Handedly Spoil Their Opening Day at Shea
description: It was supposed to be a new product. The Mets put fresh faces on the field and they put fresh paint on the walls and they hoped that on this opening day at Shea Stadium things would look appealing and different and people would get excited about the 1994 Mets.

title: Professional Jurors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Badillo Joins Chorus of Fiscal Oversight
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to appoint Herman Badillo as a special counsel to scrutinize the school budget adds a sixth observer of the financial management of the New York City Board of Education.

title: Media General Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
Baryshnikov to Perform
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov is to dance with the New York City Ballet in Jerome Robbins's "Suite of Dances" on May 10, 13 and 27 at 8 P.M. and on May 29 at 1 P.M. at the New York State Theater. The ballet, a solo set to excerpts from Bach's Suites for Solo Cello, was presented in March by Mr. Baryshnikov's White Oak Dance Project. City Ballet's spring season opens on April 28. Tickets are $10 to $57; $11 to $62 for performances of "The Sleeping Beauty." Information: (212) 870-5570.

title: Review/Television; How a Gift For Accents Flowered Into Genius
description: It all started at a working-class diner in Yonkers, where the boss's son quickly absorbed the French, German or Italian accents and language rhythms of the customers. One day somebody left behind a saxophone. That would become young Sidney's meal ticket into show business. The upshot is encapsulated in the title of tonight's "Biography" edition on A&E: "Sid Caesar: Television's Comedy Genius."

title: Review/Fashion; For Calvin Klein, Suburbia Reigns
description: White shoes are not a city thing. They aren't something those walking on filthy streets even consider. White shoes belong to the suburbs, uncharted fashion territory that this season was right at the heart of Calvin Klein's predominantly white-shod CK collection.

title: Study Confirms Some Fears on U.S. Children
description: A wide-ranging, three-year study of young American children to be released today confirms some of society's worst fears: millions of infants and toddlers are so deprived of medical care, loving supervision and intellectual stimulation that their growth into healthy and responsible adults is threatened.

title: Mets' Early Gait Helps at Gate, But Can't Deliver a Shea Sellout
description: Those three quick Met victories opening the season last week did more than buoy the morale of the players and their long-frustrated fans. They also touched off a surge in ticket sales that had club financial officials almost smiling.

title: Review/Fashion; Kors Soothes, But Never Johnson
description: Talk about culture shock. Imagine the fashion retailers and members of the press who went straight to the Michael Kors show, with its totally unadorned classicism, immediately after Betsey Johnson's exhibitionism yesterday afternoon.

title: Siberian Oil Venture by 4 Companies
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it and three other oil companies had formed a company to explore for and possibly develop oilfields in a remote area in Siberia.

title: Rangers Roster Grows by 3
description: The Rangers added another goalie, another Messier and one more Richter to their roster Monday. They will go into the final week of the regular season with 29 players, although only 18 skaters plus two goalies can dress for every game. The new faces were called up from Binghamton, which ended its regular season on Sunday.

title: Rabbi Schneerson's Condition Worsens
description: The spiritual leader of the world's Lubavitch Hasidic Jews, who has been hospitalized since suffering a stroke a month ago, took a turn for the worse yesterday.

title: Looking at the Markets; With Future Bright, Stocks and Bonds Fall; Economists Grapple With Contradictions
description: For more than three years stock and bond prices marched optimistically upward in spite of economic forecasts that varied from murky to guarded. But once the clouds lifted to reveal a sunny future for the American economy, the securities markets took their worst dive since the recession of 1990.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest quarter's results included a gain of $ 983,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of a portion of the company's investment in marketable equity securities.

title: On My Mind; Clinton In Wartime
description: President Clinton, after overriding the publicly stated opinions of his own Secretary of Defense and top military officer, sent U.S. airplanes into action in Bosnia by the decision of a British general.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Greta Garbo was famous for wanting "to be let alone," but nearly four years after her death her wish is still going unfulfilled. MARK ROESLER, president of the Curtis Management Group, an agency in Indianapolis that represents the families and estates of deceased celebrities, among them Humphrey Bogart, James Dean and Babe Ruth, announced yesterday that he had signed an agreement with Garbo's family. The actress was survived by a niece, GRAY REISFIELD, who had five children, Mr. Roesler said.

title: Centura Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Centura Banks said that higher earning asset levels accounted for most of the increase in earnings, despite a drop in interest rate spreads. Centura said that its noninterest income increased 22 percent in the quarter, primarily due to strong growth in mortgage income.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The singer ELLA FITZGERALD had both her legs amputated below the knee in separate operations last year because of complications from diabetes, her spokeswoman, Mary Jane Outwater, announced yesterday in Beverly Hills.

title: Companies Assess Psychotherapy by the Numbers
description: Trying to curb the rising cost of treating workers for mental illness and substance abuse, a growing number of companies are turning to a new way of measuring treatment using computers. That is reducing expenses, but also bringing an attempt at precision to psychotherapy that worries some therapists.

title: Benefits of Broccoli Confirmed as Chemical Blocks Tumors
description: Yes, broccoli is as good for you as it's chopped up to be. Likewise for cauliflower, brussels sprouts, cabbage and other crunchy, tastily bitter members of the cruciferous family of vegetables.

title: Who Are These Mets? 3 Games Don't Make The Entire Season
description: A game won in April, goes the baseball maxim, is one less game you have to win in September. But games won in April can be misleading.

title: Avia Group Puts Up Account for Review
description: Avia Group International said yesterday that it placed its account in review after two and a half years at Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $5 million.

title: Latin America May Outpace U.S. in Abortions
description: THE abortion rate among Latin American women is equal to or higher than the rate among women in the United States, a study has found, even though abortion is illegal in every Latin American country but Cuba.

title: Test Shows Fertilizers Can Help to Speed Oil Cleanups
description: THE notion that fertilizers could help clean up beaches fouled by oil spills was suggested more than 20 years ago, but the effectiveness of such efforts has been hard to demonstrate outside the laboratory.

title: South Africa Tries to Prepare Those It Long Denied Ballot
description: There was a pastoral sweetness in the room as the once-fantastic idea of voting freely in South Africa was explained at the Soweto Home for the Aged to 50 black people who had suffered the longest across decades of racist white oligarchy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Promoting Disney's dwarfs, builders of the franchise, for the home-video audience.
description: LISTEN carefully to that sound wafting through the San Francisco office of Hal Riney & Partners. Is it employees singing, "Heigh-ho, heigh-ho, it's off to work we go?"

title: No Headline
description: "Collectively, we all have to say, 'Enough.' " -- JUDITH E. JONES, director of the National Center for Children in Poverty. [ A1:3. ]

title: Chinatown Gang Leader to Be Returned to U.S.
description: Guo Liang Chi, who authorities say was the leader of the Chinatown gang most deeply involved in the smuggling of illegal immigrants from China, agreed in a Hong Kong court yesterday to a request by the United States for his extradition.

title: Mom Was Right
description: Scientists have joined mothers in singing the praises of broccoli, cauliflower and cabbage. Now a new study shows that when a key compound in these cruciferous vegetables is isolated it helps to prevent the formation of tumors in animals as successfully as it did in the test tube.

title: U.S. PLANES BOMB SERBIAN POSITION FOR A SECOND DAY
description: For the second straight day, United States warplanes carried out highly limited bombing raids against Serbian nationalist forces that were attacking the United Nations "safe area" of Gorazde today, NATO and United Nations officials said.

title: Researchers Are Accused Of Forgeries
description: Researchers at the University of Cincinnati who exposed patients to intense doses of radiation in a cold-war-era experiment were accused today of forging the signatures of patients on consent forms and other medical documents.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins Clinch Division Title Tom Barrasso stopped 32 shots in Ottawa last night as the Pittsburgh Penguins clinched the Northeast Division title with a 4-0 victory over the Senators. The Penguins finished the regular season with a 44-27-13 record and will be the No. 2 playoff seed in the Eastern Conference behind the Atlantic Division champion Rangers, who are 51-24-7 with 2 games left. (AP)

title: 15 Nations Offer Troops For U.N. Force of 54,000
description: More than 15 countries have pledged at least 54,000 troops and other specialists toward the creation of a United Nations inventory of peacekeepers and equipment for future operations, a United Nations official said today.

title: U.S. and U.N. Consider Heavier Attacks on Serbs
description: The Clinton Administration and the United Nations Secretariat are examining the possibility of asking NATO to conduct more aggressive air strikes against the Serbs if they refuse to end their attack on the Muslim "safe area" of Gorazde, American and United Nations officials say.

title: P.& G. Bet On Rates Turns Sour
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would take a $102 million after-tax charge against its third-quarter earnings as a result of having been "badly burned" in two derivatives contracts.

title: Reviews/Television; The Price of a Perpetual Revolution
description: "The Mao Years, 1949-1976" takes no position on whether Mao Zedong was a case history of power corrupting or of ideology running amok or of the psychopathology of dictatorship, but it leaves little doubt that whatever the diagnosis, the consequences fell heavily on the Chinese people.

title: EGYPTIAN BOTTLING COMPANY IS ACQUIRED FOR $47 MILLION
description: A joint venture led by the Pepsi-Cola International unit of Pepsico Inc. has bought the Egyptian Bottling Company, a Pepsi bottler, for $47 million. Pepsi said the joint venture would invest $60 million in the next two years to modernize the bottler's operations, introduce new packages and brands and expand distribution. The venture will operate eight bottling plants now responsible for 45 percent of the Egyptian volume of Pepsi. The company's partners in the venture are the Alkhan Group of Companies, based in Cairo, and Bugshan & Brothers, a Pepsi bottler in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

title: Study of Nuclear Workers Finds High Cancer Rates
description: Workers at an atomic weapons factory making uranium for nuclear bombs died at significantly younger ages and suffered a higher incidence of lung, intestinal and blood cancers than the American population as a whole, according to an analysis of their medical records that was made public today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE
description: Loyola

title: Phillips Stevens, 80; For 23 Years Led Williston Academy
description: Phillips Stevens, who was headmaster of Williston Academy in Easthampton, Mass., for 23 years until retiring in 1972, died on Monday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 80 and lived in Jensen Beach, Fla., and Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: I'm Insured -- I Think
description: The funny thing is, I did everything right.

title: Review/Dance; How Cast Changes at the Joffrey Can Color the Works
description: Multiple casting is a way of life in dance, as the Joffrey Ballet showed again with debuts and cast changes on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Cancer Study Renews Old Concerns
description: Karen Pearsall, a 39-year-old mother of three, has been drinking bottled water for almost two decades, fearful that Glen Cove's water may be contaminated by cancer-causing chemicals.

title: Trudeau Inquires About the Jets' Backup Job
description: The Jets played host yesterday to Jack Trudeau, another in a line of veteran free-agent quarterbacks the team has brought through in hopes of finding an experienced backup to Boomer Esiason next season.

title: Not Your Average Rice
description: A MENU featuring salmon, tuna or swordfish with a rice dish flavored with dried cherries and banana, and accompanied by a salad of endive and Gorgonzola, is a treat for any family dinner or for last-minute company on a weekday. It takes a half-hour.

title: Market Place; As other brokerage stocks sink, Salomon's shares are buoyant.
description: WITH the bond market reeling, this has been a bad year for brokerage stocks. But Salomon Inc. has bucked the trend, rising nicely despite the fact that its second-largest holder turned tail and dumped its entire holdings.

title: PARTNERSHIP WITH CABLE SYSTEM IS SOUGHT BY MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it was eager to forge ties with a cable television system operator in a partnership that would enable the companies to send voice and video over the same lines. The chief financial officer of MCI, Douglas L. Maine, said the company had had discussions with several cable companies. Mr. Maine said it was unlikely that MCI would swap equity with a cable television partner. "Never say never, but it's more likely we will reach an agreement with a cable company concerning guaranteed access time over the system," he said.

title: Radioactivity Experiment and the Human Aftermath Wins a Pulitzer
description: GENERAL NONFICTION DAVID REMNICK "Lenin's Tomb: The Last Days of the Soviet Empire"

title: Asbury to Coach Kansas State
description: TOM ASBURY, whose Pepperdine team took Michigan to overtime in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, was hired as basketball coach at Kansas State. He succeeds DANA ALTMAN, who will coach at Creighton. (AP)

title: Sund Pays the Price for Dallas's Record
description: RICK SUND, who helped build the Dallas Mavericks into a model franchise in the 1980's before the team crashed in the 1990's, was fired yesterday as vice president after 14 seasons with the club. "Let's just say it has to do with a new course that we've got to be on," said DONALD CARTER, the team's owner. Dallas is 9-66. (AP)

title: Henry Horowitz, Book Printer, 76
description: Henry Horowitz, a printer and binder of specialty books for more than 50 years, died on Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Horowitz, who maintained homes in Palm Beach and Clifton, N.J., was 76.

title:
BASEBALL;
Bonds and Giants Spoil Fun for Braves
description: Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants finally beat the Atlanta Braves. In a twist on last year's heart-stopping National League West division race, the San Francisco Giants spoiled the Braves' home opener tonight, 7-5, and stopped Atlanta's season-opening victory streak at eight games.

title: Yawn, So When Do the Playoffs Start?
description: Since their loss to the Rangers with six games left in the regular season thwarted their challenge for first place, the Devils have been playing with diminished intensity.

title: In School
description: When Bennett Brown graduated from M.I.T. two years ago with an A average, he could have worked anywhere. He'd done research on cancer and artificial intelligence and was published as a sophomore. ("At one point I was interested in growing neurons," he said.) He scored perfect 800's on the G.R.E.'s.

title: Faulk to Meet With Parcells
description: MARSHALL FAULK, the top-rated running back in the National Football League draft who could be the No. 1 pick over all on April 24, will meet tomorrow with BILL PARCELLS, the Patriots' coach. If drafted by New England, which has the fourth pick, Faulk, 5 foot 11 inches and 200 pounds, would complement the power runner, LEONARD RUSSELL. "He is very impressive," said CHARLEY ARMEY, New England's director of player personnel. "I was in San Diego and he ran the 40 in a 4.3."

title: A Volunteer and Proud
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Madonna Village Theater Company 133 West 22d Street Chelsea Through May 1 By Don Nigro; directed by Gigi Rivkin; lighting by Douglas O'Flaherty; set by Michael Blau; costumes by Alyson Hui; sound by James Harrington; production stage manager, Jennifer Creighton; scenic artist, Meta Witkowski; assistant stage manager, Keith Modeste. Presented by the Village Theater Company. WITH: Pam Bennett, Jill Chamberlain, Elizabeth Daly, Marj Feenan, Mark Foley, Peter Husovsky, Craig Little, Lisa Littlewood, Christopher Marino, J. B. McLendon, Roger Michelson, Michael Pinney, Melanie Summerfield and Brenda Warren.

title: Salvador Election Made Tammany Look Pure
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: Police Weighing Conversion To Hollow-Point Ammunition
description: In the latest effort to increase officers' firepower, the New York City Police Department is considering switching to hollow-point bullets that expand on contact with human flesh to inflict more damage than traditional ammunition.

title: Islanders Aiming to Make It on Their Own
description: They sunned themselves at poolside. They explored the local fairways. They even squeezed in a practice session at a nearby rink.

title: Book Notes
description: A Long-Neglected Novel

title: The House Tackles Crime
description: Now it is the House's turn to debate a crime bill that foolishly creates a slew of new Federal crimes and death penalties to display "toughness" but also extends a badly needed Federal hand -- and dollar -- to anxious states and localities for crime control programs. Starting with the Senate-approved $22 billion for more police and prisons, the House embarks today on several days of debate over how to spend that money and otherwise make Washington's voice heard.

title: Mitchell Moves Into Position for Top Baseball Job
description: In removing himself from consideration for the United States Supreme Court, Senator George J. Mitchell put himself in position yesterday to be named the next baseball commissioner.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Share Slide At Motorola Continues
description: Shares of Motorola Inc. plunged another $4 today as the company tried to ease concerns about first-quarter earnings that fall short of some analysts' expectations.

title: Theater in Review
description: Colette Theater for the New City 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street East Village Through Sunday By Rebecca Chace; directed by Jonathan Rosenberg; set by Erika Belsey; costumes by Christopher Del Coro; lighting by Tommy Wong; technical director, Paul Ferri; stage manager, Tim Pettolina. Presented by Theater for the New City and Bartenieff/Field. WITH: Sarah Buff, Ms. Chace, Nina Hellman, Donna LaBrecque and Jane Welch.

title: Israel and P.L.O. in Accord on Palestinian Police Force
description: Israeli and P.L.O. negotiators, meeting to work out details of the self-rule agreement signed last September, settled the thorny issue of the deployment of Palestinian police in Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho today and agreed to the release of 5,000 prisoners now in Israeli jails.

title: Public & Private; Playing Perfect Pattycake
description: Why in the world am I sitting here trying to recall how many hours my children spent playing with blocks when they were small? Why am I trying to tote up the time I spent reading "Pat the Bunny" versus that I spent wheeling them around supermarket aisles talking to myself?

title: Evans, 6-7 Forward, Picks Manhattan
description: HESHIMU EVANS, a 6-foot-7-inch forward, announced yesterday that he will attend Manhattan College this fall.

title: Russia and Belarus to Unify Monetary Systems
description: In a move bound to increase concern in the West about Russian neo-imperialism, the Prime Ministers of Russia and Belarus signed a treaty today to unify their monetary systems and lift customs barriers.

title: Women Campaign for New Plan To Curb the World's Population
description: For decades, when population planners talked about the world's poorest women, they concentrated on how to keep them from having more babies. Vast programs in Asia, Africa and Latin America were geared to sterilizing women, implanting them with IUD's, handing out contraceptives and imposing quotas on family size.

title: Review/Television; No Pat Answers, as in Life
description: A black boy is accidentally killed in New York City by a hit-and-run driver who happens to be Jewish. The man ends up with a suspended driver's license and 100 hours of community service. Enraged blacks riot. A white man is dragged from his car and beaten to death in front of his horrified wife. A black youth is charged with murder but is given sanctuary in the church of an angry minister. The city's racial tensions are at the breaking point.

title: Rangers' Victory Is 'Easy' As 1-2-3
description: The Rangers hurtled toward 1940 last night with a splurge of will in the final period. On the surface, it mattered little that they produced a 3-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden in their next-to-last game of the regular season. After all, the Rangers have already guaranteed themselves the best record in the National Hockey League.

title: Black Smokers' Higher Risk Of Cancer May Be Genetic
description: Researchers investigating why black men who smoke are 48 percent more likely to develop lung cancer than white male smokers have found a possible explanation: It may be genetic.

title: The Kentucky Waltz Has Begun in Earnest
description: It was chilly and rainy at Aqueduct yesterday morning, but the New York road to the Kentucky Derby was crowded with horses working out for the $500,000 Wood Memorial on Saturday. And another cluster of candidates for the Derby crowded the track at Keeneland in Lexington, Ky., where the $500,000 Blue Grass Stakes will attract an even more imposing field the same day with heavy hitters such as Holy Bull and Valiant nature.

title: Shawmut Picks Houston Effler
description: The Shawmut National Corporation in Boston and Hartford said yesterday that it had selected Houston Effler & Partners in Boston to handle its account, with billings estimated at $12 million. Ketchum Advertising New York had handled the account for the last five years until resigning in February.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CHEMICAL LINK IN BREAST CANCER DATA

title: Knicks Seeking a Way Back From Their Early April Swoon
description: The momentum the Knicks built in March has vanished. Their lead over the Atlanta Hawks has disappeared. And the Chicago Bulls are back in the race for best record in the Eastern Conference.

title: Critical Winds Shift for Albee, A Master of the Steady Course
description: For Edward Albee, the long exile is over.

title: A Primer on Hedge Funds: Hush-Hush and for the Rich
description: If investment bankers and junk bond dealers were the popular Wall Street villains of the 1980's -- living lavishly on hundreds of millions of dollars of earnings -- managers of hedge funds are being cast as the suspicious characters of the 1990's.

title: Personal Health
description: JUST as all roads once led to Rome, all blood vessels in the human body ultimately empty into the heart. But only one, the aorta, leaves the heart's main pumping chamber, the left ventricle, to deliver life-sustaining oxygen-rich blood to the entire body.

title: Bank of New York's Income Rose 33% in First Quarter
description: The Bank of New York Company served up several pleasant surprises to Wall Street yesterday, announcing strong earnings, a stock buyback and an increase in its quarterly dividend.

title: Wine Talk
description: NEW YORK'S first wine auction under a recently enacted state law is to be held on April 30 at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Washington Dining: A Deficit No More
description: Michel Richard, the chef and owner of Citrus in Los Angeles, is ensconced in Georgetown.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in Business Day yesterday about a shareholder lawsuit accusing executives of Spectrum Information Technologies Inc. of insider trading referred incorrectly in some editions to individuals arrested on fraud charges. They were employees of the Paradigm Group, an investment banking company founded by Peter T. Caserta, who is on leave as Spectrum's president. They are not officers of Spectrum.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Clinton Is Faulted on Political Choices for Envoy Posts
description: Despite promises to name ambassadors on the basis of qualifications that go beyond the size of their campaign contributions, President Clinton has found himself awarding many jobs to some big political donors who seem to lack much experience in international affairs.

title: Ovitz Riddle Roils Hollywood
description: The question "What does Michael Ovitz want?" has been asked repeatedly here in the last few months.

title: Dollar Rises on Speculation About a German Rate Cut
description: The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday amid speculation that the Bundesbank may cut interest rates at a meeting tomorrow on German monetary policy.

title: Critical Winds Shift for Albee, A Master of the Steady Course
description: For Edward Albee, the long exile is over.

title: Russia Drops Players From Cup Roster
description: Several of Russia's top soccer players were dropped from the preliminary World Cup roster announced yesterday because they say they won't play for Coach PAVEL SADYRIN. Included were ANDREI KANCHELSKIS of Manchester United in England, SERGEI KIRYAKOV of Karlsruhe in Germany, IGOR SHALIMOV of Internazionale of Milan in Italy, IGOR DOBROVOLSKY of Dynamo Moscow, IGOR KOLYVANOV of Foggia in Italy, VALERY KARPIN of Spartak Moscow and VASILY KULKOV of Benfica of Lisbon in Portugal. (AP)

title: German Developer Vanishes And Leaves Billions in Debt
description: Stocks fell and many construction sites all over Germany shut down today after the country's biggest real estate developer disappeared, leaving his company and its creditors in the dark and possibly holding the bag for billions of dollars worth of debts.

title: S.& P. RAISES CHASE'S SENIOR DEBT TO 'A' RATING
description: The senior debt of the Chase Manhattan Corporation was upgraded to A from A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which cited fewer problem loans and strong business lines at the bank. Standard & Poor's is the second debt-rating company to upgrade Chase Manhattan's debt in the last month. On March 17, Moody's Investors Service raised the New York bank's senior debt one notch, to A3 from Baa1. S.& P. released its opinion after the close of stock trading. Shares of Chase rose 50 cents, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pentagon Plea: Let an Admiral Keep His Stars
description: Three top Pentagon officials went to Capitol Hill today in an extraordinary step to argue that the Navy's chief admiral deserved to retire with his four stars intact, despite his role in the Tailhook sexual harassment scandal.

title: A Treat Blooms in Manhattan
description: A good garden show propagates feelings of envy and discontent. One can read unspoken soliloquies on faces of weekend gardeners: "How do they do it? I have exactly the same plants -- foxgloves, delphiniums, clematis -- and they never look like that."

title: Critical Winds Shift for Albee, A Master of the Steady Course
description: For Edward Albee, the long exile is over.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Lauren Takes an English Holiday
description: RALPH LAUREN took his audience on a romp through Merrie Olde England yesterday morning, starting with the Celts, moving through Camelot and the Elizabethans and ending with the crisp tailoring and comfortable-looking tweeds with which he has long been infatuated. It was a good-humored, pleasant journey through more than a thousand years of fashion, but with a strong contemporary look.

title: INSIDE
description: Serbs Quiet, but Defiant

title: In Virtual Reality, Tools for the Disabled
description: Strapped securely into an electric wheelchair with one hand around the joystick and a headset in place, Christopher Cobbs, 5, from Grants Pass, Ore., is negotiating challenging terrain: grassy fields, pools of mud, long panes of ice. To make it a bit more interesting, the landscape he is exploring is dotted with crazy, surreal sculptures of swirling pyramids and orbs.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about New York City's new police crackdown on truancy referred incorrectly to one student whom the police took into custody at a video arcade in midtown Manhattan. The police later learned that he was on Easter vacation from a Roman Catholic school; he was not one of the 216 truants picked up that day.

title: Theater in Review
description: Panorama Theater Row Theater 424 West 42d Street Clinton Through April 24 By Pieter-Dirk Uys; directed by George Ferencz; set by Bill Stabile; costumes by Sally Lesser; lighting by Jeff Tapper; sound by Genji Ito; stage manager, Jessica Hall. Presented by the Africa Arts Theater Company. WITH: Bill Christ, Jacqueline Pennington, Margie Rynn and Kim Tooks.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Ellen DeGeneres; Dialed God (Pause). He Laughed.
description: AT one point, Ellen DeGeneres was the Funniest Person in America.

title: 4 Former Brookhaven Officials Indicted in Bribe Scheme
description: Four former officials of the Town of Brookhaven have been charged in a Federal indictment with accepting bribes of as much as $250,000 to support a prominent developer's real-estate projects.

title: Review/Film: Serial Mom; The Case for Terminal Prejudice
description: If you're going to build a career on bad taste, sooner or later you'll have to tackle the most sacred icon of all, motherhood. John Waters is just the man to do it, for he sends up only what he deeply adores. In "Serial Mom" he takes to heart the idea that being the All-American mother is enough to drive a woman crazy. What could be more sympathetic?

title: Ferry Service Makes Ready To Broaden In the Region
description: After seven years of gradual expansion, ferry service in the New York region is about to branch out in a big way with several new routes to serve commuters -- and two designed especially for baseball fans.

title: Government Approves New Drug to Assist in Liver Transplants
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved the marketing of a new drug to help prevent rejection of transplanted livers. It became the third immunosuppressant drug licensed for organ transplant surgery in this country.

title: Free-for-All In Tokyo Is Shattering Party Lineup
