title: PRUDENTIAL LOSES ITS TOP CREDIT RATING
description: Because of problems with its Prudential Securities subsidiary, the Prudential Insurance Company of America has lost its top-notch credit rating, the A. M. Best Company, an insurance rating firm, announced yesterday. In cutting Prudential's rating to A+, the second highest of 15 ratings, from A++, officials at A. M. Best said a lower rating was justified by Prudential's exposure to losses arising from improper marketing at Prudential Securities and fraud claims levied against a real estate fund run by the insurance company. Those problems "will continue to have an adverse influence on the competitive positioning" of Prudential, A. M. Best said. Martin Pfinsgraff, Prudential's treasurer, said publicity about the problems at Prudential Securities did not prevent the company from continuing to grow. Prudential remained profitable last year with earnings of $4.6 billion before paying dividends to policyholders and has nearly $11 billion of capital to absorb unexpected losses.

title: Bausch & Lomb Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal Farm Credit Bank is selling through Paine Webber Inc. $100 million of medium-term notes due in 1996 and priced at 100 to yield 5.64 percent. The issue is callable in one year.

title: Ford Sets 12.5% Rise In Dividend
description: Casting a strong vote of confidence in the automobile industry's strengthening recovery, the Ford Motor Company plans to increase its dividend for the first time since 1989 and to split its stock 2 for 1.

title: No Headline
description: "Regardless of how much electronic equipment you have, it all comes down to the human factor. If human beings make a mistake, you are left with a tragedy." ROBERT GASKIN, a retired Air Force officer. [ A12:5. ]

title: Art in Review
description: 'Elizabeth Catlett' 'Works on Paper, 1944-1992' The Studio Museum in Harlem 144 West 125th Street Through May 8

title: First Commerce Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Vikes Have Themselves A Quarterback in Moon
description: WARREN MOON joined the Minnesota Vikings yesterday, becoming the most prominent quarterback the team has had since FRAN TARKENTON retired in 1978. The trade with the Houston Oilers, all but set on Wednesday, was finally completed yesterday.

title: A Deluxe Bit Of Europe In Manhattan
description: QUIETLY and discreetly, the Sherry-Netherland has begun advertising in the Hollywood trade papers, read by moguls, movie stars, agents and even more normal types. In the competitive New York City hotel market, it is seeking out visitors from California (only the wealthy or those with hefty expense accounts need apply). Yet it's not, perhaps, visitors from the West Coast who would feel the most comfortable at the Sherry-Netherland. It's those from Europe.

title: ABB TO BUILD $1 BILLION PLANT IN MALAYSIA
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. said yesterday that it had received a $1 billion contract to build a power plant in Malaysia that will supply 11 percent of the country's electricity. ABB, based in Zurich, said construction of the gas-fired plant in the province of Perak would begin immediately. The company expects the plant to be in full operation by July 1997. Sikap Energy Ventures, an independent power producer in Malaysia, placed the order. ABB said the plant would be equipped with six gas turbines, two steam turbines and eight electrical generators.

title: Golden West Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
L.I. INQUIRY FINDS ERRORS, NOT SNOW, STOPPED RAILROAD
description: The Long Island Rail Road's collapse of Feb. 11, which stranded tens of thousands of riders at their jobs in New York or on cold railroad platforms in Queens, was not caused by the 12-inch snowfall, but by shabby management, the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said in an unusually blunt report released yesterday.

title: Continental Insurance Plans Sale of 2 Units
description: The Continental Corporation, a New York insurance company, said yesterday that it planned to sell two major subsidiaries and reorganize its remaining property insurance businesses to eliminate 680 jobs, or about 5.5 percent of its work force.

title: Adolf J. Snow, 100; Was Sears Executive
description: Adolf J. Snow, who was an executive at Sears, Roebuck & Company when Gen. Robert E. Wood built it into the world's biggest merchandising enterprise, died on Wednesday. He was 100 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Potvin Calls Islanders 'a Real Contender'
description: Denis Potvin, a Hall of Famer who played in six "Battles of New York," suspects the Rangers didn't react with glee when they realized they would be facing their archrivals in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Nothing Is as Easy as ABC
description: The Battle of New York does not begin until Sunday and already there is controversy.

title: Riggs National Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included $ 4.7 million pretax gain from the settlement of mortgage insurance claims related to other real estate owned in the U.K.c-Net loss, which included one-time charge of $ 13.8 million, representing the cost of implementing a program to improve efficiency.(Loss)

title: 'Munchkin,' 14 and Playful, Is Now Held as Rape Suspect
description: He is "Munchkin" to his family and friends in Coney Island, the small, sweet-faced boy who could win anyone over with his playful charm. Some think they see a blossoming cartoonist in the 14-year-old boy, others a potential comic. But some said yesterday that they saw trouble looming in his life because no one was watching out for him.

title: The Federal Reserve Is Signaling A New Increase in Interest Rates
description: Federal Reserve officials say they see no signs of accelerating inflation, but the nation's central bank is signaling anew that it will raise short-term interest rates again anyway. The reason: the officials believe that low short-term rates have already encouraged too much lending, giving stimulus to an economy that no longer needs it.

title: More Officers Facing Arrest In Corruption
description: Two police officers were arrested at a Harlem station house last night and law enforcement officials said that about 10 more would be arrested today on charges that they protected or shook down drug dealers. The officials said the arrests represented the largest single sweep of police officers since the Mollen Commission began its corruption investigation.

title: Art in Review
description: Elizabeth Murray Paula Cooper Gallery 149 Wooster Street (at Houston Street) SoHo Through April 23

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Long Island Savings Bank FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 8,649,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 323,545,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bruins and Sabres Lose Finales That Really Aren't Final Word
description: Whalers 3, Bruins 2

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12 AMERICAN JETS DOWN U.S. COPTERS American jets shot down two Army helicopters carrying allied officials over the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq after the aircraft were mistaken for Iraqi helicopters. Twenty-six people were killed. A1 THE HORROR OF 'FRIENDLY FIRE' News analysis: In one sense, the accident over Iraq was just one more chapter in a long, tragic story. "Friendly fire," the military calls it -- an oxymoronic phrase designed to dull the pain. A1

title: TV Weekend; Jane Seymour as a Model Of the Noble Southerner
description: Jane Seymour is that peculiar creature called a television star, a performer who can almost miraculously transcend mediocre material. Long before "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman," her current series on CBS, she was collecting assorted and deserved awards for her television work in "East of Eden," "Jamaica Inn," "The Woman He Loved," "The Phantom of the Opera" and "War and Remembrance." The vehicles may sometimes sag noticeably, but Ms. Seymour's energy and determination are constantly in motion. Just watch her breathe life into the almost moribund "A Passion for Justice" on ABC on Sunday.

title: Mark Isaacson Memorial
description: A memorial service for Mark A. Isaacson, an expert on 20th-century decorative arts who died in August at the age of 38, is to take place on April 23 at 1 P.M. at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village. A reception is to follow in the church's parish hall.

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mustaf Cousin Indicted
description: LeVONNIE WOOTEN of Landover, Md., a cousin of Phoenix Suns forward JERROD MUSTAF, was indicted yesterday in the July 22 slaying of a woman who told her family she was carrying the player's unborn child. Before she was shot to death in her apartment in Glendale, Ariz., Althea Hayes, 28, also claimed Mustaf had offered her $5,000 to have an abortion and she had refused.

title: Corrections
description: The mutual funds tables in Business Day on Wednesday included incorrect data from Morningstar Inc. for the AIM Summit Fund. The fund's actual net asset value that day was $9.46, and the percentage returns to shareholders were minus 1.8 percent for the day, minus 2.5 percent for the year to date, plus 4.5 percent for one year and an annualized figure of plus 9.5 percent for three years. Because of the data errors, the fund was erroneously listed as the worst performing growth fund in the last year.

title: Louisiana Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 10.4 million, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Nuclear Agency Chief Warns of Need for Access to North Korea
description: The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency has warned that even if the Clinton Administration succeeded in its efforts to get North Korea to allow minimal nuclear inspections, his agency would probably need far broader access to the sealed-off country to fully measure the scope of its nuclear activities.

title: An Era of Excess Expressed in Silence
description: The lion's great jaws open, close and open again, but there's no sound: that was added only when pictures began to talk. At the Film Forum in the South Village, "The Silent Roar: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, 1924-1929" celebrates the company's 70th anniversary with a captivating series of 40 silents, many enhanced by the spirited piano accompaniment of Steve Sterner. The retrospective starts today and runs through May 11.

title: Clean Harbors Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/ Film; Chevy Chase, Wishing for Danger
description: In "Cops and Robbersons," Chevy Chase has an unfortunate chance to prove that there's something even more unfunny than his disastrous talk show. In this, a Chase vehicle with four flat tires, he plays a sad-sack suburbanite who secretly yearns to live dangerously, having watched too many police dramas on television.

title: Endorsing Growing Practice, Vatican Approves Altar Girls
description: The Vatican has granted permission for priests to have girls assist them at Mass, a task traditionally performed by boys and officially restricted to males. The action approves a practice that has become increasingly common in Roman Catholic parishes, particularly in the United States, but has also stirred fierce emotions among many Catholics.

title: Federal and New Jersey Agencies Dispute Jurisdiction in Excavation Near Pipeline
description: The explosion of a natural gas pipeline in Edison, N.J., has exposed a murky legal limbo over the responsibility for regulating excavation along the line. Such digging does not appear to be banned by Federal or state law or by Edison's land-use ordinances.

title: Operating Profit Down For Morgan
description: The first report is in on how turbulent world markets have affected big banks, and it shows that the first quarter of 1994 might not have been as bad as originally feared.

title: Endangered Children
description: America's youngest children are in serious trouble, according to a panel of experts brought together by the Carnegie Corporation. So many children are growing up without adequate medical and nutritional care, intellectual stimulation or emotional security that the nation's ability to produce healthy workers and citizens is in jeopardy.

title: Japan Welcomes Foreign Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Ex-Prosecutor in Trooper Case Says More Were Involved
description: Nelson E. Roth, who resigned last week as the special prosecutor looking into evidence-tampering by the New York State police, said he thinks more troopers knew about the faking of fingerprint evidence than have come forward.

title: 3 Players, 3 Agendas, One 3-Way Tug of War Fate of New York Coliseum Still Uncertain
description: It is, by most accounts, one of the most valuable potential development sites in New York City.

title: For Children
description: Children's Concert Riverside Church 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street Morningside Heights (212) 222-5900, extension 220 Recommended ages: 4 and up Tomorrow

title: Hofstra Hires Coach
description: JAY WRIGHT, an assistant to ROLLIE MASSIMINO at Nevada-Las Vegas, was appointed head basketball coach at Hofstra yesterday to succeed 71-year-old BUTCH VAN BREDA KOLFF, who has retired. Wright, 32, a Bucknell alumnus, had spent seven seasons with Massimino, five years at Villanova and the last two at Las Vegas.

title: The Verdict Not Guilty, the Defendant Not Satisfied
description: The legal pipeline is full of complaints filed by criminal defendants who contend that they did not get a fair trial. The improbable thing is that Howard L. Haupt is among them.

title: In Surprise Move, Germans Cut Both Key Interest Rates
description: The German central bank, in an effort to help calm turbulent financial markets, cut its two key interest rates today and set off a round of similar small cuts across Europe. The Bundesbank also held out the prospect of further gradual reductions if inflation continued to decline.

title: Darkness of 'Carousel' Has Roots in Budapest
description: To the Editor:

title: Where's Yankee Offense? O'Neill Finds It
description: Forget the sweep, forget being humiliated by the finest rotation in the league for another day and forget turning the initial trip of the season into an excursion to the dangerous land of last place. The Yankees could forget all these dreary possibilities today because Paul O'Neill unveiled a performance that the White Sox want to quickly forget.

title: Review/Art; With Old Persian Poems, Images of Wit and War
description: This little charmer of a show, tucked away deep within the Metropolitan Museum of Art's superb and little trafficked Islamic collection, is just the kind of thing the Met should be doing lots of. "Illustrated Poetry and Epic Images" highlights small-scale, easy-to-overlook art from the museum's own collection, displays it in an appropriately intimate setting, and demonstrates a bit of scholarly sleuthing in action.

title: Scripps (E.W.) Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included net gains of $ 2.3 million, or 3 cents a share, for an adjustment in estimated copyright fees; $ 1.6 million, or 2 cents a share, for a fee for the change of ownership of a newspaper; and $ 12.1 million, or 16 cents a share, for the sale of certain assets.Certain 1993 items have been reclassified to conform with 1994 classifications.

title: Review/Film; Ismail Merchant Directs First Feature
description: Lying on his side in a narrow bed is a corpulent, aging Indian poet named Nur. He is a curiously imposing figure, even with his back to the camera, and provides what may be the greatest role in the long career of Shashi Kapoor. Almost 30 years ago, Mr. Kapoor was the slender, handsome youth in the early Merchant-Ivory film "Shakespeare Wallah," and more recently the outraged father in Stephen Frears's "Sammy and Rosie Get Laid." In Ismail Merchant's rich and enticing "In Custody," Mr. Kapoor turns Nur into a present-day Balzac: fierce and wise, yet with all the signs of having lived a little too well.

title: U.S. Moves on Two Fronts To Reshape Logging Rules
description: The Clinton Administration moved on two fronts today to reshape the way the Government manages logging in the nation's remaining ancient forests.

title: Enron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 15 million, or $ 9.8 million after tax, from the offering of master limited partnership units in EOTT Energy Partners L.P.

title: New Careers for Cold War Relics
description: Hoping to find a peaceful, commercial use for relics of the cold war, the White House is considering recycling dozens of nuclear-warhead missiles and selling them to American industry for launching commercial satellites.

title: Fire Captain Improves
description: A fire captain who was badly burned in a SoHo blaze that killed two firefighters took a slight turn for the better yesterday, a hospital official said.

title: Review/Film; Did She or Didn't She? Commit Murder, That Is
description: "Two Small Bodies" is a sharply focused, intense drama about a woman whose young son and daughter are missing, and the detective who thinks she may have murdered them. There aren't many actors able to carry a two-character film, but Suzy Amis and Fred Ward are among the few who can. Eileen Maloney and Lieutenant Brann engage in a stylized dance that is antagonistic, sexual and unsettling as it reveals the dark impulses beneath their obvious social roles.

title: Critic's Notebook; Jazz With Pizazz: A New Generation of Clubs
description: THE gods of bankruptcy rub their hands together and smack their lips at the sight of a new jazz club, all lighted up and ready to go. Like the Titanic, new jazz clubs are launched with great intentions. And like the Titanic, they tend to sink. Indigo Blues, Condon's, Cameo's, Fortune Garden Pavilion and Yardbird Suite have all gone the way of the great auk. At the moment, new jazz spots are brightening Manhattan's landscape. The gods of bankruptcy must be smiling.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "WRITTEN AND SEALED," Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, 304 West 47th Street, Clinton. A drama by Isaac Chocron about a meeting between two old friends, a Jewish college professor and a Roman Catholic priest. Through Sunday. Performances: tonight at 8 (in English); Saturday at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 and 6:30 P.M. (in Spanish). Tickets: $15. Information: (212) 354-1293.

title: No Giveaway on the Coliseum
description: New York City has an undeniable interest in getting the old Coliseum site at Columbus Circle developed after years of delay and neglect -- but not at the expense of the public good. That is what makes the behavior of City Hall's chief negotiator, Deputy Mayor John Dyson, so regrettable. He sounds more like an agent for Mortimer Zuckerman, the developer, than a public servant.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ayer wins the struggle to land the industry's 'most wanted man.'
description: THE envelope, please. And the Dworin goes to -- Ayer Inc.!

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 719,000, or 6 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-After a benefit of $ 360,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Inflation: Myth and Reality
description: Fears of accelerating inflation have haunted the financial markets just at the time when the economy has turned in its best inflation performance in decades.

title: Rwanda Will Need Its Civil Servants
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; An oil spill may cause more headaches for Unocal's investors.
description: INVESTORS in the Unocal Corporation had a rough March and may be in for more unpleasant news arising from a little-publicized oil spill on the central California coast that ranks as one of the largest in the nation.

title: Fortaleza Journal; Bouquets for a State as Brazil's Dust Bowl Flowers
description: "Fortaleza: Brazil's Miami," a Rio newspaper gushed recently, describing a beachfront city of European tourists, foreign investors, imported cars, a thriving fashion industry, a new international yacht marina and steel-and-glass shopping centers with theaters showing Hollywood's latest films.

title: Gore Insists Environment Is a Trade Issue
description: Looking beyond a sweeping global trade agreement that will be signed here Friday, the United States said today that future trade negotiations should include discussion of environmental and labor questions, despite the opposition of many developing countries.

title: Schwab (Charles) Corp.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflected the 1993 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Where Sultan Swatted, Team of Dreams Is Born
description: At the same park where Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Ted Williams played in exhibition games in the 1930's, and where George Bush played first base in the 40's, professional baseball today made its debut at 66-year-old Yale Field.

title: Orr Leaves Coaching
description: JOHNNY ORR, the coach at Iowa State for 14 years, announced yesterday that he would not return for a 15th season. Orr, 66, will remain at Iowa State, in Ames, as associate athletic director to fulfill the last year of his contract. Orr's career record while coaching at Massachusetts, Michigan and Iowa State is 466-346.(AP)

title: First Bank System reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Ties to Lawyer Are Explained By Prosecutor
description: Responding to questions from Congress about his objectivity, the special prosecutor investigating the Whitewater affair has detailed what he said was a professional, not personal, relationship with the former White House counsel, Bernard W. Nussbaum.

title: Giuliani Extending Severance Deadline
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that New York City would give workers at least an extra week to apply for the voluntary severance packages that he hopes will reduce the city's work force by 7,600.

title: U.N. in Rwanda Says It Is Powerless to Halt the Violence
description: As battling armies pounded the capital with mortar fire today, the United Nations command here said that it could do little to stop the fighting or prevent the massacre of civilians and that an attempt to hold peace talks had failed.

title: Holy Bull Draws Rail As Choice in Blue Grass
description: Holy Bull, the favorite in the Blue Grass Stakes this Saturday and maybe in the Kentucky Derby three weeks later, stepped regally outside Barn 14 at Keeneland Race Course this morning. No horse has ever run in front of him in the early stages of his seven races, and he won six of them leading almost every step of the way.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CELESTIAL SEASONINGS INC., Boulder, Colo., the herbal tea company, and Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., the health care and consumer products company, have agreed to enter into a licensing arrangement by which Warner-Lambert will produce a line of Celestial Seasonings specialty herbal products. NEXTEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., Rutherford, N.J., a wireless communications company, said it would invest $5 million for a 20 percent stake in closely held Saber Communications Inc., Mobile, Ala., an operator of mobile radio networks.

title: Review/Film; Half Dog and Half Wolf, But All Hero and Lover
description: In the time-honored tradition of heroic Hollywood canines, the title character of "White Fang 2: Myth of the White Wolf" is an infallible judge of character. Half dog, half wolf, White Fang can be as plaintively devoted a helpmate as Lassie. But when scenting evil, he becomes as relentlessly ferocious as Charles Bronson settling a score. In the most spectacular of the movie's several rescue scenes, White Fang leaps from a cliff onto a speeding horse-drawn wagon to save an Indian princess from being spirited away by a slave-driving gold miner.

title: I.B.M. Agrees to Make Chips Designed by Cyrix
description: In a serious challenge to the Intel Corporation's dominance of the market for microprocessors, the chips that are the brains of personal computers, I.B.M. said today that it would manufacture the Cyrix Corporation's Intel-compatible chips.

title: Mid Atlantic Medical Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of 3 cents a share for the cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

title: Dominion Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Coleman Goes Down And Anderson Goes Up
description: It may not have been as significant as Willis Reed walking onto the Madison Square Garden floor for Game 7 of the National Basketball Association finals for the Knicks in 1970, but the Nets were happy to see Derrick Coleman return from the locker room midway through overtime tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Old Kent Financial Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BOARD OF FIBREBOARD REJECTS NEW BID BY POHLAD GROUP
description: The Fibreboard Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected the new bid of $45 a share for the company submitted by a group led by the financier Carl Pohlad. The board replied to Mr. Pohlad, the owner of the Minnesota Twins baseball club, in a letter saying that the sale of the company "at this time is not in the best interests of shareholders." The offer is valued at $187.7 million. In March, Mr. Pohlad offered to buy Fibreboard, a wood products company based in Walnut Creek, Calif., for $42.50 a share, but that offer was also turned down. Mr. Pohlad's group acquired a 6.8 percent stake in the company last November and December and disclosed it would seek to buy Fibreboard in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In New York Stock Exchange trading, Fibreboard's stock closed yesterday unchanged at $38.

title: Clinton Taxes Laid Bare, Line by Line
description: It is a rite of spring in Washington for the White House to disclose the First Family's tax returns on this day, and typically the occasion is noted with little fanfare.

title: L.I.R.R. Chief Won't Resign Under Pressure
description: The president of the Long Island Rail Road said today that he has no plans to resign from his $145,000-a-year job, despite a harshly critical report issued Thursday on the railroad's shutdown in a snowstorm on Feb. 11.

title: El Paso Natural Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included net charge of $ 12 million, or 33 cents a share, stemming from litigation.

title: Wellfleet Communications Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
109 Nations Sign Trade Agreement
description: Culminating more than seven years of arduous and often bitter bargaining, ministers from 109 countries signed a far-reaching trade liberalization agreement today aimed at stimulating exports and slashing tariffs around the world.

title: Most Programs for Dyslexic Children Succeed; Sitting in the Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: Lance Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 19
description: b-After a charge of $ 378,000, or 1 cent a share, for effect of changes in accounting principles for income taxes and retiree health care benefits.

title: The Elegant Innovator
description: John Curry was to the world of figure skating what Rudolf Nureyev was to the world of ballet: an artist to some, an athlete to others.

title: Public & Private; Poetry Emotion
description: Yusef Komunyakaa won the Pulitzer Prize this week, but he does not expect to become a household name, and not because his name itself, phonetically simple once parsed out bit by bit, looks at first glance so unpronounceable. Mr. Komunyakaa won the prize for poetry, and there is little premium in poetry in a world that thinks of Pound and Whitman as a weight and a sampler, not an Ezra, a Walt, a thing of beauty, a joy forever.

title: Beijing Journal; A Dissident Finds the Political Prospects Bleak
description: Though the poplar trees are showing green along the capital's busy boulevards, for China's beleaguered democracy movement, there is no "Beijing spring."

title: Stickball, A Metaphor (2 Sewers!)
description: CHARLIE BALLARD is a retired salesman of millinery goods who lives in the Bronx, and John F. Stephens is a banker who lives in Scarsdale, but as spring wraps itself around asphalt weekends, the two men become what they have been for 46 years, stickball players and teammates.

title: Marriott International reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 25
description: Year-ago first quarter's net income and share earnings excluded the effect of adoption of SFAS 109.Year-ago figures are pro forma, as though the October 1993 spinoff from Marriott Corp. had occurred at the beginning of 1993.Marriott International said that on an historical basis, net income for the 1993 first quarter was $ 37 million before the cumulative effect of a required change in accounting for income taxes.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Diebold Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A 'Socially Responsible' Offering, and Others
description: "Socially responsible" investing is booming. Neuberger & Berman has started the Socially Responsive Fund, which aims for long-term capital growth by investing in companies that are leaders in environmental policy and workplace diversity and employment. The fund will not own companies with substantial revenues from alcohol, tobacco, gambling or weapons. Neuberger & Berman uses a value approach to investing, seeking companies with low stock prices.

title: United Carolina Bancshares Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 316,000, or 3 cents a share, for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for postemployment benefits.c-After a benefit of $ 867,000, or 6 cents a share, on a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for deferred income taxes.

title: Hunt (J.B.) Transport Services Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
White House Memo; Mitchell's Rebuff Touches Off Scramble for Court Nominee
description: White House officials who were astonished this week by Senator George J. Mitchell's decision to remove himself from consideration for the Supreme Court confess that they have started virtually from scratch to come up with a nominee. And they have all but abandoned hope that the process of finding a justice will be neat and quick.

title: Most Programs for Dyslexic Children Succeed; Fuzzy Classifications
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the musical life of Odessa, Ukraine, misstated the location of the city Kharkov. It is in Ukraine, not in central Russia.

title: Consumer Confidence Up
description: Consumer confidence rebounded in early April, indicating that rising interest rates are not curtailing people's spending plans.

title: U.S. Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge totaling $ 100 million, which represented the cost relating to U.S. Bancorp's recently announced restructuring program.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Michelangelo, C.E.O.
description: The unveiling of the refurbished "Last Judgment" in the Sistine Chapel calls to mind the phony image of Michelangelo, the lonely genius trapped between agony and ecstasy, isolated on his back on a scaffold, paintbrush in hand. In fact, he was on everybody else's back.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Boston Symphony Peter Serkin, Pianist Carnegie Hall

title: Swift Transportation Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago first quarter's share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in November 1993.

title: Genentech Says Profit Surged
description: The Genentech Corporation reported today that its first-quarter earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, driven by the sales of two new drugs, and sales growth in older drugs.

title: Holy Bull Workout a Blue Grass Surprise
description: The speed demon Holy Bull created something of a sensation this morning when he shot three furlongs in 34 seconds flat on the eve of the Blue Grass Stakes.

title: Molex Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,605,000, or 6 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Molex said that currency translation increased revenues by $ 4.6 million and net income by $ 700,000 in the latest third quarter. For the latest nine months, currency translation increased revenues by $ 8 million and net income by $ 1.7 million.

title: Giuliani Seeks Delay On Coliseum
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to delay a decision on the sale of the New York Coliseum by up to a month to grant time for an independent appraisal of the property to determine whether the developer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, is being asked to pay a fair price.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
Taking a Second Look at a Time-Share Vacation Home
description: George and Julia Church of Mariette, Ga. are satisfied owners of two time-share units, a much maligned vacation property concept. Many people have bought such units only to have maintenance expenses rise sky-high or to have trouble finding buyers when it comes time to sell.

title: Knicks Able to Back Up Foul Language
description: The Knicks' mouths got them in trouble last night, but a strong fourth quarter got them out of it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stanley Mays, Journalist, 73
description: Stanley Mays, a British journalist who worked in New York for foreign publications for more than 40 years, died on Tuesday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. Mr. Mays, who lived in Manhattan, was 73.

title: INSIDE
description: GATT Pact Is Signed

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CORRUPTION IN UNIFORM: ARRESTS AND ANGER IN A HARLEM PRECINCT

title: Review/Film; Proving Manhood by Hunting Men
description: "Surviving the Game" is a maladroit, racially inflammatory action film in which a homeless man named Jack Mason (Ice-T) is recruited to become the prey of wealthy hunters. With the exception of Cole, played by Charles S. Dutton (the star of television's "Roc"), the hunters are white and grotesquely evil. To give the film an unwanted campy edge, they also happen to sound like Iron John on steroids. "Allow yourself to feel the purity of your primal essence!" a scary Gary Busey declares.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Mia Chung Pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: Sports of The Times; Hen House Guarded By Foxes
description: YINKA Dare's journey from Africa to the United States originated in Kabba, Nigeria, wound up in Washington and was supposed to end in two more years with a degree from George Washington University and a shot at the National Basketball Association.

title: Hilgenberg Recovering
description: JAY HILGENBERG, the New Orleans Saints' 35-year-old backup center, has been hospitalized near Chicago for several days after an apparent heart attack and a subsequent angioplasty procedure to clear a blocked artery.

title: Tax Forms Are Done. Tax Traps Await.
description: From the amateur's perspective, investing is like ice skating: try to add a little spin and you may take a tumble. Managing your money well and then stretching too far to minimize taxes is a case in point.

title: DQE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Figures for the previous year have been reclassified to conform to 1994 presentation.

title: TCF Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Talk Radio Hosts Answer a Political Call
description: For years, radio talk shows have been sending messages to Congress. Now they are sending candidates.

title: War, Blockade and Poverty 'Strangling' Armenia
description: Two and a half years after its independence, this tiny Caucasus nation should be enjoying the excitement of new-found freedom. Instead, it is experiencing little but pain.

title: Blood, Bureaucracy and Grief Linked in Alien-Smuggling Case
description: For nearly seven months, a swab of dried blood from China has been sitting in storage at the New York City Medical Examiner's office. It was sent by the parents of a 38-year-old tractor driver from Fujian Province, Lin Guoshui, who was last seen diving from the tramp steamer Golden Venture into the frigid waters off Queens.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Musicians from Marlboro Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Washington Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February 1994.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'Tosca' Metropolitan Opera

title: Grant's Tomb Benches
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN MOBILE SATELLITE CORP., ., has signed a multiyear agreement with Landstar System Shelton, Conn., to provide satellite mobile data communications for 3,000 of its vehicles. IDB COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC., Culver City, Calif., said its IDB Systems unit had opened an office in Beijing to provide customer service, engineering support and marketing for its products.

title: Bobby Bonds Has Tests
description: The San Francisco Giants hitting coach BOBBY BONDS, the father of BARRY BONDS, remained hospitalized in Atlanta yesterday after complaining of dizziness and chest pains. Bonds, 48, was expected to undergo further tests today. (AP)

title: Q & A
description: Renting and Taxes Q. I recently retired and find my income tax bracket has dropped to 15 percent from 28 percent, thereby lessening the tax advantage of my condo mortgage interest and property taxes. Are there any other advantages I may have overlooked for continued home ownership versus renting? JOYCE A. BRUNO, Chatham, N.J.

title: In Greenwich, Small Is Beautiful; A Suburban Hospital Seeks to Retain Its Independence
description: At a time when most smaller hospitals are seeking to hitch up with larger medical centers to steer them through the turbulent waters of health care overhaul, administrators at Greenwich Hospital remain determined to pilot their own ship.

title: Grenada Sunburst System Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 781,000, or 8 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bridge
description: The death of Jim Becker on Tuesday will be mourned by thousands who knew him as a player of high rank, as the proprietor of one of the world's most active clubs, the Beverly, and as a talented teacher.

title: Pentair Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Potlatch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a $ 10 million, or 21 cents a share, pretax charge for early retirement programs. The company said income before the charge was $ 11.5 million, or 39 cents a share.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 31,704,000, or $ 1.09 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: A New Playoff Format Begets a Good, Old-Fashioned Matchup
description: This spring, it was supposed to be different, with a fresh formula for the Stanley Cup playoffs in the stuffy old National Hockey League. With expansion and a conference realignment, fans awaited exotic new matchups that could send Snowbelt teams to Sunbelt settings and New York franchises to venues more than a bus ride away.

title: Flowers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 12
U.S. Charges in Bankruptcy
description: Federal authorities filed criminal charges against the son of Sergio Bosco, the founder of Future Communications Inc., accusing him of interfering with the company's bankruptcy liquidation.

title: Review/Theater; Skin Rash and Other Rock-Star Problems
description: What is the poor leader and chief songwriter of a rock band to do when his group's two principal singers abruptly depart? This is the less-than-riveting dramatic crux of "Fallen Angel," a 90-minute show at Circle in the Square Downtown that bills itself as "a rock-and-roll play."

title: U.S. HELICOPTERS GIVEN NO WARNING BY ATTACKING JETS
description: The F-15 fighter pilots who mistakenly shot down two American Blackhawk helicopters over northern Iraq on Thursday gave no warning before firing because the rules of engagement in effect did not require it, the Pentagon said today.

title: Cancellation of Timber-Cutting Contract in Alaska May Cost Jobs
description: The company that lost its 50-year contract to cut timber at low prices in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska said it would decide within a week or two how many of its 400 yearround workers would keep their jobs.

title: Corrections
description: The Business Digest yesterday misstated the change in the Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday. The Dow rose 1.78 points to close at 3,663.25; it did not fall 1.78 points.

title: League-Leading Goalie Leading Test for Devils
description: Dominik Hasek was the name on the lips of every member of the Devils after today's practice here in preparation for their playoff series against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Crash Killed Top Officers In North Iraq
description: The Air Force missiles that downed the two Army helicopters over Iraq wiped out the entire leadership of a Western military field operation that has worked as a liaison to the Iraqi Kurds since the end of the Persian Gulf war.

title: King's Assassin Is Given Power Of Subpoena in Bid for Retrial
description: A Memphis Criminal Court judge ruled today that James Earl Ray, the confessed assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., would be allowed to subpoena witnesses in support of his assertions of innocence and his request for a new trial.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about newspapers' minority hiring rendered the name of an organization of news executives incorrectly. It is the Association of Minority Media Executives.

title: NBB Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Healthsouth Rehabilitation Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Healthsouth Rehabilitation attributed its increased revenues to its December 1993 acquisition of 28 hospitals and 45 outpatient facilities from National Medical Enterprises Inc.

title: Colonial BancGroup Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 1,160,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bronx Pediatrician Accused of Molesting Boys
description: A Bronx pediatrician was charged yesterday with sexually abusing two boys, one of them a 10-year-old patient, the police said.

title: Answers Needed on Iraq
description: "Clearly something went wrong," as Gen. John Shalikashvili put it, in the friendly-fire downing of two U.S. helicopters ferrying Turkish, British, French, Kurdish and American personnel across the exclusion zone in northern Iraq. The helicopters were reportedly en route to a meeting with Kurdish tribal elders to discuss responses to Iraqi military pressure in the area.

title: State Power Agency Picks Nuclear Chief From Texas Utility
description: The State Power Authority has hired William J. Cahill Jr., a well-known figure in the nuclear industry, to take charge of its troubled nuclear operations, authority officials said yesterday.

title:
INSURANCE;
Disability Policy Costs To Increase for Women
description: WOMEN who would like to buy a disability insurance policy still have time to act before new pricing models raise their costs.

title: AIR RAID REJECTED
description: Defying NATO and United Nations warnings, Serbian nationalist forces renewed their offensive against the Muslim enclave of Gorazde today, and were reported to be on the verge of overrunning it.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Sawdust Caesar
description: Even in an age addicted to revisionism, it is startling to read that Benito Mussolini is "the greatest statesman of the century." So says Gianfranco Fini, the youngish leader of Italy's resurgent neo-Fascist party, speaking to a Turin newspaper the other day. Still, Mr. Fini was not under oath, and yes, in some ways the Duce who ruled Italy from 1922 to 1943 did shape history.

title: WELLFLEET GAINS ON BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED EARNINGS
description: The shares of Wellfleet Communications rose 7 percent yesterday after the company posted better-than-expected third-quarter earnings late Thursday and declared a 2-for-1 stock split. Shares rose $5, to $70, in Nasdaq trading. Wellfleet's stock is to split, effective May 13, to shareholders of record on April 22. The split will be issued in the form of a common stock dividend. Wellfleet, based in Billerica, Mass., makes computer networking products.

title: U.S. Trust Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.The company said that net securities gains totaled $ 2 million in 1994 as various securities were classified as available for sale, mainly U.S. Government Treasury obligations, were sold. Net securities gains in the 1993 quarter were insignificant.

title: Scripps Howard Broadcasting (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 2.7 million, or 26 cents a share, for copyright fees owed upon resolution of dispute between the television industry and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Excluding the charge, the company had earnings of $ 13,027,000, or $ 1.00 a share.

title: Wilder Takes Small Step Toward Race for Senate
description: The Virginia Senate race, already a bizarre tangle of charges of lying, sexual misconduct and mental instability, took another confounding twist today when former Gov. L. Douglas Wilder sent a strong signal that he might jump in as an independent candidate.

title: So Far, U.S. Senate Race Is Mostly About Finances
description: Money was on everyone's mind today as the race for the United States Senate officially got underway in New Jersey.

title: Magic Johnson Won't Return
description: Magic Johnson will not return as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers next season, the team anounced before its 105-100 loss to the Portland Trail Blazers here tonight.

title: Beliefs
description: Future wars and global tensions will no longer be primarily based on conflicts between states but on clashing civilizations, those broad cultural entities defined by history, language, ethnicity and, above all, by religion.

title: Observer; Grandma Didn't Have One
description: There seems to be a controversy about Generation X. Some people of an age to qualify as Generation X'ers say there isn't any such thing, it's all a lot of magazine editor's hooey, also book editor's gaseous effusion. Others disagree.

title: Trains Collide At Low Speed, With 15 Hurt
description: A New Haven-bound commuter train with 19 passengers aboard went through a stop signal this morning and struck an oncoming commuter train in Old Saybrook, Amtrak officials said.

title: EMC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks Stay in Step The Atlanta Hawks remained in a tie with the Knicks for the Eastern Conference lead last night as Kevin Willis had 24 points and 18 rebounds and Danny Manning 23 points in a 105-96 victory over the Bucks in Milwaukee. The Bucks and Knicks are half a game ahead of the Chicago Bulls. Milwaukee and New York have five games remaining and Chicago has four. (AP)

title: Justice for Jurors
description: Organized interest groups like trial lawyers and podiatrists -- and assorted professional naysayers -- are likely to resist the streamlining proposed in a new report on New York State jury reform. Which is why the jury process remains so cumbersome and jury duty so often unpleasant. And why Gov. Mario Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature must push for overdue changes.

title: Redskins Appear Close To a Deal With Friesz
description: The Washington Redskins seem close to signing JOHN FRIESZ, the San Diego Chargers' backup quarterback and an unrestricted free agent. LEIGH STEINBERG, Friesz's agent, said yesterday that he and the Redskins were discussing a one-year contract worth $900,000 to $1 million. Steinberg said he expected an agreement by today.

title: John Curry, Figure Skater, Is Dead at 44
description: John Curry, the elegant 1976 Olympic champion who infused figure skating with the possibilities of dance, died yesterday of an AIDS-related heart attack, his agent said. Mr. Curry was 44.

title: Teco Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 11.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It would be difficult to determine who generated more comment at the Humanitarian Award Dinner given by the Elie Wiesel Foundation Thursday: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, recipient of the award, or her friend BARBRA STREISAND.

title: Ice-Pick Case Ignites New Debate Over Resisting Rapists
description: On the Barnard College campus yesterday, little more than a mile from where a 57-year-old woman used an ice pick to stab a man trying to rape her, Julia Johannsen had six words to describe the victim who turned on her attacker: "A hero for all of us."

title: A Bodega, A Bagman And a Sting
description: In late 1992, a former drug dealer and ex-convict came in from the streets and volunteered to work undercover for investigators seeking evidence of police corruption in New York City.

First Midwest Bancorp Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Wachovia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
National City Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Share figures reflected 2-for-1 stock split effective July 1993.The company reported after-tax security gains of 2 cents a share in the latest first quarter, compared with 1 cent a share for the year-ago period.

title: Trustmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Rural Retreat Journal; Store Closes, and a Way of Life Is Just a Memory
description: In a brick pharmacy in this hollow of the Blue Ridge Mountains, a former Confederate surgeon named Dr. Charles T. Pepper dispensed patent medicines in what was then fast becoming the "Cabbage Capital of the World." At least that's how the people of this hamlet saw it.

title: Rule Will Ban 'Paying to Play'
description: A Federal securities rule to prevent brokers from making political donations in exchange for municipal bond business will take effect on April 25.

title: Treasury Prices Mixed As Traders Mark Time
description: Treasury securities were mixed in sluggish trading yesterday as investors, uncertain of the Federal Reserve's next move, refrained from changing positions.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Holyfield-Lewis Set; Bigger Bouts Later
description: While Riddick Bowe prepares for summer camp and Mike Tyson gets ready for summer school, Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis have agreed to meet in a November showdown to unify the world's heavyweight title.

title: U.S. Policies Under Siege
description: The latest Serb offensive against the Muslim town of Gorazde is a setback for the Clinton Administration's strategy that the limited use of NATO air power would persuade the Serbs to back down on the battlefield and make peace.

title: After Early Struggles, Perez Gets a Passing Grade
description: It was only Melido Perez's second start and it is only April, but tonight was a monumental test for him. The Yankees gave him a lead, he gave it back to the Tigers. The Yankees tied the game, he allowed the Tigers to take the lead again. Then the Yankees burst ahead one more time and Perez knew he had to throttle the Tigers. He had to pass the test.

title: Ojeda Eager to Answer Call
description: Bob Ojeda will make his pitching debut with the Yankees on Saturday afternoon, continuing a comeback that began last season with Cleveland after he survived a boating accident that killed two of his Indian teammates 13 months ago.

title: Uncharted Change at the N.A.A.C.P.
description: Who is Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. and what in the world is he is trying to do to the venerable National Association for the Advancement of Colored People?

title: Army Contract to G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has received a $671.3 million Army order for engines used by Blackhawk and Apache helicopters, as well as engines used by Navy transport helicopters.

title: Brazil in an Accord With Large Banks On Cutting Its Debt
description: Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, completed an agreement last night with its creditor banks that reduces its $49 billion foreign debt and provides the country with lower interest rates and new longer-term loans.

title: No Headline
description: These police officers have stained the honor of the vast majority of police officers who daily serve the people of our city with great dedication, integrity and distinction. -- JUDGE MILTON MOLLEN [ 1:6. ]

title: BancorpSouth (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 3.2 milion, or 42 cents a share, reflecting gain related to cumulative effect for change in accounting for income taxes.

description: National Commerce Bancorp said that the improved performance for the latest quarter was due primarily to an improvement in net interest earnings, contributions from fee-generating areas and a decrease in the provision for loan losses.

title: First Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Review/Music; Electronic Sounds Evoke Earth, Sky and Humanity
description: Electronic music no longer has the cachet it once had, offering composers liberation from mundane human practitioners and overly familiar instruments. But Morton Subotnick, at the age of 61, can still produce fresh effects with his electronic and computer-generated sounds, creating worlds in which the human and the electronic merge.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: 'Otello' Metropolitan Opera

title: On Front Line of the Drug Wars, Police Corruption Is Nothing New
description: A 27-year-old man, buoyed by the good weather, was walking his black Doberman pinscher past the 30th Precinct station house in Harlem yesterday when an angry voice broke his reverie.

title: Upjohn Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included nonrecurring gain of 7 cents a share on the sale of the Orthoxicol trademark, income from discontinued operations of $ 920,000, or 1 cent a share, and after a charge of $ 18,906,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago first quarter was restated to reflect the discontinued operations and the adoption of FASB 112.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: FirsTier Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a pretax expense of $ 2.85 million for litigation settlement.

title: HARRIS OF CHICAGO TO BUY SUBURBAN BANCORP
description: Harris Bankcorp, the Chicago-based unit of Bank of Montreal, signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Suburban Bancorp of Palatine, Ill., in a stock swap valued at about $246 million. Under the transaction, each share of Suburban Bancorp will be exchanged for 3.9352 shares of Bank of Montreal. The transaction values Suburban's shares at about $73 each. The Gerald F. Fitzgerald family, which owns a majority of Suburban's shares, has agreed to vote in favor of the transaction, Bank of Montreal said. Suburban's shares were up $1 at $49.50 in Nasdaq trading. Suburban Bancorp has 30 branches in metropolitan Chicago and $1.36 billion in assets.

title: Starks Recovering Rapidly
description: The Knicks announced yesterday that they hoped to have their All-Star shooting guard, John Starks, ready for the first round of the playoffs, and Starks insisted last night that he would "definitely be back" for them. Starks underwent successful arthroscopic surgery on his left knee on March 14, and his recovery has been more rapid than expected. It was originally thought he would miss six to eight weeks.

title: ALC Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of about $ 800,000, or 2 cents a share, from the resolution of a state telecommunications excise tax issue.c-After a benefit of $ 13.5 million, or 38 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Boise Cascade Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: During the first quarter of 1993, the company sold its interest in a specialty paper producer at a pretax gain of $ 8,644,000, or 14 cents per fully diluted common share, after taxes.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing cigarette companies and their brands misstated the parent company of the Liggett Group Inc. It is the Brooke Group Ltd., not Metropolitan P.L.C. On the same page, a list of company executives who testified on Thursday at a Congressional hearing on the hazards of smoking misspelled the surname of one executive and rendered the name of his company incorrectly. He is Thomas Sandefur Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation.

title: Dow Off 1.78 as Trading Continues on Light Side
description: In trading distorted by the "double witching hour," the stock market zigzagged a lot yesterday but closed essentially unchanged.

title: The Chicago Board of Trade Will Leave Globex Network
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would pull out of Globex, the slowly expanding global electronic trading network for futures and options that it began nearly two years ago with its neighbor and longtime rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Wednesday of the winners of the Pulitzer Prizes misstated the background of Jim Mitzelfeld, who won a prize for beat reporting at The Detroit News. When he left The News last year to attend law school, he had spent nine years as a reporter, not three years; five of them were at The News.

title: New CMS Power Plant
description: The CMS Energy Corporation's CMS Generation Company subsidiary has begun construction of a 35-megawatt wood-burning power plant near Flint, Mich. The $90 million Genesee Power Station, which is intended to burn up to 175,000 tons of recycled waste wood a year, is 50 percent owned by CMS Generation. The remainder is owned by the Black & Veatch Power Development Corporation and the Genesee Power Company. The plant will sell its entire output to the Consumers Power Company, which is Michigan's largest utility and a CMS Energy unit.

title: Industrial Output Up 0.5%, 10th Straight Monthly Gain
description: Production at America's factories, mines and utilities advanced five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the 10th consecutive monthly gain, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Isn't It Time for a Searching Look at Taxi Commission Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin and Ukraine's Chief In Pact on Black Sea Fleet
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine reached a new agreement today on the division of the much-disputed Black Sea Fleet. The announcement of the accord came at the end of a week in which the two-year quarrel threatened for the first time to lead to armed conflict.

title: Speeches Pay for Cuomos; Whitmans Need Extension
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made an average of $17,583 for each of 12 speaking engagements in 1993, a slight decrease from 1992 but still enough to insure that he received far more income for speaking than he did for governing New York State, according to tax returns made available yesterday.

title: Trade Talks Up to Japan, U.S. Says
description: Senior American and Japanese officials said today that they hoped to resume crucial trade talks before the meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in July, but American officials insisted that "the ball is still in the Japanese court."

title: Grainger (W.W.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 820,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Sherwin Williams Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Chronicle
description: JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS, who has a treatable form of lymphatic cancer, is undergoing treatment at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, a hospital spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: AKZO NOBEL SELLS DUTCH CHEMICALS UNIT TO ALLIED SIGNAL
description: Akzo Nobel N.V. said yesterday that it had sold its Dutch fluor chemicals plant to Allied Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J., for an undisclosed amount. The plant, based in the southeastern Dutch town of Weert, produces hydrogen fluoride and chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's. Its 70 employees will now become part of Allied Signal's work force. Allied Signal is already a global market leader in the production of hydrogen fluoride and CFC substitutes. Akzo Nobel, a leading international chemical company, said fluor chemical activities no longer formed part of its key operations.

title: A.M.A. Errs in Tie-In With Nutrition Chain
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy Worries Tax Authorities
description: The attorneys general for five states and lawyers for some local taxing authorities have asked Cyrus R. Vance, the court-appointed mediator assigned to oversee R. H. Macy & Company's bankruptcy case, to take note of their interests.

title: A Sideshow to Macy Case: Lawyers' Letters of Vitriol
description: What was once a behind-the-scenes feud between two lawyers with leading roles in R. H. Macy & Company's bankruptcy case has evolved into a very rare public sideshow.

title: Mismatch: Mets' Kent Can't Do It This Time
description: Offensively, the Mets' first sign of life against the Houston Astros last night came in the bottom of the seventh inning when second baseman Jeff Kent smashed a 3-2 pitch over the wall in left field at Shea Stadium.

title: HON Industries(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-After an accounting charge of $ 237,000, or 1 cent a share, reflecting postretirement.c-After an accounting benefit of $ 489,000, or 2 cents a share, reflecting income taxes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 NO WARNING TO HELICOPTERS

title: 12 POLICE OFFICERS CHARGED IN DRUG CORRUPTION SWEEP; BRATTON SEES MORE ARRESTS
description: Twelve New York City police officers were charged yesterday with forcing drug dealers to pay them protection money to operate on the streets of Harlem. They beat up some dealers who would not cooperate, investigators said, and stole hundreds of thousands of dollars in drugs and cash from others.

title: CCB Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,371,000, or 17 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.

title: VCR Standards Drawn Up To Use Digital Technology
description: Paving the way for the next generation of videocassette recorders, a committee representing 50 electronics companies from around the world has agreed on a proposed standard for VCR's that will use digital technology.

title: Dover Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Turkey Battles Terrorists, Not Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: Roosevelt Financial Group (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,483,000, or 25 cents a share, from the repurchase of mortgage-backed bonds.

title: Citizens Banking (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a $ 1.5 million pretax charge as a result of losses in National Bank of Royal Oak's travel banking product line. Excluding the charge, income was $ 7,184,000, or 50 cents a share.Share and per share information has been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1993.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on April 6 about Maj. Gen. Aharon Remez, the first commander of the Israeli Air Force, misstated two details of his career. It was his father, David Remez, not General Remez, who was a member of the Israeli Parliament and Minister of Transport.

title: Howard University Postponed Lecture by a Jewish Historian
description: Fearing that a visiting professor from Yale would be subjected to heckling and harassment because he is Jewish, Howard University postponed a lecture he had been scheduled to give earlier this month, university officials said today.

title: Dance Magazine Awards
description: The winners of the 37th annual Dance Magazine Awards, given for excellence in dance, are Christine Dakin of the Martha Graham Dance Company, Kate Johnson of the White Oak Dance Project and Jiri Kylian, the choreographer and the director of the Netherlands Dance Theater. The awards will be given in a private ceremony on April 25 at Asia Society.

title: Glatfelter (P.H.) Co.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss, which was after extraordinary charges of $ 8,430,000, or 19 cents a share, that included pretax gains of $ 1,492,000 from disposal of Ecusta division's airplane and $ 1,642,000 from updating of estimates relating to SFAS 106. Period also included pretax charge of $ 16,363,000 from ''rightsizing'' and restructuring, and after a charge of $ 4,193,000, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Becoming Artists the Old-Fashioned Way
description: Life drawing, once the art student's entrance ticket to the mythical world of canvas and paint, of chisel and stone, of masterpieces scribbled feverishly on napkins, of berets, garrets, mistresses, poverty, drugs, wine, death and, ultimately, fame, is now an entrance to -- well, no one seems to be sure anymore, but probably something bleak, like painting portraits of corporate executives for a living. Certainly it is no longer an entrance to anything very fashionable, or, in the opinion of many, artistically credible.

title: What if the Dentist Didn't Do It?
description: On March 29, 1990, Dr. David Acer gave a sample of his blood to an investigator from the Federal Centers for Disease Control. Dr. Acer had quit practicing dentistry eight months earlier and was dying of AIDS; the investigator went to his home in Stuart, Fla., to tell him that a former patient had AIDS but no apparent risk factors for contracting the virus that causes it. The centers, she explained, wanted a blood sample to see if the genetic strain of his virus matched the patient's.

title: Court Asked To Reinstate Rape Counts
description: Acting as special prosecutor in a contentious rape case, State Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell asked a court here today to reinstate charges against five men who admitted having sex with a woman who had passed out in an upstate restaurant.

title: Bush Criticizes Caning but Likes Singapore
description: Former President George Bush said today that he regarded caning as a "brutal" punishment, but suggested that public criticism of Singapore over its plan to flog an American teen-ager would be counterproductive.

title: LaSalle National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: LaSalle National, a unit of ABN-Amro Holding N.V., said that the 1994 first quarter increase in net income was due to growth in net interest income and in processing fees for trusts, deposits and affiliates. The increases were partly offset by increased loan loss provisions. The company also noted that the 1993 first quarter results were hurt by securities losses.

title: E-Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: E-Systems said that the earnings per share were calculated with the average shares outstanding and the effect of dilutive options outstanding.

title: The Elegant Innovator
description: John Curry was to the world of figure skating what Rudolf Nureyev was to the world of ballet: an artist to some, an athlete to others.

title: Most Programs for Dyslexic Children Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Partnership Stigma And Equipment Leasing
description: BOB VORLOP has a plan. He wants to buy computer equipment, lease it to businesses and then resell it. He has ideas for dealing with the risks -- avoiding mainframes that can become obsolete quickly, buying mostly I.B.M. products because their maintenance policy means good resale prices. If all goes well, he will turn a handy profit -- especially if the economy continues to grow.

title: A Deepening of Losses at Digital Equipment
description: Last June, when Digital Equipment's president and chief executive, Robert B. Palmer, and several of his top lieutenants presented their reorganization plans for the beleaguered company, the board of directors stood and applauded. The optimism was stoked a few weeks later, when the computer maker reported its first profitable quarter in several years.

title: Carlo Bergonzi Will Define 'Retirement' as He Wishes
description: Retirement for an opera singer means an end to instant recognition, stage-door groupies, recording projects, the pleasure of filling a theater with one's voice and the thrill of standing center stage and receiving cheers from packed houses.

title: Bill Winfrey; Hall of Fame Horse Trainer
description: Bill Winfrey, a trainer of thoroughbreds including Native Dancer and a host of other champions, died on Thursday in a hospital at Lake Forest, Calif. A resident of San Clemente, Calif., he was 77.

title: Solomon Hoberman, New York City Administrator, 79
description: Solomon Hoberman, who served as New York City's director of personnel and chairman of its Civil Service Commission from 1967 to 1970, died on Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Hoberman, who lived in Manhattan, was 79.

title: Weis Narkets Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: b-Included a $ 830,000 gain on the sale of an abandoned store.

title: The Biggest Yields in Money Market Funds: Where to Find Them
description: After taking a beating in stocks and bonds in the first quarter, many investors are letting their cash idle in money market mutual funds, especially the tax-free variety. But the smart money is landing in taxable funds.

title: Comsat Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 1.3 million, or 3 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Democrats Need Money and a Message to Rebuild
description: The last time the New Jersey Democratic Party lost the governorship and both chambers of the Legislature, the telephone company threatened to pull out the phones and the party's headquarters building had to be sold.

title: Hold the Polo
description: Charles Walker Jr. doesn't play polo. Neither do most of the young men and women, including black Americans like him, who at one time or another have made Ralph Lauren's Polo gear and Tommy Hilfiger clothing part of their daily wardrobes.

title: Constructive Criticism
description: WHAT IS ARCHITECTURE? An Essay on Landscapes, Buildings, and Machines. By Paul Shepheard. Illustrated. 131 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $9.95.

title:
THE DRESSING ROOM;
The Science of Beauty
description: Recently, a spate of scientific articles has appeared on the subject of beauty. Evolutionary biologists, anthropologists and evolutionary psychologists, it seems, are hot on the trail of proof that there are geometric features in a woman's face that may be universally perceived as beautiful, and that a man's ability to perceive this beauty and appreciate it may be a matter of natural selection.

title: The Bottom Line on Banks
description: APRIL Tyler opened an interest-bearing checking account at Chemical Bank eight years ago, and now has thousands of dollars in an individual retirement account there, too. But the relationship took a nose dive last month when Chemical announced that it was closing 50 branches, doubling the minimum balance required for "free checking" and sharply increasing fees for checking accounts that fail to make the cutoff.

title: April 10-16: A Study of Risks; Breast Cancer Near Chemical Sites
description: A report by the New York State Health Department appeared to lend weight to a growing belief among breast cancer activists that the environment, along with personal risk factors, could be responsible for the high rate of breast cancer on Long Island. But it stopped short of making a direct causal connection between factory emissions and breast cancer.

title: Onetime Darling Of French Artists
description: A HUNDRED YEARS AGO, PEOPLE all over France were awed and impressed by the gigantic historico-religious murals of Pierre Puvis de Chavannes. And when Puvis showed the nine muses levitating, or lolling around in white shifts and doing nothing in particular, the public was captured, just as it is captured today by a Kurosawa movie or a daylong interpretation by Peter Brook of an Indian epic poem.

title: Footprints on the Infobahn
description: Say the word footprint, and I immediately think of the Abominable Snowman of the Himalayas. Does this prepare me for a nanosecondary grasp of computer lingo? Not yeti; a generation of hackers, confronted with the old word footprint, thinks first of its latest sense, "the desk space taken up by a computer."

title: Sports of the Times; Jim Rome Didn't Just Happen
description: When I got back from Norway, I received dozens and dozens of letters from bright Times readers who had been captivated by the Tonya-Nancy-Oksana Frolics, but many of the readers also complained about the fragmentation of the events on television.

title:
In the Region/New Jersey;
Trenton Acts to Revive a Once-Vital Industrial Base
description: HUGGING Route 1 in the northern part of Trenton are 47 gritty acres that the city hopes to transform into the keystone of a revival of its once-thriving industrial sector.

title: Haiti's Agony, Clinton's Shame
description: It is deeply troubling that, just as the United States becomes the world's sole superpower, we have a President who has neither an aptitude for foreign policy nor interest in it. And since Bill Clinton has no deep convictions regarding America's new role in the world, he often seems incapable of seeing the broad significance of the challenges before him.

title: Charlie Goldstein, Power Broker
description: Charlie Goldstein sells sport coats. But not just any sport coats. Not in just any store. Not to just anybody. Mr. Goldstein is a salesman for Brooks Brothers. Third floor. Sport coats, slacks and formal wear.

title: Police Go After Drug Commuters Who Now Use Buses and Trains
description: FOR about 18 months, the police in New York have been cracking down on people who drive into Manhattan to make drug purchases and then head back home to the suburbs. Officers have not only arrested people as suspected drug buyers but also seized dozens of cars, most of which have turned out to be registered in New Jersey.

title: More Tours of Frank Lloyd Wright's Home
description: Taliesin, the former Wisconsin home of Frank Lloyd Wright, whose work is currently the subject of a major retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, will expand its roster of guided tours from three to five this year. The 600-acre estate, situated in the hills of Spring Green, will be open to visitors from May 1 until Nov. 1.

title: Diana Rigg Is A Chilly, Elegant Medea
description: LET'S FACE IT: MEDEA, THOUGH grievously wronged by her husband, Jason, is not exactly your prototypical battered wife. She's the daughter of the king of Colchis, the granddaughter of the sun, a wife, a witch, a mother, a primeval terror in her own right. Medea is not a woman to be easily characterized. "I am adept at everything that's hidden," she boasts to the women of Corinth. She then goes on to commit atrocities that astonish even her. To play her mostly as victim is to humble one of world literature's most titanic creations.

title: Holocaust Memories Make the Serbs Fear Their Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Ashes; More Derelict Factories Are Returning to Productive Use
description: From the outside, it looks like one more decrepit multi-story brick factory building left for dead. The inside, however, is alive with the sound of screaming band saws and the smell of fresh sawdust. The former 19th-century rope factory on the Brooklyn waterfront in Greenpoint has been broken up into dozens of smaller spaces for woodworking shops and artisans.

title: Oh, How the Critics Raved. Why Didn't the Masses Follow?
description: FROM THE STAGE OF THE Bottom Line in Manhattan, Marshall Crenshaw peered out at the audience and introduced his next song. "I wrote this one about a year and a half ago," he said, "and then I decided to rest on my laurels."

title: The Satirist Who Landed in a Sitcom
description: IN MAY 1993 DAVE THOMAS, formerly of the brilliant "Second City Television" comedy troupe, appeared on NBC's 90th birthday tribute to Bob Hope. During that three-hour "parade of stars," a tuxedoed Mr. Thomas (whose turn came just after Lucie Arnaz and just before Brooke Shields) was introduced as "Chester Hope, Bob's nephew." He did a gently satirical version of Mr. Hope's standup style. Then, dropping out of character, he praised Mr. Hope as "the guy everybody acknowledges as the best."

title: Brazil Reaches Accord With Large Banks to Cut Debt
description: Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, completed an agreement last night with its creditor banks that reduces its $49 billion foreign debt and provides the country with lower interest rates and new longer-term loans.

title:
ON LOCATION;
Does a Bird Have ---- ? Fanciers Seem to Think So
description: JUST another night at the Masonic Temple in Amityville. Parrots everywhere. Parrots on people's heads. Parrots on people's shoulders.

title: Gaining Insight Through Invisibility
description: Excerpts from "Invisible Man," by Ralph Waldo Ellison (Random House, 1952):

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING SPRING

title: Thomas Likes High Intensity of Rangers-Isles After High-Water Year
description: Steve Thomas of the Islanders has much in common with Adam Graves of the Rangers. Both led their teams in goals, Thomas with 42, Graves with 52. Both play on the wing of the top forward line alongside star centers. Thomas skates to the right of Pierre Turgeon, Graves to the left of Mark Messier.

title: Weddings; Leslie Farrow, David Hutchinson
description: Leslie Ann Farrow, the daughter of John Farrow of Ellington, Conn., and Sandra Farrow of East Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Travis Hutchinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Travis Hutchinson of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Sidat Balgobin performed the Congregational ceremony at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Elisabeth Israels Perry;
Women's History as a Continuing Study
description: ELISABETH ISRAELS PERRY became interested in women's history because she wanted to find out more about her grandmother, Belle Moskowitz, who had run Alfred E. Smith's campaigns for Governor and President in the 1920's. Professor Perry had never met her grandmother but had heard that she had made it in a man's world only by being "an honorary man."
