And for the next nine and a half hours, faces of all kinds pass in front of the four panes of bulletproof glass at Roebling Check Cashing -- black, Hispanic, Hasidic, male, but mostly female, with children placed on countertops.

title: Jones: A Man After His Own Heart?
description: Twelve college football seniors eagerly anticipating the 1994 National Football League draft gathered one night last week in a hotel suite here with Dallas Cowboys coaches and other team officials. Next Sunday, when the N.F.L. draft begins, these prize players, each likely early round picks, will learn where their pro careers will unfold and which team's colors they will proudly wear.

title: Insurance Law Shift Is Gaining
description: A proposal to overhaul a 49-year-old Federal law shielding the insurance industry from antitrust rules has been endorsed by large insurance companies and one of their longtime Congressional critics.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALICE WALKER , who was named a California "state treasure" last month for her literature, is horrified at the award statuette: a foot-tall sculpture of a woman's torso, without arms, legs or head.

title: In Co-ops and Condos, Apartment Managers Are Girding for a Possible Strike
description: As negotiators met yesterday to discuss a new contract for unionized doormen, porters, elevator operators and other building workers, apartment managers made preparations for a possible strike beginning as early as midnight Wednesday.

title: Myths of the Midnight Rider
description: Today is Patriot's Day, the anniversary of Paul Revere's Ride in 1775. Every American has heard the story of that event; it is one of the shared memories that make us one people, diverse as we may be. But we haven't all remembered it the same way.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Giuliani Meets With G.O.P. To Break Albany Deadlock
description: With talks on a new state budget still deadlocked in Albany, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met yesterday with Republican members of the State Senate to try to persuade them to support Democratic proposals that would help New York City.

title: A van Gogh Becomes a Cause Celebre
description: Even though repeatedly rebuffed by the Culture Ministry, Jacques Walter kept lobbying throughout the 1980's for permission to take his van Gogh painting, "Garden at Auvers," out of France, first to hang it in his Geneva home, later to sell it for a better price than it would fetch here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Dr. Marcel Bessis French Biologist, 76
description: Dr. Marcel Bessis, a French physician who was applauded in the United States 30 years ago for his role in developing instruments and techniques for studying portions of single live cells, died on March 28 in Paris. He was 76 and lived in Paris.

title: Holy Bull's Front-Running A Dilemma for Derby Foes
description: So, who can catch Holy Bull in the Kentucky Derby?

title: Business Shuns Areas That Look Too White
description: The offer was sweeter than a bushel of Iowa roasting ears: $25 million in incentives to a Maryland biotechnology company if it would flee the nerve-rattling East Coast and settle here in America's heartland -- fresh air, quiet streets, smiling faces.

title: Frayed Knicks Continue to Unravel in Loss
description: It was an alarming loss for the suddenly vulnerable Knicks. And after it ended, Coach Pat Riley showed more concern than at any other time this season.

title: A New Ford in California's Future
description: Californians beset by fires, earthquakes, recessions and riots received one glowing omen last week: Gerald J. Ford, known for his sensitivity to sweet deals and impending turnarounds, is moving to their state.

title: Waco Inferno Remembered By Davidians
description: Though most of Waco was otherwise occupied, rock music blared from loudspeakers and vendors hawked religious tracts under colorful tents today as nearly 300 people gathered at the site of the Branch Davidian compound nearly one year after the fire that destroyed it.

title: Review/Theater; Dreamers and Exploiters in a Slice of Americana
description: Before Baby Jessica, there was Floyd Collins. On Jan. 30, 1925, Collins went exploring underground in Barren County, Ky., looking for a cavern that could be turned into a tourist attraction. Trapped by a fallen rock, he could still speak to the outside world. A cub reporter from The Louisville Courier-Journal climbed down to interview Collins and started an avalanche of press coverage, making the buried man a national obsession and drawing 20,000 curiosity seekers and hustlers to the site. The hoopla didn't save Collins, who died after two weeks underground.

title: Dance in Review
description: Homer Avila and Edisa Weeks Dia Center for the Arts SoHo

title: Abroad at Home; Peace At Any Price
description: Truman! thou shouldst be living at this hour.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The weather was dreadful the other day when MARK E. TALISMAN transported a 300-year-old Torah from Washington to the United States Military Academy at West Point, but the flight, he said, was smooth.

title: Foreign Debt Mop-Up; After Refinancing Brazil, Banks Now Face Just a Few Small Bad International Loans
description: Last week's refinancing agreement between Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, and its foreign creditors allowed bankers to trumpet what many had been saying more quietly for years: The international debt crisis is over.

title: Don't Need to Be a Rock Star to Feel Suicidal; My Sensitive Son
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Growing Support, New Laws On Smoking Are Unlikely This Year
description: The momentum is building, no doubt about it. But the time does not seem to be ripe this year for new Federal laws or regulations that would sharply curtail the use of tobacco.

title: A Mustang and a Boy Named Bill
description: CONCORD, N.C., April 17

title: Hungary and the Jews: Looking at 1944 Is Difficult
description: Just before the mass deportation of Jews from Hungary to death camps 50 years ago this spring, a young Protestant minister arrived for a clandestine meeting in a cafe here. He left his battered suitcase slightly open on a chair beside him and watched as a courier dropped a 30-page account of the workings of Auschwitz inside.

title: Topics of The Times; Listening Critically
description: We have all heard about those characters who stroll into police departments and confess to any crime that has not already been claimed. Editors are a little like that when they get together. At least they have a tendency to listen politely to any bill of particulars.

title: Motorola Offers a New Chip
description: Motorola Inc. will introduce today the latest generation in its 68000 line of microprocessors, which is best known as the chip at the heart of Apple Computer's Macintosh. Motorola said the new chip, the 68060, maintained software compatibility with the current 68040 and was about three times as fast as the older chip.

title: Mini-Series Blazes Trail In High-Definition TV
description: When "World War II: When Lions Roared" is broadcast on NBC tomorrow and Wednesday nights, it will be a technological first for a mini-series. The four-hour production is the first significant American foray into high-definition television.

title: Moscow Embarrassed When Serbs Make, and Break, Promise of Pullback
description: The Russians were embarrassed today when their power to put pressure on the Serbs in Bosnia proved to be as feeble as everyone else's, underlining the weakness of their claim of influence over their Slavic brothers.

title: Bulls Go Backward In Fight for Top Spot
description: Magic 118, Bulls 101

title: Nets Clinch Fittingly: Anderson and a Rally
description: Before the game today against the Miami Heat, Nets Coach Chuck Daly thought back to early in the season, when his club was 13-20 "and ready to go into the dike," as he called it. Three hours later, the Nets' turnaround was officially complete.

title: Bridge
description: How well extraterrestrials play bridge is a subject that receives little attention, perhaps understandably. The only evidence comes from Warren Dix of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, who reports occasionally on the appearance of some Little Green Men wearing metallized jump suits at a duplicate game at the French Bridge Club in Athens.

title: Cairo Journal; Battling the Religious Right: The Celluloid Front
description: A tourist bus is raked with automatic fire. A video shop is firebombed. A Christian jewelry store is robbed, and a police official assassinated.

title: INSIDE
description: A Precinct in Crisis

title: Yankees Survive Both Gusty Winds and Porous Defense
description: There were snippets of today's game against the Tigers that the Yankees would not offer for an instructional video on baseball fundamentals. The early mishaps and miscues, some of them caused by a vicious, swirling wind, would have been perfect for "America's Funniest Home Videos."

title: Don't Need to Be a Rock Star to Feel Suicidal
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Senators Renew Call To Lift Bosnian Arms Ban
description: On a bewildering and confusing day for the Clinton Administration, several influential senators today renewed their call to allow the Bosnian Muslims to obtain weapons by lifting a United Nations arms embargo if diplomatic efforts to end the fighting fail.

title: Topics of The Times; No April Gushing, Next Year
description: Writers for editorial pages -- not to mention the hapless readers -- know the dangers of April. The abrupt vernal glory of the fourth month annually brings a flood of fatuous nature writing. Only October comes close to competing with April as an inspirer of seasonal tributes, and April's spell is stronger. This is a month, after all, that has caused editorial writers to render into a cliche the opening lines of one of the great poems of the century. Were he living, poor Eliot might have thought his literary effort wasted indeed.

title: Review/Pop; Going With the Flow at a Party With Phish
description: A show by Phish is unmistakably a pop-music party. At the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night, the opening show of a three-day, sold-out stand, the auditorium was packed with smoke, legal and illegal, and the audience swayed under the influence of the music and other things.

title: Essay; Reds Under the Bed
description: In the wake of charges that a high C.I.A. official was a Russian "mole," an old question is being newly raised: how deeply did the Soviet Union penetrate the American Government?

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MISSING BABY REPORT REVEALED AS HOAX

title: In Brazil, Help From Viewers On TV Ad
description: In November, W/Brasil, the fourth-largest Brazilian advertising agency, and its high-powered client, Unibanco, had a sticky problem.

title: Compaq's New Line
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, in a move likely to intensify competition in the lucrative corporate market for personal computers, will introduce today a new line of premium PC's priced hundreds of dollars lower than the models that they will replace.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Irwin Holds Off Norman in Heritage Hale Irwin, who nearly ruined his chances at the sixth hole, recovered with a three-under-par 68 yesterday for a record-setting victory in the Heritage Classic at Hilton Head, S.C. The 48-year-old PGA Tour veteran finished with a record 18-under 266 at Harbour Town Golf Links, two strokes ahead of Greg Norman. Norman, who led Irwin by three strokes with 11 holes left, closed with 13 straight pars for a 68 and 268. (AP) Women's Championship to Skinner: Val Skinner birdied five holes and closed with a four-under-par 68 to win the L.P.G.A. Women's Championship by one stroke over Liselotte Neumann at the Eagle's Landing Country Club in Stockbridge, Ga. Skinner completed the three rounds in 10-under 206. (AP) TENNIS Courier Takes Surprising Tumble Alberto Berasategui upset Jim Courier in the final of the Philips Open, 6-4, 6-2, in Nice, France. The 20-year-old Spaniard, ranked No. 34, broke for a 3-2 lead in the first set and saved two break points at 5-4 before winning the set. Both players had two matches in one day. Berasategui struggled past Slava Dosedel, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, in a rain-delayed semifinal, and Jim Courier defeated Marc Rosset, 6-0, 6-3. (Reuters) MARATHON Ceron Wins 4th Straight in London Dionicio Ceron of Mexico won his fourth straight marathon, capturing the London race yesterday under gusty conditions in 2 hours 8 minutes 53 seconds. Ceron won last year in Rotterdam, the Netherlands; Mexico City, and Fukuoka, Japan. (AP) HOCKEY Canadian Women Beat U.S. in Final In a matchup of unbeaten teams, Canada defeated the United States, 6-3, yesterday in the title game of the women's world hockey championships at Lake Placid, N.Y. Canada also defeated the Americans in the previous two world tournaments, at Ottawa in 1990 and at Helsinki in 1992. TRACK AND FIELD Lewis and Teammates Break Record Carl Lewis and his Santa Monica Track Club teammates rewrote their world record in the 800-meter relay yesterday at the Mount San Antonio College Relays in Walnut, Calif. Lewis ran the anchor leg on the team with Mike Marsh, Leroy Burrell and Floyd Heard. They were timed in 1 minute 18.68 seconds, bettering the mark of 1:19.11 set by the same four April 25, 1992. (AP)

title: Ode to Joy: Mighty Jeffrey At the Bat
description: His last name makes it too easy to characterize how he is hitting by substituting Clark for his first name. But Jeff Kent would be far more comfortable being the Invisible Man than Superman.

title: Penske's Engine Has Opponents Singing Brickyard Blues
description: When Andy Granatelli whooshed into the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in 1967 with a turbine-powered car that outran the competition, the protests of other car owners could not obscure this: The car was legal, and Granatelli was the only man with the vision and resources to take advantage of a small opening in the rules.

title: Trevino Defeats Floyd, Who Falls Apart in Stretch
description: If Raymond Floyd isn't absolutely the last golfer one would expect to see fly apart like a cardboard suitcase, he is at least in the final foursome. Throughout his career, Floyd has always been regarded as the front-runner's front-runner. When he took the lead in a golf tournament, the theory went, it would be easier to loosen a sirloin from a pit bull's mandible than snatch the victory from Floyd's grasp.

title: Dance in Review
description: The Joffrey Ballet New York State Theater

title: In Shaken Police Precinct, a Somber Time
description: In the last three days, they have seen fellow police officers carted off in handcuffs, they have been razzed by residents in their Harlem neighborhood, they have been dressed down by their Commissioner, and their captain has been stripped of his command.

title: GORAZDE IN PANIC AS SERBIAN FORCES ENTER 'SAFE' AREA
description: Panic erupted among the trapped residents of Gorazde today as Bosnian Serb forces entered the United Nations-declared "safe area" with a tank and as artillery and snipers took aim at people who were unable to find shelter.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Balance of Trade . . . Feb. Wednesday Housing Starts . . . March Thursday Weekly Jobless Claims Friday None

title: Jurors Find L.I. Murder Case Easy to Resist
description: Some prospective jurors said they did not want to serve on the jury in the Joel Rifkin case because they already thought he was guilty in the serial killings of several women.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'Goodbye and Good Luck' Neta Pulvermacher and Dancers Dance Theater Workshop Bessie Schonberg Theater

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a new magazine being introduced by the Library of Congress misstated the number of items in the Library's collection. It is more than 101 million. In some editions, the first name of the Librarian of Congress was omitted. His name is James H. Billington.

title: Patents
description: IT has been a quarter of a century since Hal, the orbiting computer whose soothing humanoid voice belies a malevolent egomania, appeared in Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey." The idea of a talking computer has since insinuated itself into the popular imagination, but so far the imagination is the only place where computers have real conversational skill.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS , who has a treatable form of lymphatic cancer, is recovering from ulcer surgery at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Rwanda Puzzle: Is Uganda Taking Sides?
description: Eight years ago, Defense Minister Yoweri Museveni of Uganda seized power in Kampala, the Ugandan capital, with the help of about 2,000 guerrillas, a force he recruited among Tutsi refugee families who had fled neighboring Rwanda to escape ethnic bloodletting.

title: Wealthy Mexican's Abduction Underlines Vulnerability of Elite
description: The kidnappers of one of the richest men in Mexico have threatened to kill him unless they are paid a ransom.

title: Ex-Foreign Minister of the 'Old Guard' Seeks to Lead Japan
description: A longtime leader of the former governing party said today that he was defecting in a bid to become Prime Minister and would create an alliance with the rocky coalition now running the country.

title: A River Runs Through Him: Rangers Overwhelm Hextall and Isles
description: After his Rangers humiliated the Islanders and goalie Ron Hextall in the local opener of the Stanley Cup playoffs yesterday, Aleksei Kovalev couldn't keep the grin off his face. After the 6-0 victory at Madison Square Garden, someone asked him, "When did you think Hextall was giving up easy goals?"

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; How correct is political correctness? American editors seem as divided as everyone else.
description: IT is, of course, impossible these days to get together with news people without having it come up.

title: Market Place; Boeing's stock seems unable to rise above its plateau.
description: THE BOEING COMPANY is set to fly its new airplane, the wide-body 777, in June, but the company's stock price is hovering in the mid-40's and not gaining much altitude. With the airline industry still in trouble, orders for new airplanes have been shrinking and the decline is expected to continue at least through this year.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on April 6 about Marlon Riggs, a film maker and a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, misstated his educational background. He received a bachelor's degree from Harvard University and a master's degree from Berkeley.

title: New York City Police Richly Deserve a Shorter Workweek
description: To the Editor:

title: Ron Vawter, Actor, Dies at 45; Known for Avant-Garde Roles
description: Ron Vawter, an avant-garde actor who was a pillar of the Wooster Group, an experimental theater collective in SoHo, died on Saturday on a plane flying from Zurich to New York, his agent said. He was 45 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Review/Concert; An Exercise in Harmony, Aside From Music
description: It took a two-tier system of listening to make compelling sense out of Friday night's concert by the American Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. Devised and conducted by Leon Botstein under the title "Common Ground: Jazz, African-American and Jewish-American Composers (1930-1955)," this long program of recent Americana was either wildly uneven or a well-reasoned affair. It depended on what you were listening for.

title: New Hits Bolster ABC's Hand for the Fall
description: This is the kind of season ABC had in the annual prime-time ratings contest:

title: Macy Urged To Hire New Advisers
description: Two directors of R. H. Macy & Company have circulated letters to their colleagues suggesting that it would be in the board's best interests to hire new legal and financial advisers, people close to the retailer's board of directors said last night.

title: Dance and Conversation
description: Clark Center for the Performing Arts and Louise Roberts, its longtime director, will be honored in "Remembering Clark Center," a free program of dance and conversation on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the Charles Moore Center for Ethnic Studies, 397 Bridge Street, in Downtown Brooklyn. Information: (718) 773-3046.

title: De Klerk's Party Is Driving Wedge Between Nonwhites
description: In the darkest ways, the history of this nation has been a journey into the unthinkable. So it may be understandable that Michael Africa, a "colored," or mixed-race merchant seaman, stepped ashore this week and immediately charted a political course into the once unthinkable choice: voting for his long-time oppressors in South Africa's first free election.

title: Hoax Unravels: 'Missing' Baby Is Found Dead
description: A Canadian couple's stunning but suspicious tale of a baby's disappearance in Central Park was exposed as a hoax yesterday as the parents gave the police a dramatic new account, saying they found the child dead in her crib 10 days ago and abandoned the body in a Quebec woods.

title: Anguish, East and West
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Arrests
description: A renewed emphasis on arrests is at the core of the Giuliani administration's drug strategy. After reaching a record high in 1989, drug arrests declined. The police department stopped aggressively pursuing low-level drug dealers because of soaring costs, the strain on the city's courts and jails and doubts about the effectiveness of mass arrests. Despite fears that beat cops aggressively involved in drug enforcement can more easily fall into corruption, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton now wants all uniformed officers to concentrate on drug offenses. He is also doubling the number of specialized drug units. The Giuliani administration hopes to complement the increased arrests with more drug treatment. According to state officials, 2,000 people per month wait for treatment in New York state.

title: Kidder Reports Fraud and Ousts a Top Trader
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company said yesterday that it dismissed its chief government bond trader during the weekend after it had uncovered fraudulent trading apparently intended to inflate the brokerage firm's profits and the trader's 1993 bonus. As a result, Kidder said $350 million in profits it recorded in the last year never existed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 7 about Greece's relations with the Republic of Macedonia misstated the timing of six Western European countries' diplomatic recognition of the former Yugoslav republic. The diplomatic recognition was in December 1993, not at the end of 1991.

title: Dance in Review
description: Soundance Repertory Company Clark Studio Theater Lincoln Center

title: Review/Opera; 'Ariadne' Brings Its Mix Of Tragedy and Pratfalls
description: Richard Strauss resolved the paradoxes of stagecraft by acting them out in his own operas. Just as "Capriccio" wages a war of ascendancy between words and music, so "Ariadne auf Naxos" which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, lets classical drama and low comedy go 10 rounds to a draw.

title: A startling merger pins its hopes on an industry maverick to help lift the 'Ketchum curse.'
description: THE colorful career of Jerry Della Femina, the rambunctious ad man whose self-promotional skills almost equal his creative capacities, is taking perhaps its most unexpected twist yet.

title: CUNY to Train Recruits For Police in Puerto Rico
description: Tomorrow, almost 900 students will begin their first day of classes in a new City University of New York program to train police officers and confer on them an associate degree in police science.

title: Review/Music; A Vision of Cultures in Flux
description: Yothu Yindi's audience at the Grand on Thursday night pretty much just stood around. The band, which mixes aboriginal music from Australia with various international pop styles, performs in aboriginal outfits. The band members come out, bodies painted, playing sticks and didgeridoos. They perform a short set of tribal music, unaccompanied. And they do traditional dances. Inadvertently, their shows become a type of ethnic spectacle.

title: Sports of The Times; This Hextall Joins Ranger History Books
description: HIS family name already resides in the New York Rangers' record book: winning goal in 1940 Stanley Cup final game -- Bryan Hextall Sr.

title: Schools Prosecute Parents for Children's Truancy
description: Ellen Freeman concedes that from last September to December she was less than attentive to her 10-year-old son's school attendance. Beset by personal problems and "fighting off another nervous breakdown," she said she actually kept him home sometimes simply to provide her with a focus and anchor -- some needed ballast in her storm-tossed life.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: MONDAY Dana Corp Eastern Utils Assoc Genuine Parts Co Goodrich B F Co Lilly Eli & Co Merry Ld & Invt Inc Pall Corp Southern Co TUESDAY First Intst Bancorp Hawaiian Elec Inds Health Care Reit Inc Honeywell Inc Inco Ltd Mellon Bk Corp Southern Ind Gas&Elec Sprint Corp Timken Co V F Corp Whirlpool Corp WEDNESDAY Amer Home Prods Corp Cincinnati Gas&ELec Co Core Inds Inc Dow Jones & Co Inc First USA Inc Intl Shipholding Corp Nalco Chem Co Outboard Marine Corp Washington Energy Co Wells Fargo&Co THURSDAY Alltel Corp Archer-Daniels-Midland Bearings Inc Central Newspapers Inc Cmac Invt Corp Gillette Co Health Care Ppty Invs Jostens Inc Niagara Mohawk Pwr Oneok Inc PPG Inds Inc Shaw Inds Inc Student Ln Corp Transtechnology Corp Weyerhaeuser Co FRIDAY Amer Precision Inds Boise Cascade Crop Central La Elec Crestar Finl Corp Ferro Corp Harland John H Co Harris Corp Lee Enterprises Massmutual Corp Invs Monsanto Co Nashua Corp Nationwide Health Pptys Progressive Corp Ohio Snap On Tools Corp Wachovia Corp Zero Corp

title: Bronx Woman Is Slain
description: A 63-year-old Bronx woman, whom residents called the unofficial mother or grandmother of nearly everyone in her apartment building, was found stabbed to death yesterday, apparently during a robbery.

title: More Democracy Vital, Mexican Candidate Says
description: The new presidential candidate of Mexico's long-governing party says further democratization of the political system has become essential to economic and social progress.

title: Command Presents
description: So now the Senate Armed Services Committee has joined the old boys' network that protects the top military brass from accountability. It recommended last week that Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, the Chief of Naval Operations, retire at the rank of four stars as his predecessors traditionally have.

title: Bronx Postal Building Fails to Stem Mail Delays
description: A Bronx building that the Postal Service bought for $25.9 million in 1989, intended for use as a mail processing center, sits largely dormant, even as Bronx officials say postal delays have plagued the borough for nearly a year, with letters mailed within the Bronx sometimes taking weeks to arrive.

title: Guarding the Image in Newark; City Bars Local Filming of a Movie About Teen-Age Car Bandits
description: After decades of trying to claw its way out of the ranks of urban has-beens, Newark can be a bit prickly about its image. The local boosters often complain that no matter how much they rebuild their venerable but often pitied city, they cannot wipe away the stains left by a history of poverty, bad schools and rampant car theft.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions Friday with an article about a dispute over the value of Andy Warhol's estate referred incorrectly to "Shot Red Marilyn," the Warhol painting that was shown. It is not part of the estate.

title: White House Goes Courting In California
description: It is well established that the White House is determined to stroke California voters as often and as vigorously as possible to win their allegiance in the 1996 Presidential election.

title: Tribute to Cunningham
description: "Cunningham on Camera," a 10-day festival of films and videos about and by Merce Cunningham, opens on April 26 at 8 P.M. at the Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, with a tribute to the modern-dance choreographer. The program includes the New York premiere of "Beach Birds for Camera" and a discussion featuring Mr. Cunningham. Tickets are $10; $7 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The festival is to include 25 films and videos and rare clips from the Cunningham archives. Information: (212) 875-5600.

title: Books of The Times; Dissecting the Values Of a Divided Intellectual
description: A Rebel in Defense of Tradition The Life and Politics of Dwight Macdonald By Michael Wreszin Illustrated. 590 pages. Basic Books/HarperCollins. $30.

title: Question Is Raised on Hormone Maker's Ties to F.D.A. Aides
description: Two House committee chairmen and a Vermont Congressman asserted yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration may have collaborated with the manufacturer of a genetically engineered dairy hormone in clearing the new drug for sale.

title: Cancer Study Prompts New Awareness
description: In the days since the New York State Health Department released a report suggesting an association between the high rate of breast cancer on Long Island with living near chemical plants, citizen groups that fight breast cancer in the Northeast have been taking another look in their own backyards -- and at Long Island's vocal breast-cancer lobby.

title: Banks Testing System For Corporate Payments
description: A computerized system that enables companies to make payments and send the payment data in a single electronic message will be introduced on Monday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Could this be the beginning of the end for one of the country's more public marriages? ROSEANNE ARNOLD filed suit yesterday in Los Angeles for a divorce from TOM ARNOLD.

title: Dworin's Suitors Make Other Choices
description: Two agencies that unsuccessfully wooed Steve Dworin have appointed executives to the positions he was offered.

title: Observer; Excuses For a Shame
description: It's mean out here. Half the country is cheering for a foreign government to go ahead and beat an American, age 18, to bloody pulp because he vandalized cars and signs in Singapore.

title: Accounts
description: * Growing Healthy Inc., Eden Prairie, Minn., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the maker of frozen baby food, previously at Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Failure at Gorazde
description: The battle for Gorazde leaves no one covered with glory. The Serbs now have the city at their mercy. But their duplicity and bloodthirstiness have disgusted the world. NATO and the U.N. have been ignored and humiliated. And Russia, despite its supposed clout with the Serbs, is as powerless as everyone else to hold them to their word.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL CABLE CORP., Highland Heights, Ky., announced that it had received a proposal from an unaffiliated third party to acquire all of the company's common stock at a price not exceeding $6 a share. KELLWOOD CO., St. Louis, said its American Recreation Products unit had agreed to acquire Sierra Designs, a unit of closely held Odyssey International. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Success Greets A Little Movie
description: Every now and then a movie unexpectedly climbs to the No. 1 slot without big stars, huge budgets, violent action, a half-dozen uncredited writers and the cliches that mar too many studio films.

title: State Dept. Criticizes White House on Macedonia Ties
description: In an open rift with the White House, State Department officials contend that the Administration is bowing to pressure from Greek-Americans in delaying a decision to establish full diplomatic relations with the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia.

title: Coca-Cola Co. (KO:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 12,000,000, or 1 cent a share, from a change in accounting for postemployment benefits.Revenue represented net operating revenues.

title: NEC Selects Houston Effler
description: NEC Technologies Inc., a maker of computers and peripheral products, said yesterday that it had selected Houston Effler & Partners in Boston to handle its North American account, which had been at DDB Needham New York for the last eight years. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about modifications offered by Senator George J. Mitchell for President Clinton's health care legislation described one alternative incorrectly in some copies. Mr. Mitchell's apparent preference is for a plan that calculates subsidies for small businesses based on each worker's wage, not age. Under this plan, a company could get a subsidy for each of its low-paid employees.

title: Cincinnati Bell (CSN:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,925,000, or 4 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Cincinnnati Bell said that the 1994 revenue increase can be primarily attributed to the acquisition of WATS Marketing in November 1993, and to strong revenue increases in continuing CBIS operations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a picture yesterday showing the police training program operated in Puerto Rico by the City University of New York was published in mirror image. The man with the shotgun should have appeared at the right.

title: Russell Corp.(RML:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: b-Included an accounting gain equal to 2 cents a share from the adoption of FASB 106 and 109.

title: Lanes Open For Car Pools
description: Forget the 4-minute mile. Yesterday more than 1,000 drivers managed a 4-minute Queensboro Bridge, compared with the usual 20 minutes or so.

title: Review/Dance; The Pennsylvania Ballet Looks Back on 30 Years
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet has faced various economic and directorial crises since Barbara Weisberger founded it 30 years ago. But it remains alive and kicking.

title: Dana Corp.(DCN:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago net income and net income per share as reported in 1993 excluded a one-time charge relating to the adoption of SFAS 112 of $ 48.9 million, or $ 1.06 a share.

title: Xerox Creates Software To Rival Offset Printing
description: Seeking to promote plateless printing, the Xerox Corporation is expected to announce today that it has developed software to link computer terminals and scanners with high-speed copiers, regardless of location or manufacturer.

title: Universal Foods Corp.(UFC:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 23,563,000, or 90 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Isolation As Tactic
description: One year later, the Bosnian Serbs have applied the Srebrenica model again.

title: Reviews/Pop; A Harp Here, A Concept There, Naturally
description: What strange things the 1960's have left us. Ethnic exoticism, yesterday's allegiance to experimentalism, the New Age movement; without the 1960's, the Swiss harpist Andreas Vollenweider wouldn't exist. Mr. Vollenweider, who performed at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night, is the king of touchy-feely New Ageism. He has made a career of creating mammoth landscapes around the tinkling of his harp. His music occasionally has the sounds of nature percolating through it, and there is a touch of sci-fi medievalism to titles like "Dancing With the Lion" or "Jugglers in Obsidian."

title: Nortek Inc.(NTK:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-Included extraordinary income of $ 400,000, or 3 cents a share, from the retirement of debt, and after a benefit of $ 400,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 2.1 million, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: A Spring Ice Jam Bursts, and a Maine Town Is Pummeled
description: Spring arrived with a vengeance over the weekend in this town in northeastern Maine when an ice jam clogging the Aroostook River burst, sending huge blocks of ice barreling into town on a wave of frigid waters.

title: Drug Emporium Inc.(DEMP:NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: McGraw-Hill Inc.(MHP:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included pretax loss of $ 20,345,000 from the company's share of losses from the Macmillan/McGraw-Hill joint venture. McGraw-Hill bought Macmillan's 50 percent interest in the venture on Oct. 4, 1993.

title: Review/Theater: Beauty and the Beast; Disney Does Broadway, Dancing Spoons and All
description: As Broadway musicals go, "Beauty and the Beast" belongs right up there with the Empire State Building, F. A. O. Schwarz and the Circle Line boat tours. It is hardly a triumph of art, but it'll probably be a whale of a tourist attraction. It is Las Vegas without the sex, Mardi Gras without the booze and Madame Tussaud's without the waxy stares. You don't watch it, you gape at it, knowing that nothing in Dubuque comes close.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday, about the plans of the Ford Motor Company to increase its dividend and split its stock, misstated the percentage of outstanding shares in the Hertz Corporation that Ford intends to buy to gain full ownership of the company. It is 46 percent, not 26 percent.

title: A Tunnel Waiting Two Decades for a Train; Shafts for the Second Avenue Subway Are Maintained, in Case the Line Is Ever Built
description: The lights, strung on makeshift wires between steel girders, dimly illuminate a long shaft that seems to stretch far into the distance. As Mike Hardiman, a Transit Authority supervisor, strolls with a flashlight on the subway tunnel's floor, there is a deep rumble.

title: Player of Year Times Two
description: The Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association presented the Haggerty Award to co-winners tonight at Giants Stadium -- Arturas Karnishovas of Seton Hall and Izett Buchanan of Marist.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Andreas Haefliger Pianist 92d Street Y

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Newark officials' refusal to allow the filming of the movie "New Jersey Drive" in their city referred incorrectly in some copies to the position of the director, Nick Gomez, in the photo. He was at the left, near the camera, pointing with his left hand.

title: Beijing Now Admits That Robbers Killed 24 Taiwan Tourists
description: China acknowledged for the first time on Sunday that 24 tourists from Taiwan found burned to death on March 31 in a pleasure boat on a scenic lake in southern China had been slain.

title: Traders Ponder Fed's Moves as Dow Falls
description: How gradual is gradual? Is Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and famed gradualist, preparing the markets for speedier increases in interest rates, greasing the stock and bond markets' already slippery decline?

title: NEC SAID TO BE CLOSE TO INVESTMENT IN GENERAL MAGIC
description: The NEC Corporation, which dominates Japan's market for personal computers, will invest an undisclosed amount in the multimedia consortium General Magic to gain access to the United States company's communications software, Nikkei English News reported yesterday. A NEC official denied that the company had made any formal decision to invest in General Magic, but he would not rule out the possibility that NEC might do so in the future. A General Magic spokeswoman also declined to confirm the report. NEC's participation would bring to 11 the number of high-technology giants that have joined the privately held General Magic, based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.(WTI:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. Urges Users of New Well Pumps to Drink Bottled Water
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today advised hundreds of thousands of people who drink from private wells to switch temporarily to bottled water and to test for possible lead contamination from pumps installed in the past year.

title: Rockwell International Corp.(ROK:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
G.E. Shaken by Phantom Trades at Kidder Unit
description: Just when the General Electric Company thought that it had put its investment banking subsidiary, Kidder, Peabody & Company, on solid footing, a seemingly rogue bond trader caused it to take a $350 million pretax charge to its first-quarter earnings.

title: Polaroid Corp.(PRD:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: b-Net loss, which included pretax charge of $ 44 million from early retirement of debt, and after a charge of $ 119.2 million, or $ 2.56 a share, from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principle for postretirement benefits and postemployment benefits.(Loss)

title: Ukraine's Unsettling Vote
description: Shrugging off predictions of apathy, Ukrainians turned out by the millions this month to vote in the independent republic's first free parliamentary elections. They gave scant support to paramilitary extremists. But 118 Communists and their allies won seats, as did 35 of their moderate nationalist opponents. Reform-minded centrists fared poorly.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Liege Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Sports of The Times; Montague The Obscure And Jordan
description: "SURE Babe Ruth was good, but could he play hoop?"

title: Is It Springtime for Moscow?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dissidents Threaten A Macy Bid
description: Dissident directors of R. H. Macy & Company threatened yesterday to step in with a bid of their own for the bankrupt retailer.

title: Review/Music; Concordia Offers Premieres
description: New works, and works that draw on jazz elements, have always been the heart of Marin Alsop's repertory with her Concordia Orchestra, and in that sense, the ensemble's concert on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall was business as usual. One piece, George Bogatko's "Go for It," was hardly even a jazz-classical hybrid: its language, structure and moves were pure jazz, but it was scored for strings rather than for winds. Besides a drum solo, played with spectacular variety and energy by Chris Adams, it included a cello solo, which Erik Friedlander played deftly.

title: Devils' Rx: 2 Aspirins And Storm The Net
description: Attack the net with more vigor and create more traffic in front of Sabres goaltender Dominik Hasek. That's what the Devils want to do to even their opening-round series against Buffalo.

title: Pentair Inc.(PNTA:NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Merrill Net Was Up 21% In Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter rose 21 percent, to a record $371.8 million, largely because of substantial increases in commissions and asset-management fees.

title: Slap Shot Is a Long Shot in the All-Important Ratings as Well as on the Ice
description: Why is hockey on ABC when its ratings' tote board looks like World League football's did? Over the first three weeks of ABC coverage on Sunday afternoons, the national Nielsen rating averaged a 1.7.

title: VLSI Technology Inc.(VLSI:NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
description: b-Net loss(Loss)The latest first quarter was a 14-week period, while the previous first quarter had 13 weeks.

title: CONAGRA TO BUY UNIVERSAL'S FROZEN FOODS UNIT
description: Conagra Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the frozen food business of the Universal Foods Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash. Conagra said it was paying a premium over book value for the division, which accounts for $268 million of Universal's $892 million annual sales. The unit, based in Boise, Idaho, makes frozen potato products and has 2,000 employees in Idaho, Oregon and Washington. Universal, based in Milwaukee, makes prepared foods and ingredients. Conagra, a diversified food company in Omaha, has annual sales of $21.5 billion. Its stock fell 75 cents yesterday, to $27.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Big Picture of Cancer Process Is Being Seen for the First Time
description: FOR years, molecular biologists have held fast to a deep-seated belief about the nature of cancer. Malignancy, they argued, must have something to do with a loss of the molecular brakes that halt the growth and division of cells. After all, they reasoned, the most distinctive feature of a cancer cell is that it does not stop growing, while a normal cell does.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Consider a Ban on Guns Near Schools
description: In a case with implications for an array of Federal gun control measures, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress has the constitutional authority to ban the possession of guns near school buildings.

title: Hewlett Names a Manager
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has named Richard C. Watts general manager of its personal information products group, which markets personal computers and products ranging from calculators to interactive cable television boxes.

title: Harding Says Thanks
description: TONYA HARDING, who has led a very private existence lately, has a public message for her fans: thank you.

title: 5 Players Move On In N.F.L.
description: Six days before the college draft, the National Football League's free agent game of musical teams picked up tempo yesterday. Defensive end Sean Jones moved from Houston to Green Bay, quarterback John Friesz went from San Diego to Washington, guard Kevin Gogan moved from Dallas to the Los Angeles Raiders, guard Derek Kennard went from New Orleans to Dallas and returner Vai Sikahema said goodbye to the Philadelphia Eagles and hello to broadcasting.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Connecticut is selling $50 million of tax-exempt general obligation capital appreciation bonds through Merrill Lynch & Co., initially priced to yield a maximum 6.30 percent for an issue due in 2013. The remaining bonds were priced to yield from 5.10 percent in 1999 to 6.25 percent in 2011. The issue, for a college savings plan, is rated Aa by Moody's Investors Servive, AA- by Standard & Poor's and AA+ by Fitch Investors Service.

title: The 6-Mile Shelf of Computer Books
description: COMPUTER books are big business; how big, no one knows. For circumstantial evidence, wander into one of the chain bookstores and look down the long shelves of books like "DOS for Lovers," "Backpacking a Powerbook" and "Taking Virtual Reality Through the Glass Ceiling," all made-up titles but none an absolutely crazy idea.

title: Review/Music; Carlo Bergonzi Sings His American Farewell
description: Even in a city where vocal recitals are plentiful, concerts that are likely to be remembered as much for the electricity of the atmosphere as for their musical content are few and far between. Or at least, they usually are. It was only five weeks ago that Victoria de los Angeles, at 70, set an audience at Alice Tully Hall aflame. Yet in retrospect, that seemed almost a warm-up for the reception given to Carlo Bergonzi on Sunday evening, when he sang his American farewell recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Johnson Controls Inc.(JCI:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a one time charge of $ 122,000,000, or $ 2.99 a share, from a cumulative effect of accounting changes. The company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions'', No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes'', and No. 112, ''Employers' Accounting for Postemployment Benefits'' effective Oct. 1, 1992.(Loss)Sales represented net sales.

title: Dollar Down on Wide Front As Stocks and Bonds Drop
description: The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday after an increase in American interest rates sent stock and bond markets into a tailspin.

title: Tribune Co.(TRB:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: Revenue represented total operating revenues.

title: Zilog Inc.(ZLOG:NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
Insurer in China
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies said today that it had opened a representative office in Beijing. The Beijing office will receive full administrative and operational support from the Hong Kong office, the New York-based insurance broker said.

title: Review/Television; The Many, Many Steps That Led to Yalta's Table
description: Reducing all of World War II to the equivalent of a dud firecracker might seem impossible but, by golly, television has managed to do exactly that in "World War II: When Lions Roared," a four-hour movie that NBC is to broadcast this evening from 8 to 10 and tomorrow night from 9 to 11.

title: Wandering Down Civilization's Garden Paths
description: IN the course of Western civilization, April 19 has been something of a day off. It is St. Alphege (pronounced ALF-edge) of Canterbury's Day, commemorating the Archbishop of Canterbury who went to his eternal reward in 1012, axed in the head after refusing attempts to ransom him from the marauding Danes on the ground that the money should go to the poor. On the same date a scant 869 years later, in 1881, Queen Victoria's favorite Prime Minister, Benjamin Disraeli, joined St. Alphege in eternity and in doing so created the legacy of Primrose Day, a holiday observed by his party in England.

title: Books of The Times; Profiles in Leadership, and in Anti-Leadership
description: Certain Trumpets The Call of Leaders By Garry Wills Illustrated. 336 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Allen J. Frances; Revamping Psychiatrists' Bible
description: PERHAPS the most powerful psychiatrist in America at the moment is Dr. Allen J. Frances, the man who has been directing the fourth major revision of his profession's diagnostic bible, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, to be published next month.

title: MacTavish Is Taking Charge In a Hurry
description: Sometimes, Brian Noonan's game is this simple. His teammate of less than a month, Craig MacTavish, was to the left of the net, and Noonan was to the right. They had both arrived in this place, in the second game of what has so far become an overwhelming Ranger playoff drive, in separate trades made March 21. Noonan had come from Chicago, MacTavish from Edmonton, and now they were on the same line, sharing the same chance.

title: Chess
description: The type of attack most difficult to see through is the one that demands painstaking preparation because a long series of developing moves can often look routine and thus lull the defender into dropping his guard. Quite often none of this preliminary stage will embody direct threats. Indeed, the course of the game will look deceptively as though the opponent were just tending to his knitting.

title: United Cos. Financial Corp.(UCFC:NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss, which included a loss of $ 17,585,000, or $ 1.95 a share, from discontinued operations.(Loss)

title: GORAZDE POUNDED BY SERB GUNNERS
description: Serbian nationalist artillery opened fire on the refugee-packed eastern Bosnian town of Gorazde again today as the top United Nations general here warned of a humanitarian catastrophe.

title: FED AGAIN RAISES SHORT-TERM RATE ON LOANS, TO 3.75%
description: The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates today for the third time in two and a half months, trying once again to slow the nation's brisk economic growth before it begins to feed inflation.

title: Cuts and Tax Rises Urged To Bolster Social Security
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, today proposed shoring up the finances of Social Security by reducing next year's cost-of-living adjustment, increasing the retirement age, trimming benefits for new retirees and raising payroll taxes in the 21st century.

title: Hawks Next So Knicks Need Rapid Recovery
description: The Knicks spent yesterday saving their energy for the biggest game of the season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 BOSNIAN TOWN SURROUNDED The Bosnian town of Gorazde was surrounded by Serbian forces after Bosnian Government defenses collapsed, and the top United Nations general warned of a humanitarian catastrophe. A1

title: True 'Skinheads' Are Not the Racist Thugs of Media Fame
description: To the Editor:

title: UST Inc.(UST:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 19,846,000, or 9 cents a share, froms the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.

title: Springs Industries(SMI:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 72,543,000, or $ 4.07 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.(FRE:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 28 million, or 16 cents a share, to retire high-cost debt.Year-ago revenues are pro forma. In the first quarter, Freddie Mac changed the way it reports uncollectible interest on single-family mortgages to be more consistent with industry practices.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Corporate Communicating; The Fax Flood Shows Little Sign of Receding
description: Like kudzu, paper spews out endlessly from the office fax machine, crucial reports and rubbish alike. Missed two pages of a 40-page document? No problem -- The whole thing will be resent.

title: Stelco (STE.A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: (Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Zulu Nationalist Leader Appears to Yield on Election
description: South African negotiators said today that they were near a breakthrough that could avert a violent election boycott, after Chief Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi, the Zulu nationalist leader, made a last-minute appeal to be included in elections next week.

title: Big Project Dead, Physicists Find Small Is Beautiful
description: SCATTERED bands of inventors are quietly laboring to insure that physics, three centuries after its birth, has a chance to keep advancing into its most challenging realms despite the recent collapse of its flagship project, the superconducting supercollider, which would have been the biggest science experiment of all time.

title: Biggest Bank Is Criticized In Germany
description: Germany's largest commercial bank drew criticism for responding too slowly to the financial problems of the fugitive developer Jurgen Schneider, as the dissolution of his real estate empire accelerated today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NORMAN DORSEN was a 23-year-old graduate of Harvard Law School and in the Army's judge advocate general's office when he landed his first assignment: helping Joseph N. Welch, counsel to the Army in the McCarthy hearings.

title: KU Energy Corp.(KU:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: KU Energy said that 1994 first quarter earnings included a one-time, pretax recovery of about $ 3.2 million from resolution of a coal contract dispute.

title: Senate Women Want Admiral To Lose Rank
description: Six of the seven women in the Senate said today that they would oppose allowing the Navy's top officer to retire with his four-star admiral's rank because of his role in the Tailhook sexual-harassment scandal.

title: Illinois Power Co. (IPC:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Beefing Up Bradley
description: The Philadelphia 76ers are hoping that an eight-time world body-building champion can help beef up center SHAWN BRADLEY before next season.

title: Chris-Craft Industries(CCN:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 108,413,000, pretax, from Time Warner Inc. securities recognized by BHC Communications Inc., a 72 percent-owned unit.

title: Review/Music; The Y Continues Its Examination of Schubert
description: In a fascinating talk on Sunday during the opening festivities of the Schubertiade at the 92d Street Y, Leon Botstein gave a portrait of the Vienna of Schubert's day, a town of about 300,000 people with no running water, no sewage system and an elaborate series of government regulations. There were high death rates and a life expectancy that only slightly exceeded Schubert's (who died at the age of 31). The city was stench-ridden; gastrointestinal disorders were plentiful, personal hygiene minimal. As for Schubert himself, Mr. Botstein said, "none of us would survive sitting next to him."

title: GSE MULTIMEDIA ACQUIRES 36% STAKE IN EMERSON RADIO
description: The GSE Multimedia Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired 12 million shares, or 36 percent, of the Emerson Radio Corporation for $15 million. Emerson Radio, a consumer electronics company in Parsippany, N.J., recently emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Financing for the transaction was arranged by Fidenas International Ltd. as part of its $75 million financing for the restructuring of Emerson. GSE Multimedia, based in New York, is a developer of interactive multimedia technology.

title: Wolverine Tube Inc.(WLV:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,768,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

description: Okidata, a manufacturer of computer printers, facsimile equipment and desktop processors, has called off an agency review and retained the incumbent, Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor of New York, on its estimated $10 million account.

description: The Jets avoided what could have been a calamitous situation on their offensive line and came to terms with the veteran center Jim Sweeney today.

description: Representative Jim Cooper offers a simple explanation for his putting forward a health care proposal: "This is a pocketbook issue. It really matters to every family."

Trading Places in South Africa?
description: The Crossroads and Khayelitsha squatter camps lie just beyondCape Town's D. F. Malan Airport. Over the years, they have ever edged closer to the N2 highway, and here and there litter from thousands of tin shacks cascades onto the road. The southeasterly wind blows some of it against wire fences. From afar, it makes an eerily beautiful picture with the sunlight glinting off hundreds of pieces of plastic.

ENTERRA TO ACQUIRE TOTAL ENERGY SERVICES
description: The Enterra Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Total Energy Services Company for about $246.2 million in stock and cash and the assumption of $68 million in Total Energy debt. Enterra said it would swap 11.3 million common shares for Total Energy. At yesterday's closing price of $19.75 for Enterra's shares, the stock portion of the transaction would be $223.2 million. In addition, Enterra will pay $23 million cash for minority interests in two Total Energy subsidiaries. Private funds managed by the First Reserve Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., currently own about 99 percent of Total Energy and will own about 41 percent of Enterra's common stock after the deal.

title: BOSNIA UPDATE
description: In the refugee-packed town of GORAZDE, Serbian nationalists ignored cease-fire promises and continued their attack, while in SARAJEVO, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, the United Nations commander in BOSNIA, warned of a humanitarian catastrophe.

description: Benita Valente Soprano Alice Tully Hall

title: Dudley Looks to Return
description: CHRIS DUDLEY, who has missed virtually the entire season with a broken ankle, worked out with the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday and hopes to play before the regular season ends Sunday.

title: Settlement Recommended For L.I.R.R. and Workers
description: With the possibility of a strike looming in June, a Presidential panel has recommended a settlement between the Long Island Rail Road and its workers based on a management proposal.

title: Maxwell McKnight, a Diplomat In Postwar Europe, Is Dead at 83
description: Maxwell Stewart McKnight, a retired lawyer and former State Department official who held diplomatic posts in postwar Europe, died on Friday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 83.

title: Corrections

Macy & Company, omitted a connection of Stutman, Treister & Glatt, a Los Angeles law firm, to the case. The firm was recently retained to represent Fidelity Investments, a mutual fund company that is one of Macy's largest creditors.

New Jersey Teachers Flex Muscles, but Carefully
description: In the tightly knit universe of New Jersey politics, no organization has had more muscle than the New Jersey Education Association and none has been more willing to use it, whether to reverse control of the State Legislature or to run an otherwise friendly Governor out of office for crossing it over teachers' salaries and pensions.

title: 'Deal of the Century': Debt-to-Riches at Citicorp -- A special report.; How an Argentine Bonanza Helped Big Bank and Friends
description: Two years ago, when Citicorp was in financial trouble and its chairman, John S. Reed, was battling to save his career, he turned for help to Argentina and to his old friend and confidant, H. Richard Handley, the president of Citibank Argentina.

title: Lumber Falls on Concerns Over Mortgage Rate Rises
description: Lumber prices fell their daily limit yesterday amid concern that the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates for the third time since Feb. 4 may reduce demand for housing.

title: MICROSOFT CORP. (MSFT:NMS)
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported quarterly profits yesterday that were above analysts' expectations, led by strong sales of its Windowsoperating system and its bundled offering of business applications, called Office.

title: Miami Officer in '89 Shooting Is Dismissed
description: William Lozano, the Miami police officer whose shooting of a black motorcyclist in 1989 led to three days of rioting here, is being dismissed, the Miami Police Department said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League NEW YORK YANKEES -- Named Keith Wiarda director of marketing and public relations.

title: AMWEST PARTNERS' AMERICA WEST BID MAY BE IN JEOPARDY
description: A $245 million bid for America West Airlines Inc. could be in jeopardy after the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the carrier's case in Phoenix struck down $8 million in potential fees. United States Bankruptcy Judge Robert Mooreman denied a request by the financier David Bonderman for the fees, which are intended to cover Mr. Bonderman's expenses for putting the bid together. The fees, which were opposed by a shareholder group, would be paid only if America West accepted a competing offer. Mr. Bonderman's group, known as AmWest Partners, has said it would drop its offer if the "breakup"fee was not approved.

title: Turner Is Lost to Magic
description: JEFF TURNER, who started the past 13 games at power forward for the Orlando Magic, will miss the remainder of the season because of a knee injury.

title: I.B.M. AND MOTOROLA ANNOUNCE FASTER POWERPC CHIP
description: I.B.M. and Motorola announced yesterday that they had completed development and fabrication of a new chip in the PowerPC family, the 604. Intended for use in high-end desktops, servers and work stations, the new chip is 60 percent faster than the Intel Corporation's Pentium chip running an industry-standard set of programs, according to Michael Slater, publisher of the Microprocessor Report in Sebastopol, Calif. But the PowerPC family of chips is mainly an advantage for users of Apple MacIntosh personal computers running Apple's operating software. More than 85 percent of today's personal computers run the Microsoft Corporation's operating software on the Intel chip architecture. The 604 chip is scheduled to move into volume production in the fourth quarter of this year.

title: Slaying in St. Thomas Stains Image of an 'American Paradise'
description: According to the license plates on the cars and buses that haul tourists around this bustling port, the Virgin Islands are still an "American Paradise." But a surge in violent crime over the last year, including the slaying of a San Diego swimming instructor this week, has put that image in jeopardy.

title: U.S. Creators Said to Abet Soviet A-Bomb
description: A new book by a high Soviet intelligence official asserts that the chief Western architects of the nuclear era acted as spies to give Moscow the secrets of the atom bomb.

title: Rust Int'l(RST:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Dr. Annemarie Weil, A Child Psychiatrist And a Teacher, 84
description: Dr. Annemarie P. Weil, a child psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died on Friday at a convalescent home in Bryn Mawr, Pa., near Philadelphia. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clients Press to Keep AIDS Agency
description: The woman was 22 years old, pregnant and renting out a single room in a house in Queens when she found out she had H.I.V. Coming at a time when she was trying to find an apartment for herself and the baby, the news left her in a daze and gave a her a host of new worries, like arranging specialized medical care and counseling.

title: New Criteria For Earnings
description: The listing of corporate earnings in Business Day now covers only companies that have at least $50 million in quarterly revenues. Banking and insurance companies, which do not usually report revenues, will be covered in the listing if their total assets exceed $2 billion.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: The Bluff That Failed; Serbs Around Gorazde Are Undeterred By NATO's Policy of Limited Air Strikes
description: In conducting limited air strikes last week to defend the Muslim enclave of Gorazde, Western military commanders played the game the way the Serbs had hoped they would -- and lost.

title: Extension at Villanova
description: Villanova Coach STEVE LAPPAS, who led his team to its first National Invitation Tournament championship this year, received a contract extension yesterday through the 1997-98 season.

title: Reid to Razorbacks
description: KAREEM REID, the 5-foot-9-inch blur of a point guard out of St. Raymond's High School in the Bronx, announced yesterday that he had signed a letter of intent to attend Arkansas, the newly crowned national champions. Reid chose Arkansas over Providence, Texas and California.

title: FIGGIE SHARES FALL 14.7% AS TALKS WITH LENDERS FALTER
description: Shares of Figgie International Inc. fell 14.7 percent yesterday after the Willoughby, Ohio, conglomerate said on Friday that it had failed to negotiate a new long-term bank agreement before filing its annual report. Figgie's inability to wrap up a lending agreement before submitting the year-end report to the Securities and Exchange Commission prompted the company's independent auditors to question its ability to continue as a going concern. Figgie's many businesses include Rawlings sporting goods, firefighting equipment and electronic missile components. The previous agreement expired Dec. 31. Figgie's Class A stock fell $1.375 yesterday, to $8, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Progressive Corp.(PGR:N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Latest first quarter included net realized loss on sale of securities of $ 2.6 million.Year-ago period included net realized gain on sale of securities of $ 17.8 million.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Ameritech and U S West Post Gains in Quarter
description: The Ameritech Corporation and U S West Inc. reported strong first-quarter earnings today as the two Baby Bell telephone companies reaped benefits from continuing efforts to revamp and were aided by improving regional economies where they operate.

title: Salary Cap Is Misguided Medicine
description: Considering some of the comments emanating from major league club owners, it seems that the salary cap they want the players to accept would cure not only their economic problems but also the problems of health care, secondary smoke and the succession to the British throne.

title: Now It's the Israeli Right That Urges Soldiers to Refuse to Evict Settlers
description: In Israel, where the army is respected to the point of veneration, soldiers rarely refuse to carry out orders.

title: Kent Hits Another Key Homer, But 2 by Bell Outdistance Mets
description: Once again, Jeff Kent tried to save them. Once again, Jeff Kent took a mighty swing and smashed a two-run home run over the wall when the Mets were in desperate need of offense. This time, it wasn't enough.

title: Nixon Hospitalized After Having Stroke
description: Richard M. Nixon suffered a stroke yesterday and was in stable condition last night at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, a spokeswoman said.

title: No Regrets From L.T.
description: Lawrence Taylor insisted, "No, no, no," when asked today if he had any second thoughts about retiring from the Giants.

title: If It's Mattingly in April, It Must Be .200
description: Don Mattingly sounded like an incumbent in an election year. No change, no change, no change. He repeated those two words whenever questions were tossed at him, but he was not discussing politics. Mattingly was talking about hitting, or his lack of hitting in the first month of the season. Again.

title: Presidential Health Show Travels to a Friendly Spot
description: Saying the health care system "costs too much and does too little," President Clinton took his campaign to change the system to the constituents of three friendly but uncommitted Democratic members of Congress today.

title: Zuckerman Postpones Closing Deal for Coliseum
description: Faced with a deadline yesterday for closing the deal for his purchase of the New York Coliseum, Mortimer B. Zuckerman exercised his right to another delay, this time at the request of city officials.

title: Wall St. Journal Plan
description: The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that it would begin additional regional coverage for its Southeast and Florida editions every Wednesday, beginning on Oct. 12. The Journal said its Marketplace section for the Florida and Southeast editions would get an additiional four pages devoted to coverage of issues important in those regions. The Southeast Journal will appear in about 122,000 copies of the newspaper that circulate in Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina and parts of Tennessee.

description: Kidder officials, who spoke yesterday on condition they not be named, said the "profits" he reported reflected what amounted to accrued interest that would never be received. Those profits would vanish within months or even days. But by then, they said, he would have reported more such trades, and profits.

title: Court Backs Reinstating Of Jeffries to College Post
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the reinstatement of Dr. Leonard Jeffries as chairman of the black studies department at City College but overturned a jury's award of $360,000 in damages from City University, which demoted him after he gave a speech that some considered anti-Semitic and racist.

description: Undermined by deep fiscal problems and poor academic achievement, the Hartford public school system is seriously considering a radical step: turning over management of all its schools, troubles and all, to a private, for-profit company.

title: Autopsy Data Inconclusive In Baby Death
description: An autopsy on the baby of a Canadian couple who concocted a kidnapping hoax in New York City last weekend to conceal her death and the abandonment of her body in a Quebec woods found no signs of violence, abuse or malnutrition, but further tests will be needed to pinpoint the cause of death, Canadian officials said yesterday.

title: Acid Rain Is Cutting Birds' Reproduction In a Dutch Forest
description: ACID rain is causing a severe drop in the reproductive rates of songbirds in the Netherlands, scientists have found. In an environmental threat reminiscent of the widespread havoc caused by DDT and other pesticides more than three decades ago, the pollution causes changes in the food chain, leading the birds to lay thin and defective eggs that rarely hatch.

title: Ndeti and Pippig Run Like the Wind
description: The course for the Boston Marathon runs from Hopkinton to the city, almost directly west to east. The wind during today's 98th running of this American sports classic blew steadily at 20 miles an hour or more, also west to east.

title: Medicinal Plants Get Sanctuary in Rain Forest
description: A GROUP of traditional healers has collaborated with the Government of Belize to create a 6,000-acre sanctuary in the rain forest dedicated to the protection and use of medicinal plants. The Terra Nova Forest Reserve, the world's first ethnobiomedical forest reserve, is intended to insure that the plants, and the healers who depend on them will flourish.

title: Aides Ready to Ask Clinton To Send Jets Against Serbs
description: President Clinton's principal national security advisers will recommend to him on Tuesday that he seek approval for the broader use of air power in Bosnia to halt hostilities and force the Serbs back to the bargaining table, senior Administration officials said tonight.

title: Budget Plan Draws Fire From Hevesi
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that the Giuliani administration's budget proposals would mean fewer home-delivered meals for the elderly, less support for companies owned by women and minorities, dirtier parks and more potholes.

title: Reviews/Pop; Rebellions Small And Many
description: One of the best videos on MTV is by Seaweed, a punk-rock band from Tacoma, Wash. In its video for "Kid Candy," from its third album, "Four" (Sub Pop), the quintet parodies Soul Asylum's overplayed video "Runaway Train." But where Soul Asylum displays photographs of missing children, Seaweed flashes pictures of missing bicycles. Such suburban irrelevance -- even to the point of tastelessness -- saturates Seaweed's melodic hard-core music and its bratty, energetic live shows.

title: Experiment in Leaner Government: 64-Page Form Becomes 8
description: Seven complex forms comprising 64 pages with which poor people request various kinds of Federal help could be reduced to eight pages or fewer under a plan announced today by former President Jimmy Carter.

title: Hot Lines Offer Help on Lead
description: Most deep private wells use submersible pumps, installed inside the well below water. Shallow wells use a different type of pump which sits on the surface.

title: Publisher Withdraws Novel
description: Responding to a complaint that "Cranes' Morning," a recent novel by the Indian author Indrani Aikath-Gyaltsen, was almost completely plagiarized from "The Rosemary Tree," a 1956 book by the English novelist Elizabeth Goudge, Ballantine Books said yesterday that it had stopped shipping "Cranes' Morning" and had ordered its sales representatives not to distribute any more copies.

title: Front-Runner for Japanese Premiership Gains as Rival Falters
description: Foreign Minister Tsutomu Hata stood on the verge of being named Japan's sixth Prime Minister in five years today when his chief rival wavered after it became clear that he did not have the votes to win.

title: Yankees Pay $715,066 to City
description: For the first time since 1991, the Yankees last week paid the city rent on Yankee Stadium, presenting the Parks Department with a check for $715,066.

title: Nixon 'Stable' After Stroke At His Home
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon suffered a stroke yesterday, and an aide said that he was conscious and in stable condition but unable to speak late last night at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Giulio Gari Is Dead; Operatic Tenor, 84
description: Giulio Gari, a tenor who sang at both the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Brick Injures Officer
description: Two teen-age boys were arrested after a police officer was struck in the head by a brick thrown through the window of a patrol car in Queens yesterday, the police said. The officer, whose name was not released, was admitted to Jamaica Hospital, but his injuries did not appear to be serious, said Officer Andrew McInnis, a spokesman for the Police Department. He said the officer was riding in the front passenger seat, his window down, when he was hit about 7 P.M. on Rockaway Beach Boulevard near 91st Street. Julio Estebes, 14, and Jason Rivera, 15, were charged with assault, reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon. Officer McInnis said they would be prosecuted as adults.

title: United-Iberia Link
description: United Airlines and Iberia Airlines of Spain announced plans today to coordinate their flight schedules and develop joint marketing programs. The combination of the carriers' route systems means better-timed connections for passengers traveling between Spain and several United States and Latin American destinations. The companies intend to start the program on July 1, said Joe Hopkins, a spokesman for United's parent company, the UAL Corporation.

title: Senator Mitchell Enters the Health Fray
description: Now that he has declined nomination to the Supreme Court, George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, is charging ahead on health reform. He has offered Democratic colleagues reasonable changes to President Clinton's bill that would cut costs for employers and taxpayers without sacrificing the goal of universal coverage. His suggestions are an encouraging sign of flexibility. But if he is to forge a workable compromise he will need to bring moderate Republicans into the conversation.

title: Nationsbank Net Falls; Chase Has a Big Rise
description: Nationsbank said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter fell 13 percent, largely because of an accounting change affecting the first quarter of 1993, while Chase Manhattan Bank said its earnings more than doubled in the first quarter, helped by a continued evaporation of its problem real estate and strong trading results.

description: Frederick Burr Opper, a retired broadcaster, foreign correspondent and editor, died on Thursday in Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. A resident of Westport, he was 82.

title: Review/Folk; Songs of the Season When Fastballs Are in Bloom
description: Why is it that a recitation of the names of Major League baseball players carries a mythic resonance that doesn't extend to lists of professional football, basketball and hockey players? That question was one of the mysteries to be pondered on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall where a program called "Baseball Blues" opened the Carnegie Hall Folk Festival, which this year is devoted to exploring Americana.
