The agencies competing for the account, with billings estimated at $2 million to $5 million, are Butler, Shine & Stern, Sausalito, Calif.; Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis; Cole & Weber, Portland, Ore.; DDB Needham Chicago, and Livingston & Co., Seattle. * Shell Cos. of China and Hong Kong to Dentsu, Young & Rubicam, Hong Kong and Shanghai, as the first agencies to handle advertising and communications for the Shell brand and Shell products in China. Dentsu, Y.& R.'s Beijing and Guangzhou offices will also work on the account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: THE 37th PRESIDENT; Federal Offices Close for Nixon
description: Congress will recess, the Supreme Court will close, regular mail delivery will be suspended and most Federal offices and financial markets will shut down tomorrow to mourn former President Richard M. Nixon, but the offices of most state governments will remain open.

title: Missing Long Island Woman Found, Well, on an Upstate Bus
description: Michelina Abbatiello, the 23-year-old Long Island woman who disappeared March 25 on the weekend of her wedding shower, was found today aboard a bus at a customs check point on the Canadian border in upstate New York. In a phone call, she told her sister she was well but was not returning home.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on April 6 about the choice of a chef for the White House and the eating habits of its past occupants misidentified Andrew Jackson's rival in the 1828 Presidential campaign. He was President John Quincy Adams, not Martin Van Buren. The article also misidentified the critic of Van Buren's fancy food habits and misstated the timing of the criticism. Representative Charles Ogle made the remarks in 1840 during President Van Buren's re-election campaign, which Van Buren lost to William Henry Harrison.

title: LeMond and Alcala Lead Field
description: Former winner GREG LeMOND, defending champion RAUL ALCALA of Mexico and 5 of the world's top 10 teams will compete in next month's Tour DuPont bicycle race, organizers of the event said yesterday. A field of 16 teams with seven riders each and representing 19 countries was confirmed for the $300,000 event, which begins May 4 in Wilmington, Del. LeMond, the three-time Tour de France winner, won the Tour DuPont in 1992, his first United States stage race victory in seven years. (AP)

description: In an emotional appearance at the White House today, President Clinton renewed his longstanding call for a ban on assault weapons and pledged to enlist his Cabinet in the lobbying battle when the ban comes up for a House vote early next month.

title: Uncovered Short Sales on Nasdaq Show a Small Decline
description: Investors who bet on falling stock prices are finally cashing in a few chips -- probably because prices have indeed dropped.

title: John C. Russell; Playwright, 31
description: John C. Russell, a playwright whose works appeared in Off Broadway theaters in New York City, died on Friday in New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 31 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hearst Book Head Resigns
description: Howard Kaminsky, president of the Hearst Corporation's troubled Trade Book Group, resigned yesterday, citing personal matters that have forced him to be away from the office for much of the time.

title: Boy Held in Derailment
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy has been arrested in the derailment of a Long Island Rail Road train that injured three passengers last month, the railroad said yesterday. The unidentified teen-ager from South Ozone Park was charged with criminal mischief, criminal tampering and reckless endangerment and is scheduled for an appearance in Queens Family Court on May 15.

title: At Least 4 Die In Tornadoes Near Dallas
description: A storm system that lashed through the central United States late Monday and early today left its most severe trail of destruction here, with three people dead and the brick buildings and majestic live oaks of the Reconstruction-era town square blown to ruins. A fourth person in a nearby town died of a heart attack as he sat out the tornado in his storm cellar.

title: People
description: * Lawrence L. Logan was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director for the Oswego Co., Portland, Ore. He was previously a vice president and creative director for the Playboy Entertainment Group, Los Angeles. * Tom Chung was named to the new position of executive creative director for Lee Liu & Tong Advertising, New York. He was previously an art supervisor for McCann-Erickson Direct, New York.

title: An Effort To Classify A Racist Classic
description: Like an orator who says all the wrong things brilliantly, "The Birth of a Nation," D. W. Griffith's 1915 epic, manages to thrill and appall at the same time. The film, formally innovative and daring, has influenced directors from Sergei Eisenstein to Francis Ford Coppola. But its unashamedly racist depiction of Reconstruction has made it one of the most troubling masterworks in American cinema.

title: Alliance Entertainment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net lossThe company attributed its latest quarter earnings to recent acquisitions and internal growth. The company acquired CD One Stop, a wholesale distrbutor of recorded music, in October 1993 and Abbey Road Distributors in February 1994. The company said Abbey Road's results are only partly reflected in its 1994 first quarter from Feb. 4 to March 31.(Loss)

title: CHEVRON CORP. (CHV:N)
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings declined 23 percent because of lower prices for crude oil and higher operating costs at its refineries.

title: Starks Takes Court and Looks Like Starks of Old
description: John Starks returned to practice with the Knicks today and participated at full speed. It was another indication that he will be ready to make an impact in the playoff opener against the Nets Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Cray Research (CYR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Threat Doesn't Faze Graf
description: STEFFI GRAF returned to the tennis court in Hamburg, Germany, where her rival MONICA SELES was stabbed last year, and easily defeated SILKE FRANKL, 6-0, 6-0, in the opening round of the Citizen Cup yesterday.

title: Democracy Won
description: Just before Nelson Mandela debated President F. W. de Klerk earlier this month, I asked one of Mr. Mandela's advisers, "Are you nervous?"

title: Wage Increases Are Small but Confidence Jumps
description: American workers are obtaining less in pay and benefit increases from employers these days, but they seem ever more optimistic, two surveys indicated today.

title: Stirring Up Simplicity With Chinese Noodles and Vegetables
description: MUCH is made of the simplicity of Italian pasta dishes, but their Chinese counterparts are, if anything, quicker and easier to prepare.

title: A Different Take on the 'Myth' of Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Rainy Prologue to Subdued Funeral for Nixon
description: In a scene worthy of "King Lear," the usually sunny California sky unleashed thunder, lightning, rain and hail today as Richard M. Nixon's body returned to his birthplace in a plain wooden coffin covered by a flag.

title: Cuomo Details Compromise Proposed in Budget Talks
description: In an unusual bargaining tactic, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo released details today about a compromise plan intended to revive the stalled negotiations over the $33 billion state budget, which is now 26 days late.

title: Whitewater Inquiry Lengthening, Officials Say
description: The call came through this morning on Federal Bureau of Investigation teletypes around the nation: Wanted -- agents with accounting and white-collar experience for the Little Rock, Ark., office.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEPHEN J. SOLARZ, the former Congressman from Brooklyn, will return to academia in the fall after a hiatus of 27 years. He has been named the J. B. and Maurice C. Shapiro Professor of International Affairs at George Washington University in Washington. He will teach foreign policy for a year starting in September.

title: A Positive Note in U.S.-Japanese Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: China Says Blast Won't Slow Satellite Launchings
description: China's space launching agency said today that a blast on April 2 that killed one person and injured 20 would not delay the launching of three foreign communications satellites this year.

title: Curbing Rowdy Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: SERBS COMPLYING WITH NATO DEMAND ON ARMS PULLOUT
description: The Bosnian Serb army has complied with a NATO ultimatum for the withdrawal of its heavy weapons beyond 20 kilometers from Gorazde, apparently insuring that there will be no NATO bombardment of Serbian positions there, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Rape Charges Reinstated Against Five
description: A state judge reinstated rape charges today against five men who admitted having sex with a woman who had passed out after drinking too much in an upstate restaurant.

title: Residents Flee Haitian Town After Killings
description: Hundreds of residents have fled a coastal slum area in Gonaives after what human rights activists and local residents said was one of the worst instances of violence by the military since it seized power in a coup two and a half years ago.

title: Tambrands Finally Gets A New Chief
description: After nearly a year without a commander in chief, troubled Tambrands Inc. named a president and chief executive: Edward T. Fogarty, who now leads the domestic division of the Colgate-Palmolive Company.

title: New York City Isn't Playing Favorites on the Coliseum Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Cuomo's Sensible Budget Plan
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York proposed a reasonable compromise yesterday to end a legislative deadlock of almost a month over the state budget. The plan does not cut taxes as much as the Republican-controlled Senate wants, or pick up all the local costs of Medicaid -- the program of medical insurance for the poor -- that the Democratic-controlled Assembly wants. But over all, the Governor has proposed a budget that ought to be acceptable to every part of the state.

title: Accounts
description: * Provident Health Care Plans, Chattanooga, Tenn., to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, to handle its account, to be shared with Provident's in-house communications department. Billings were estimated to exceed $1 million in the first year.

title: Day of Mourning
description: Today has been declared a day of mourning for Richard M. Nixon. NEW YORK

title: Foundation Health Corp.(FH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago 9 months included a restructuring provision of $ 12.4 million.

title: THE 37TH PRESIDENT: In School; Remembering Nixon? For some students, he might as well be George Washington.
description: America's high school seniors were born after Richard M. Nixon resigned. Ronald Reagan is the first President most remember. These students expect Presidents to be involved in scandals. The three Presidents they've seen have all been accused of cover-ups and lying.

title: Ball Corp.(BLL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: b-Net loss and after a gain from discontinued operations of $ 2,100,000, or 8 cents a share, and a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 34,700,000, or $ 1.29 a share.(Loss)

title: Council Panel Passes Bill On Privatization Oversight
description: A City Council committee passed a measure yesterday that would allow the Council to conduct hearings on the Mayor's efforts to turn city services over to private companies.

title: Bridge Column
description: The Bridge column now appears on Mondays, Thursdays and Saturdays. The location is shown at the bottom of the News Summary on page 2 of the first section.

title: C.I.A. Officer Takes Deal For Life Term in Spy Case
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Aldrich H. Ames on charges of spying for Moscow as the career C.I.A. officer signed a plea agreement accepting life in prison without parole in return for leniency for his wife, people involved in the case said.

title: Saab Prices Convertible
description: Saab Cars U.S.A. Inc. said yesterday that the price of its all-new Saab 900 convertible would start at $31,990 for the S model and $37,990 for the SE version. When equipped with an optional 2.5-liter V6 engine, the SE version will cost $38,490, the United States importer of the Swedish-built cars said. The 1995 model convertibles will go on sale in July.

title: 13 Addy Awards For DeVito/Verdi
description: DeVito/Verdi took top honors last night at the 1994 Best of New York Addy Awards presentation, sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York.

title: For Devils, It Was a Night to Remember
description: Should this Devils team go a long way in the Stanley Cup playoffs, the signature game will be No. 5 against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Mogilny Aide Pleads Guilty
description: A Russian who helped the Buffalo Sabres' ALEXANDER MOGILNY defect from the Soviet Union has pleaded guilty to a menacing charge involving the player, whom he was accused of threatening in an extortion attempt. SERGUEI FOMITCHEV, 31, agreed to the plea on a lesser charge to avoid a long wait in jail for an extortion trial and a possible prison term of up to seven years, his lawyer, ROBERT RIORDAN, said yesterday in Buffalo.

title: Justices Limit '91 Rights Law To New Cases
description: In decisions ending a divisive chapter in Federal civil rights law, the Supreme Court voted 8 to 1 today against applying the Civil Rights Act of 1991 retroactively to thousands of cases pending when the law was passed.

title: Big Little Who Got Big Help
description: LOOKING back over his 81 years Ted Miller has to say that stealing the cue sticks from the burned down pool hall on Westchester Avenue in the Bronx when he was 10 years old was one of the better things that happened to him. Not the stealing, but the getting caught.

title: Theater in Review
description: Promiscuous Downtown Art Company 64 East Fourth Street East Village Through May 8 Directed by Brian Jucha; lighting by Roma Flowers; costumes by Kasia WalickaMaimone; choreographic consultant, Rocky Bornstein. Presented by Downtown Art Company.

title: The Spy Who Came Into the Classroom Teaches at Boston U.
description: Prof. Lawrence Martin-Bittman, a former Czechoslovak spy and propagandist now teaching at Boston University, threw himself an unusual party this semester.

title: EG&G Inc.(EGG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: b-Net loss and after a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 20,500,000, or 36 a share.(Loss)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES, Houston, has won a five-year $60 million contract to dispose of solid waste at 67 Ford Motor locations in Michigan. DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO., New York, said that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to four million shares.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Friday listing the American Stock Exchange's uncovered short sales for the month ended April 15, compared with those for the month ended March 15, included erroneous figures for Wilshire Technologies Inc. and Xytronyx Inc. The short interest in Wilshire's stock was 505,668 shares in April, down from 524,555 shares in March. The short interest in Xytronyx's stock was 132,872 shares, down from 142,700.

title: Executone Information Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 604,000 on the sale of Vodavi Communications Systems and income from discontinued operations of $ 153,000.c-Included loss of $ 123,000 from discontinued operations.Results for the earlier quarter have been restated to reflect Vodavi Communications Systems, which the company sold as of March 31, as a discontinued operation.

title: Review/Dance; In 'Swan Lake,' a Tribute to Many Masters, but Mainly One
description: Tchaikovsky wrote three ballet scores, and all are downright terrific. How else to explain the popularity, for instance, of "Swan Lake," which made for a splendid opening of American Ballet Theater's spring season on Monday night?

title: What Looks Like an Apricot and Sounds Like a Kumquat?
description: ASK New Yorkers about loquats, and they typically reply, "Is that like a kumquat?" But ask natives of southern Spain or Sicily, and they respond with a dreamy smile, savoring memories of this first fruit of spring, a delicate, delicious forerunner of plums and apricots.

title: Carillon and Agency To Give to Charities
description: Carillon Importers Ltd. and its new agency, Margeotes Fertitta Donaher & Weissof New York, are seeking to do well by doing good, donating to 16 charities about $500,000, which they said would have otherwise gone to buy print advertisements for Stolichnaya vodka.

title: Tel Aviv Journal; 'I Do' With a Difference (and a Different Rabbi)
description: When Dana Gerner decided to marry Guy Aharon, she resolved to steer clear of Israel's Orthodox rabbinate, which legally sanctions and performs Jewish marriages in Israel.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: First American Financial Corp.(FAF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 4,200,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: Market Place; Wall Street is closed to honor a bear market President.
description: WHEN Richard M. Nixon was elected President in 1968, there was general pleasure on Wall Street. According to the prevailing wisdom of the time, his election marked a return to traditional economic policies and good news for the stock market.

title: DeVry Inc.(DVRY,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
In This Corner, Giants' Cupboard Is Bare
description: The Giants knew this was probably going to happen, so when Mark Collins signed a four-year deal with the Kansas City Chiefs yesterday worth between $6 million and $7 million, it wasn't a surprise.

title: Eating Well
description: LET'S see. Two years ago Americans were told to forget the four food groups and learn about the new Eating Right Pyramid. Created by the Federal Government, it suggested that they eat less meat and more fruits, vegetables and grains.

title: George Oliver Dies; Polo Star Was 83
description: George Oliver, a leading professional polo player from the 1930's to the 1960's, died yesterday at his home in Sparta, N.C. He was 83.

title: Rheaume Joins Roller Team
description: MANON RHEAUME, the first woman to play on a men's professional hockey team, will broaden her resume this summer as a goaltender for the New Jersey Rockin Rollers of Roller Hockey International, a league that began last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Accused Spy Agrees to Plea

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday about Amy Seidl, who studies a rare butterfly species, referred incorrectly in some copies to the university where she is a graduate student. It is Colorado State, not the University of Colorado.

title: Morgan Stanley Abroad
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said this week that it had opened an office in Sydney, Australia, and that it planned to open an office in Johannesburg in July. The global financial services company opened its first Australian office in Melbourne in 1985. The move into Johannesburg will make Morgan Stanley the latest Wall Street company to resume business dealings in South Africa as the country dismantles its system of apartheid.

title: Sports of The Times; Koss Still Carrying The Torch
description: THEY snuffed out the flame on the mountainside. The trolls disappeared under the rocks. The tourists bought their last sweaters and went home. But Johann Olav Koss is still using the Olympic glow to help other people.

title: ACX Technologies Inc.(ACXT,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AMP Inc.(AMP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Deaf Students Protest New School Head
description: The jets screaming by at treetop level might have spoiled another demonstration, but they were not a distraction yesterday. The students protesting outside the Lexington School for the Deaf were chanting in American Sign Language, and they had no trouble communicating with one another.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON, who has been out of the public spotlight since reaching a settlement with the family of a 14-year-old boy who had accused him of sexual molestation, is scheduled to appear in New York tomorrow at the City Center. He is to pick up an award from Body Sculpt, an organization that uses body building to persuade schoolchildren to avoid drugs and remain in school.

title: Review/Film; A Corrosive Comedy Of Hip-Hop Manners
description: "Martin Lawrence: You So Crazy" is a film for people who think Beavis and Butt-head are genteel wimps. The stand-up comedy in this concert film is raunchy, sexually graphic, intermittently funny and, because of a ratings skirmish, already semi-notorious. When the film was given an NC-17 rating, it was dropped by its distributor, Miramax. It is now being released without a rating by the Samuel Goldwyn Company.

title: A Step Toward Gift Reform
description: Yesterday the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee took an important step toward cleaning up a long-festering Congressional scandal: the gifts that lobbyists and other powerful interests give to lawmakers.

title: Visions of Weaning Americans From Nicotine
description: ANTISMOKING forces in Washington, gaining momentum in Congress in recent weeks, have begun to imagine America with strict regulation of cigarettes.

title: Kidnappers Seize a 2d Mexican Executive
description: A prominent Mexican businessman has been kidnapped, the second in six weeks, adding to the climate of uncertainty in Mexico even as a new national office to prevent crime was being created.

title: It's the Bitter Truth: Flavor Can Be Painful
description: REMEMBER the Tongue Map? There it sat, a disembodied organ on the pages of high school science textbooks, neatly divided into tiny states labeled "sweet" or "sour" or "salt" or "bitter." It was just bizarre enough to stick in the mind and give most Americans an idea of how taste works.

title: Nixon's Funeral
description: President Nixon's funeral service will begin at 7 P.M. Eastern time. It is expected to last about an hour. This is the tentative program of speakers. ABC, CBS, NBC, PBS, CNN and C-Span plan live coverage. The Rev. Billy Graham, officiant

title: Cilcorp Inc.(CER,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Condemned Can't Vote, But Share Desire to Live
description: An obviously weakened Blom Pule could barely muster enthusiasm for South Africa's first free election, attributing his mood less to the debilitation of a recent hunger strike than to his vantage point in death row.

title: When it comes to ad spending, executives don't expect much of a sting from inflation.
description: THE Federal Reserve Board keeps raising interest rates because of fears that inflation will harm the economy. But in the media, the potential for inflation does not seem so menacing.

title: Clinton Proposes Revising Pesticide Regulations
description: The Clinton Administration today offered a proposal for rewriting two laws that control pesticides in food. But its prospects in Congress are uncertain because neither industry nor environmental groups support the Administration's approach.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about Richard M. Nixon's Presidential tapes and papers referred incorrectly in some editions to the legal effort to control their release. While suits filed by Mr. Nixon will continue after his death, they have not been joined by his heirs.

title:
Real Estate;
A Family Hopes To Net $60 Million By Converting A Boston Property Company Into A Real Estate Trust
description: THE Beacon Companies, a 48-year-old Boston development, construction and management enterprise, is seeking to transform itself into a real estate investment trust, or REIT.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Hallmark Cards Inc., the greeting card company, has agreed to pay $365 million cash for RHI Entertainment Inc., the largest producer and distributor of television movies and mini-series, the companies said yesterday.

title: After All the Buildup, the Vote Is a Visual Letdown
description: Charged though South Africa's first multiracial election is with history and portent, it has so far produced no made-for-television extravaganza.

title: 261 Die When a Flight From Taiwan Crashes in Japan
description: At least 261 people died Tuesday night when a Taiwan jet crashed on landing at Nagoya Airport and burst into flames. It was the second-worst airline disaster in Japan's history.

title: 100 Quadrillion Calculations Later, Eureka!
description: An international effort to crack a tough mathematical problem has succeeded, researchers said yesterday. The problem has stood out as a challenge to computer scientists for 17 years because it was linked to a popular coding system and was said to be proof of the system's security.

title: CITIBANK TO USE PHILIPS ELECTRONICS FOR HOME BANKING
description: Citibank said yesterday that it had signed a contract with a unit of Philips Electronics N. V. that would allow Citibank's customers to do banking at home with a telephone featuring a computer screen and a pull-out keyboard. Citibank will offer the Philips P100 Screen Phone first to its customers in metropolitan New York, where Citibank has been testing a similar system of its own in about 400 to 500 households. The P100 allows customers to perform most bank transactions -- except withdrawing cash -- from their homes with a personal access code and a special plastic card.

title: Study Sees Overuse Of Ear Operation
description: AN evaluation of more than 6,000 children scheduled to have tubes placed in their ears to combat recurrent ear infections indicates that the procedure is inappropriate in about one-quarter of cases and of questionable benefit in another third. The children in the study ranged in age from 22 days to 16 years.

title: Officers on Streets Before Screening Is Completed
description: New York City's Police Department routinely gives rookie officers their badges and guns and puts them on the streets before their background checks are complete, officials investigating police corruption have determined.

title: Rwanda Aide Calls Truce 'Last Chance'
description: Rebels who control half of Rwanda have said that the four-day cease-fire they began on Monday would not stop their drive to "liberate" the country and punish those responsible for the deaths of more than 100,000 people in the last three weeks.

title: Tribute to Graham At Next Wave Festival
description: A two-week tribute to the groundbreaking early work of Martha Graham, the American premiere of Philip Glass's latest opera, "La Belle et la Bete," and the American premiere of Pina Bausch's dance "Two Cigarettes in the Dark" are among the highlights of the 12th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Public & Private; Living Will
description: It is difficult not to imagine that the last 20 years of his life had been leading up to this week, this day, this moment. And as he had so many times before, against all odds, with many setbacks, Richard Nixon won. Today he will be laid to rest amid a wave of revisionist history that has rendered him almost unrecognizable, like one of those pastel portraits done by street artists, all the harsh features smoothed away, designed to flatter and to sell.

title: Karl Hess, a Republican Aide Who Became an Anarchist, 70
description: Karl Hess, an anarchist who was once a conservative aide in the Republican Party, died on Friday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. Mr. Hess, who lived in Kearneysville, W. Wa., was 70.

title: Breed Technologies Inc.(BDT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BURLINGTON RESOURCES TO BUY MAXUS'S STAKE
description: Burlington Resources Inc. will pay $375 million to acquire oil and gas properties from the Maxus Energy Corporation of Dallas, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Burlington Resources will buy Maxus's 87 percent stake in Diamond Shamrock Offshore Partnerships L.P. for $287.4 million. It will also acquire other properties from Maxus. Burlington Resources, based in Seattle, will pay $4.48 a unit in cash for the Diamond Shamrock Offshore units. They closed yesterday at $4.50, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 6 Montclair Teen-Agers Cleared of Sexual Assault Charges
description: Six Montclair, N.J., teen-agers accused last June of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old seventh grader have been cleared of all charges against them by a New Jersey Family Court judge in Newark.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Business Technology

title: No Headline
description: "Today marks the dawn of our freedom." NELSON MANDELA [ A1:3. ]

title: UConn's Marshall to Go Pro
description: A little more than a month after he missed two last-second free throws that resulted in Connecticut's elimination from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the all-America forward Donyell Marshall announced that he would forgo his senior year to play in the National Basketball Association.

title: New Jersey Nuclear Plant Faulted for Series of Flaws
description: The alert at a nuclear plant in New Jersey on April 7 was caused by a combination of design flaws, operator errors and longstanding equipment problems that made the operators' jobs harder, a team of inspectors from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission reported yesterday.

title: Baxter International (BAX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 70,000,000, or 25 cents a share.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 57,000,000, or 20 cents a share, included 23 cents a share in after-tax costs of litigation.

description: b-Net loss and after a charge which reflects effect of an accounting change for post-retirement benefits of $ 130,800,000, or $ 5.66 a share.(Loss)

title: Continental Medical Systems Inc.(CNM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months included merger expenses of 5 cents a share and 4 cents a share, respectively, for the acquisition of Kron Medical Corp.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on March 31 described the robbery and killing of a manager of a Brooklyn plumbing supply store. The first paragraph said that witnesses -- whom it did not identify -- saw the manager, Marvin Wildstein, fall to his knees and plead for his life before he was shot.

title: Amid Swirl of Activity, a Woman Is Raped in Prospect Park
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn woman walking on a path in a wooded area of Prospect Park was grabbed from behind and raped yesterday afternoon, unnoticed by bicyclists, joggers and motorists passing nearby, park and police officials said.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Hip-Hop Night

title: Enserch Corp.(ENS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Senior Executive at I.B.M. Steps Down Unexpectedly
description: Gerald M. Czarnecki, a senior I.B.M. executive who joined the computer company less than a year ago, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

title: Miscellany
description: * Grizzard, Atlanta, has spun off a direct-marketing division, called Grizzard/The Agency Team. * Network Television Association, New York, formed an advisory council made up of 19 executives who represent advertisers and agencies including Johnson & Johnson, Walt Disney, Clorox, BBDO, Leo Burnett and Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL IN HOSTILE BID FOR INSURER
description: Fidelity National Financial Inc. began a hostile takeover of the U S Facilities Corporation yesterday with an offer of $15 a share in cash, or $79 million. Fidelity, an Irvine, Calif., title insurer, also offered an alternative in which it would pay $15 a share in cash for half of U S Facilities' shares outstanding and pay for the rest with a tax-free swap of Fidelity common stock worth $15 a share. U S Facilities, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., sells medical stop-loss and property and casualty insurance. Company officials declined to comment on the offer, saying that its board would meet this week to discuss it. Shares of U S Facilities rose $2.5625, to $13.5625, in Nasdaq trading, where its 23.3 percent gain was the fourth-best of the day.

title: Coastal Corp.(CGP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Tenneco to Offer 35% of J.I. Case
description: Tenneco Inc. announced today that it planned to sell at least 35 percent of its J. I. Case subsidiary, one of the world's largest farm and construction equipment companies, through an initial public offering of stock.

Coca-Cola Bottling Consolid.  (COKE,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,211,000, or 24 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.c-Net income(Loss)

title: CompUSA Inc.(CPU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
description: b-Included $ 9,918,000 in restructuring costs.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Teamsters' Fate Could Hang On Outcome of Truck Strike
description: As a strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters lumbers into its fourth week with little sign of cooperation at the negotiating table, the nation's longest trucking strike is shaping up as a test of the union's future.

title: A Different Take on the 'Myth' of Inflation; The Debt Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: AT WORK WITH: George Fowler; Twists and Turns of a Religious Life
description: ASK people in this buckle of the Bible Belt their opinion of George Fowler and they either roll their eyes to the heavens or stammer for words to describe him.

title: Wine Talk
description: BECAUSE of my position on wine prices over the years, this column is regularly cited by consumers who believe that for too long, wine has cost too much in far too many restaurants.

title: James Corbett, 65, Professor of Physics At SUNY in Albany
description: Dr. James William Corbett, a researcher in semiconductor and solid-state physics, died on Monday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 65 and lived in nearby East Berne.

title: A Promising Glimpse in Harlem
description: At some experimental programs in inner-city and rural schools, educators are finding evidence that advanced technology has the potential to put students of different backgrounds on a more equal footing. In these programs, teachers report that many students who use computer networks have shown a new enthusiasm for learning and have improved their test scores.

title: Donald Atwood, 69, No. 2 at Pentagon During Bush Years
description: Donald Jesse Atwood, a retired vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation and Deputy Secretary of Defense in the Bush Administration, died on Sunday in a hospital in Royal Oaks, Ill. He was 69 and lived in Franklin, Mich., a Detroit suburb.

title: Stock Market Is Listless in Slow Trading
description: The stock market closed essentially unchanged yesterday despite factors that ought to have prompted a rally, notably a drop in long-term interest rates and fresh employment data that indicated inflation was still under control.

title: Arbour Absent as Autopsy Begins
description: Still numbed, still embarrassed and still shocked by a season that ended with a shower of whisk brooms on the Nassau Coliseum ice Sunday in sarcastic commemoration of the Rangers' masterly four-game playoff sweep, Islander General Manager Don Maloney was right back on the job today.

title: German Rebound Predicted
description: Germany's economy is beginning to rebound from one of its worst recessions of the postwar era and a full-fledged recovery should start in the second half of this year, the nation's six leading economic research institutes said today.

title: Corrections
description: The futures markets table in Business Day yesterday, in some editions, omitted futures contracts for two-year Treasury notes, five-year Treasury notes, ten-year Treasury notes, Treasury bonds, crude oil, unleaded gasoline, heating oil and platinum. Readers wishing corrected copies of the table may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Blocking Shots Beats A Room in a Hospital
description: Two days, 99 saves, and two dramatic playoff victories removed from an ill-timed visit to Montreal General Hospital, North America's best-known appendicitis patient sounded as if he was beginning to surprise himself.

title: Computers in School: Equal Access Sought
description: As the nation moves beyond today's computers and communications toward the so-called information highway, the Clinton Administration and growing numbers of educators and lawmakers contend that the Government must insure equal access to technology for rich and poor.

title: Mandate for Human Dignity
description: The question that most worries the lame-duck whites whose monopoly began seeping into history today, and privately worries the next Government, too, is couched in cautionary phrases about "unrealistic expectations."

title: Publishers Look Hard At Content of Papers
description: After years of blaming things like declining literacy rates and increasing competition from television for the problems of American newspapers, the publishers of the country's big dailies have turned to a new culprit: their own publications.

title: Moorer Rejects Idea of Unification
description: In the afterglow of his triumph Friday over Evander Holyfield, Michael Moorer is reluctant and evasive about topics ranging from unifying the heavyweight division in a fight against Lennox Lewis to his future as a boxer.

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp.(BS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: U.S. to Aid Industry In Computer Battle With the Japanese
description: In the biggest Government help for private industry since an effort to assist computer chip makers began seven years ago, the White House has approved a proposal to spend up to $1 billion on American companies competing with Japan in making advanced flat-panel computer display screens.

title: Newman Is Feather in Reed's Cap
description: When Johnny Newman came to New Jersey last Dec. 10 in a trade with the Hornets for Rumeal Robinson, he was just glad to be out of Charlotte and back in the metropolitan area.

title: Interest Rates Continue to Decline
description: Interest rates dropped yesterday for second time this week and the sixth time in seven sessions on continuing evidence that the economy is not expanding so rapidly as some may have thought.

title: Food Notes
description: From Seattle to New York

title: Industrial Lands Invite Russian Cooperation on Political Issues
description: The Group of Seven industrial countries will invite Russia to work formally with them as they develop positions on a range of political issues, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.

title: List of Overseas Guests for Nixon's Funeral Is Short
description: Although international relations dominated Richard M. Nixon's long career, no foreign heads of state or government are expected for his funeral Wednesday at the library his friends built on the site of the failed citrus orchard where he grew up.

title: Fiserv Inc.(FISV,NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Personal Health
description: SPRING, the season of weekend warriors, is also prime time for injured shoulders. As golfers take to the green, tennis players to the courts, baseball players to the field, swimmers to the water and do-it-yourselfers to the paint brush and tree-trimmer, many also take it on the shoulder. For while the shoulder is the body's most talented joint, it is also inherently unstable and, after the knee, it is the most vulnerable link between bone and bone.

title: 4 Defendants Ask Lawyers Be Changed
description: With a week to go before sentencing, all four men convicted in the World Trade Center bombing have dismissed their defense lawyers and asked to be represented by William F. Kunstler and Ronald L. Kuby, the flamboyant legal team known for its support of radical political causes.

title: In New York, It's a Dream Come True
description: Far from the squalor of her native Soweto, history caught up with Moli Ntuli yesterday as she nervously inched toward a tent pitched on the north lawn of the United Nations Plaza in Manhattan. Once inside, the 49-year-old Ms. Ntuli did something she had only been permited to do in her waking dreams.

title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Co.  (CYM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included income of $ 8,800,000, or 10 cents a share, from earnings of oil and gas business, which the company sold to Union Pacific Resources Co. for $ 819 million in proceeds on March 31.c-Included charge of $ 19 million from effects of ''record heavy rain'' and flooding at the company's Arizona copper operations, and gain of $ 16 million from partial sale of LTV Steel Co. bankruptcy claim.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: DISNEY (WALT) CO. (DIS,N)
description: The Walt Disney Company reported record second-quarter profit yesterday, buoyed by strong domestic and international sales of classic and animated home videos and consumer products. Top performers were "The Fox and the Hound" in domestic home video and "The Jungle Book" and "Bambi" in foreign home video.

title: Adams Resources & Energy Inc.(AE,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Review/Television; An Islamic Indictment of the West
description: "Beirut to Bosnia" attributes the rise in Islamic fundamentalism and terrorism to the West's betrayal of Muslims. It is a contentious proposition and probably simplistic, but on tonight's evidence, there is enough to it to compel attention.

title: Engelhard Corp.(EC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on sale of investment of $ 6,290,000, or 6 cents a share, and a charge from adoption of FAS 112, accounting for post-employment benefits of $ 16,000,000, or 16 cents a share.Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 split Sept. 30, 1993.

title: Dishes for Grain-Lovers-Come-Lately
description: IN this country, grains have long been seen as dowdy. Although that's changing because of health concerns and the relentless search for new tastes and textures, other cultures have as much expertise with cooking and eating grains as Americans have naivete.

title: Clinton Forces Out U.S. Envoy to Haiti To Display Resolve
description: The Clinton Administration forced its special envoy to Haiti to step down today in a move aimed at deflecting criticism and showing that it is serious about coming up with a new policy.

title: B.A.T. Is Buying U.S. Rival
description: In a move that would strengthen its position as the nation's third-biggest tobacco company, B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the American Tobacco Company from American Brands for $1 billion in cash.

title: Irgun Joins Long List of Derby Casualties
description: The Kentucky Derby lost one of its brightest stars yesterday when a sore right foot forced the withdrawal of Irgun, the speed horse who won the Gotham Stakes and the Wood Memorial and was considered the main threat to duel the favored Holy Bull.

title: UNC OFFERS $105 MILLION FOR SMALL-ENGINE BUSINESS
description: UNC Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to buy Aviall Inc.'s small-engine repair businesses for $105 million, topping a competing offer of $89 million from a newly formed venture called Dallas Automotive. Aviall, based in Dallas, put the businesses up for sale in June 1993 as part of a plan to be spun off from Ryder System Inc., said Gregory M. Bubb, UNC's vice president and treasurer. The spinoff was completed in December. UNC, based in Annapolis, Md., is a manufacturer of airplane engines.

title: Most U.S. Markets Closed Today
description: Most financial markets in the United States will be closed today in memory of former President Richard M. Nixon, who died on Friday.

title: Airborne Freight Corp.(ABF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 3,828,000, or 20 cents a share.

title: The Talk of London; Opera of the Phantoms: Ghouls and Zombies Haunt the London Stage
description: The earth may be on the far side of the sun from Halloween just now, but four days of attending operas and plays in London suggested that shape-shifting spirits, ghosts, fairies, medieval enchantresses and singing headless knights have found new favor in the British capital. It must have something to do with Tory arts policies.

title: CRAY RESEARCH'S STOCK FALLS ON SIGN OF WEAK ORDERS
description: Shares of Cray Research Inc. dropped 16.6 percent yesterday after the maker of supercomputers reported weak first-quarter orders. The stock fell $4.25, to $21.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its percentage decline was the worst of the day. Monday night, Cray reported its best first-quarter earnings per share since 1980. But analysts said investors instead focused on the net contract value of orders signed in the first quarter, which fell to $59 million from $124 million. In a conference call with analysts yesterday, company officials predicted that orders would recover in the current quarter.

title: U.N. Mediator Rebuked
description: A senior Clinton Administration official publicly rebuked Mr. Akashi, the United Nations mediator, today for criticizing America's refusal to send peacekeeping soldiers there and warned that such remarks would make it harder to win Congressional support for peacekeeping.

title: Mother of King Of Jordan Is Dead at 86
description: Queen Zein al-Sharaf, the mother of King Hussein of Jordan and in past years an influential figure behind the scenes in his turbulent realm, died yesterday in a hospital in Lausanne, Switzerland. She was 86, the Reuters news agency reported, and had lived in Amman, Jordan.

title: American General Corp.(AGC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 45,909,000, or 21 cents a share.Revenue represented revenues and deposits.

title: Astral Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Eastman Kodak (EK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 12,000,000, or 4 cents a share, from costs associated with early call of Liquid Yield Option Notes on April 1.c-Net loss and after a gain from discontinued operations of $ 55,000,000, or 17 cents a share and a net charge of $ 2,168,000,000, or $ 6.64 a share, which included $ 1,723,000,000 charge for cumulative effect of changes in accounting for continuing operations, and $ 445,000,000 charge for cumulative effect of changes in accounting for discontinued operations.Eastman Kodak said results for 1993 have been restated to reflect the spin-off of Eastman Chemical Co. and do not include the cumulative effect from the adoption of new accounting standards for postemployment benefits.(Loss)

title: 261 Die as Airliner Crashes in Landing Near Japan Airport
description: An Airbus A300 from Taiwan crashed near the runway last night while trying to land in Nagoya, Japan, killing 261 people. Only 10 people survived.

title: Computervision Corp.(CVN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: A Cozy Bed for Salmon
description: THE ingredients for the bed on which a simply grilled piece of salmon is presented fulfill many of the components of a well-constructed dish: sweet and bitter, crunchy and silken. The accompanying rice is greatly enlivened by the addition of asparagus, fennel, chives and garlic. Salmon on a Bed of Greens And Mango

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: No Word on Impact Of Tobacco Deal
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that it was too soon to comment on the advertising or agency ramifications, if any, of its proposed purchase of the American Tobacco Company from American Brands.

title: A.L. to Name President From College Ranks
description: Gene Budig, the chancellor of the University of Kansas, has won the recommendation of a search committee to be the next president of the American League, two executives familiar with the committee's deliberations said yesterday.

title: SHARES OF UNUM PLUNGE ON REPORT OF INFLUX OF CLAIMS
description: Shares of the UNUM Corporation traded as much as $7.25 lower after the company said that net income rose in the first quarter but that it had more large claims. The stock closed down $4.25, or 7.8 percent, at $50.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading as low as $47 earlier. UNUM, based in Portland, Me., said its net income rose 20 percent. But the company said its disability insurance earnings were hurt by an influx of claims late in the quarter, more large claims and low interest rates.

title: AK Steel Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said it will report extraordinary charges of $ 17.5 million on the year for early payment of debt.(Loss)

title: INTERDIGITAL STOCK SOARS ON NEWS OF AT&T PATENT DEAL
description: Shares of the Interdigital Communications Corporation surged 28.1 percent yesterday after the company signed a patent agreement with the AT&T Corporation. Interdigital shares rose $1.125, to $5.125, on the American Stock Exchange, where the stock's percentage gain was the second best of the day. Interdigital, which is based in King of Prussia, Pa., said on Monday that it had signed an agreement that calls for AT&T to pay an initial $2.4 million royalty fee and future royalties to use patents for two digital wireless technologies. The patent agreement is Interdigital's first with a large telecommunications company.

title: Thriving in What Was the Soviet Silicon Valley
description: Even for those who believe in fairy tales, the story of a computer software company in this Caucasus republic can leave one laughing in disbelief.

title: 'Wise Use' Movement Is Anti-Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Lee Mazzilli's Cafe

title: Overreacting to Asia's Naval Race
description: Even as defense budgets shrink around most of the globe, a naval arms race is under way in Asia. Many navies in the region are buying newer and better-armed ships, though none have yet acquired formidable fleets capable of attacking other nations far from their shores.

title: After 300 Years, Blacks Vote in South Africa
description: Throngs of elderly and infirm voters came forward in the predawn Tuesday to sweep aside three centuries of white racist rule and euphorically open the first fully democratic elections in South Africa.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Lawmakers Express Interest In Taxing Health Benefits
description: Members of Congress expressed interest today in limiting tax breaks for health insurance. But labor unions denounced such proposals as a new tax on middle-income workers, and tax lawyers said it would be extremely difficult to measure the value of any benefits that might be taxed.

title: A Surge in Earnings at Capital Cities/ABC
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter nearly doubled to $116.08 million, or $7.56 a share, from $58.37 million, or $3.55 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenue was up 19 percent, to $1.404 billion.

title: Public Unions Challenge Whitman on Pension Security
description: Admitting they're trying to play catch up to the new administration's changing fiscal policies, leaders of unions representing teachers and state employees today attacked Governor Christine Todd Whitman's plan to reduce state payments for pensions by more than $1 billion in order to balance the budget and help pay for tax cuts.

title: Day of Remembrance
description: As a tribute to former President Richard M. Nixon, Congress and the Supreme Court are in recess today, most Federal offices and financial markets are shut down and regular mail delivery is suspended. Related articles, page A14.

title: A Top Executive Is Ousted From Walt Disney Studios
description: In a major shake-up at the Walt Disney Studios, Ricardo Mestres was ousted today as president of Hollywood Pictures, which has produced a string of box-office flops in recent years.

title: Petitions Seek California Vote on Canada-Style Health Plan
description: Leading a nationwide push for state-run health insurance systems, a coalition of consumer, labor and doctors' groups submitted petitions today that would allow California citizens to vote this fall for a Canadian-style "single payer" plan.

title: Japanese Tax Cuts Are Thwarted
description: As Prime Minister-elect Tsutomu Hata struggles to form a Government this week, he is facing the disintegration of his ruling coalition, the most tenacious recession in decades and the anger of the Clinton Administration at Japan for not having done more to revive its economy.

title: NEXT COMPUTER SAYS IT MAY SEEK CORPORATE PARTNERS
description: Next Computer Inc. may soon sell stakes to other companies in an effort to spur sales of its software, its chairman, Steve Jobs, said yesterday in an interview. "We may sell a stake in the company or just recruit other partners," said Mr. Jobs, who founded Next in 1985. Next, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., sold a 1.5 percent stake to Sun Microsystems Inc. in November.

title: Blair Corp.(BL,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Fund Is Set Up to Stabilize Mexican Peso
description: The United States, Mexico and Canada announced the formation today of an unusual multibillion-dollar fund to stabilize Mexico's currency and protect it from further onslaughts by global speculators.

title: Pitino Puts Rumors to Rest
description: Kentucky Coach RICK PITINO said yesterday that he would remain with the Wildcats and not take a job as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers. "There have never been any negotiations," Pitino said a news conference in Lexington, Ky., responding to reports that he had talked with the Lakers while in Los Angeles. "I was on vacation."

title: Showalter Proves He Is Clairvoyant
description: Buck Showalter is often hesitant to shower players with compliments, even his own players. So when Showalter quietly predicted before yesterday's game that California's Brian Anderson could pose problems for the Yankees, it was a revealing admission from the cautious manager. It was also an accurate assessment.

title: Books of The Times; How a Poet Kept in Touch With Life's Prosaic Side
description: One Art Elizabeth Bishop Letters Selected and Edited by Robert Giroux Illustrated. 668 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 28 about the background of Lisa Bongiorno, who is charged with having killed two officials of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America on March 17 in Queens misstated the ages of the two priests. The Rev Dimitrios Frangos was 81; the Rev. Germanos Stavropoulos was 51.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about companies that are moving into the Times Square area misspelled the name of an advertising agency. It is D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: Review/Music; Cecilia Bartoli Finds Beauty in the Sound of Breath
description: If God is in the details, Cecilia Bartoli must be a very devout mezzo-soprano. At her extraordinary recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, Ms. Bartoli, who made her debut here in 1990 at the age of 24, put plenty of wonderful effects on display: elaborate roulades, pinpoint coloratura, smooth, effortless legato. But even in the smallest details her presence and virtuosity were powerfully felt, in the ways vowels were shaped or colored, in the ways character and meaning were created using rubato and phrasing, and, most importantly, in the sound of her breath.

title: Gorazde Cease-Fire Is Irrelevant
description: Although the Clinton-NATO ultimatum on Bosnia has led to a Serb pullback from Gorazde, it has put compassion on a collision course with reality.

title: Overseas Press Club Names 16 Recipients Of Journalism Prizes
description: Paul Watson of The Toronto Star won the Robert Capa Gold Medal for his photography in Somalia at the annual awards last night of the Overseas Press Club of America.

title: Theater in Review
description: Reproducing Georgia American Place Theater 111 West 46th Street Manhattan By Karen Hartman; directed by Dana Kirchman; set by Peter Shevenell; lighting by Paul Bartlett; costumes by Karen Ngo; sound by Matt Berman; choreography by Katherine Profeta; dramaturg, by Garrett Eisler; props by Andrew Epstein; graphics by Ronit Kirchman; stage manager, Susan Felber; technical director, Sergio Cruz. Presented by Bold Face Theater.

title: Consolidated Edison Co.  (ED,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 SERBS PULL BACK FROM GORAZDE A United Nations spokesman said the Bosnian Serbs had complied with a NATO ultimatum for pulling back their heavy weapons from the besieged town of Gorazde. A1 VOTING BEGINS IN SOUTH AFRICA Throngs of elderly and infirm voters came forward in South Africa to sweep aside three centuries of white rule and euphorically open its first fully democratic elections. A1

title: Bears Bid Adieu to Dent, Anderson and Heyward
description: The Chicago Bears said yesterday that they would not pursue negotiations with defensive end RICHARD DENT and running back NEAL ANDERSON, both free agents, and they released fullback CRAIG HEYWARD.

title: In the Young, Signs That Feminism Lives; Piqued by High School Harassment
description: After the final bell rang and classes were dismissed on a recent afternoon, about a dozen young women at Fair Lawn High School headed for the homeroom of the Spanish teacher, Eileen Levine. They meet there every week for what, 20 years ago, would have been called a consciousness-raising group.

title: 2 Major Leaguers Accused Of Soliciting Prostitution
description: A pitcher and a center fielder for the San Diego Padres were arrested early yesterday and charged with soliciting prostitution after the police said they propositioned two undercover police officers on a street corner in midtown Manhattan.

title: Hours After His Arrest, Padre Pitcher Gets Save
description: Presumably the worst team in the National League, the San Diego Padres made the suffering Mets their fourth straight victims last night as a pitcher who had been arrested in the pre-dawn hours finished up the game.

title: A Different Take on the 'Myth' of Inflation; Raise Taxes, Not Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Scientific Corp.(BSX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Coast Guard Bans Bias Against Gay Workers
description: The Coast Guard has banned discrimination against civilian employees on the basis of "sexual orientation," the first military service to adopt such a policy.

title: Kamieniecki Is Back as Starter, With Bitter Memories
description: Scott Kamieniecki was asked this spring when he began considering the possibility that he might not be in the starting rotation and he blurted out Oct. 4. He was not joking. One day after a glorious 1993 had ended for the Yankees and Kamieniecki, he was already contemplating job security.

title: Cincinnati Milacron Inc.(CMZ,N) reports earnings for 12wks to Mar 26
description: b-Net loss and after a net loss of $ 52,125,000, or $ 1.86 a share, from cumulative effect of accounting changes.Latest 12 weeks results included Valenite, Inc., which was acquired in February 1993, and Klockner-Werke AG's Ferromatik plastics injection molding machine business, which was acquired in November 1993.(Loss)

title: Shirley Kheel; Lawyer, 49
description: Shirley Ann Dungan Kheel, a lawyer and civic worker, died yesterday at her Manhattan home. She was 49.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Connecticut is selling $65 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds won by Dillon, Read & Company in competitive bidding. The serial bonds are priced to yield from 3.10 percent in 1995 to 5.85 percent in 2011, with the issue rated Aa by Moody's, AA- by Standard & Poor's and AA+ by Fitch Investors Service. * Michigan Municipal Bond Authority is selling $126.5 million of tax-exempt revenue notes through CS First Boston. Due in 1995, the noncallable notes are initially priced to yield 3.60 percent and are rated SP-1+ by S.& P.

title: Gymnastic Coach Faces Sex Charges
description: A coach at a gymnastic club in Chappaqua was arraigned today on charges that he sodomized a 15-year-old female student in 1990, the Westchester District Attorney's office said.

title: Upjohn Facing F.D.A. Inquiry On Pill Effects
description: The Federal Government will investigate new allegations that the Upjohn Company knew of serious side effects caused by the sleeping pill Halcion but reported them falsely to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: QUESTIONS ARISE OVER SUCCESSION TO TOP MERCK POST
description: Merck & Company surprised analysts, shareholders and employees yesterday by announcing that Martin J. Wygod, one of its biggest shareholders, would not succeed Dr. P. Roy Vagelos as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Wygod, whose company, Medco Containment Services Inc., was acquired by Merck last year for $6 billion, was widely viewed as first in line to succeed Dr. Vagelos, who will retire on Nov. 1.

title: For Tomb of Civil War Hero, The New Battle Is in Court
description: Ulysses S. Grant waged war in the field. But his descendants and admirers, bent on improving conditions at the war hero's tomb, are taking their battle to court.

title: News Corp. Game Deal
description: The News Corporation has bought the Kesmai Corporation, a privately held video game developer based in Charlottesville, Va., for an undisclosed sum. The News Corporation, the giant media company based in Sydney, Australia, said Kesmai's games would be available on-line through its Delphi Internet Services subsidiary in May. Delphi is an on-line service, offering news, financial information, software and electronic mail services to customers through their modem-equipped personal computers.

title: Rifkin Linked to an 18th Killing As Prosecution Rests in His Trial
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the murder trial of Joel Rifkin, with the final witness offering testimony suggesting that Mr. Rifkin might have killed more women than the 17 he says he strangled.

title: When Your Water Might Contain Lead
description: Millions of households that use well water have been warned by environmental groups that some submersible well pumps, made of lead alloys, can leach the toxic metal into drinking water. Last week, the Environmental Protection Agency advised people with such wells to have their water tested for lead, renewing concerns in many families about pollution on tap in the kitchen.

title: Surgery Found to Help Emphysema Patients
description: A new operation eases the effects of emphysema by removing 20 to 30 percent of the damaged lung tissue, a surgeon has reported.

title: Acquittal in Trash Plant Case
description: The chairman and general counsel of North American Recycling Systems Inc. were acquitted this week of felony bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from the construction of a trash incinerator in Washington County, N.Y.

title: THE 37th PRESIDENT: HENRY KISSINGER; 'Courage in the Face of Wrenching Domestic Controversy'
description: Following is the eulogy delivered yesterday by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger at the funeral of former President Richard M. Nixon in Yorba Linda, Calif., as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Nixon on Clinton
description: "So what did you think of him?" I asked Richard Nixon after his first meeting with Bill Clinton.

title: Abortion Clinic Fight Heads to Court
description: The red line painted across the driveway of the Aware Woman Center for Choice here does more than mark the boundary of the only abortion clinic in Brevard County. For a year, it has also been the front line in the national debate over abortion, the focal point of a bitter legal battle.

title: Politics Is Breaking Out, Feverishly and Impishly
description: The white suburban liberal candidates come close to self-parody. "Security provided for you and your car," promises the radio ad for a campaign rally of the Democratic Party in these joyous, but still mugger-haunted days on the South African hustings.

title: 3 Players Banned in Game-Fixing Scandal
description: JEAN-JACQUES EYDLIE of Olympique Marseilles and JORGE BURRUCHAGA and CHRISTOPHE ROBERT of Valenciennes were banned from soccer yesterday until July 1, 1996, for their role in a game-fixing scandal. The decision, taken by the emergency committee of FIFA meeting in Vienna, prevents the players from appearing with any club in the world for the next two seasons and from playing for their national teams. They will miss the 1994 World Cup, the 1995 America Cup and the 1996 European Championship.

title: THE 37th PRESIDENT: SUMMING IT UP; In the End, the Words Were Those He Sought
description: As Richard M. Nixon must have hoped it would, his funeral turned into a rite of reconciliation today, bringing to a fitting end his 20-year struggle to rehabilitate himself after the disgrace of resignation.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY POLICE SUPERVISORS FACE ACTION IN INQUIRY Eight of the 22 police sergeants in the 30th Precinct in Harlem will be transferred and may be disciplined for any corrupt and brutal acts of officers under their watch, according to a law-enforcement official. The plan is part an effort to break up what has been described as departmental indifference to corruption. A1. DOCTOR GUILTY OF REFUSING AID A doctor was convicted of refusing to admit a woman in labor to Harlem Hospital, forcing ambulance attendants to deliver her baby in the hospital's waiting room and of later falsifying hospital records to cover up his actions. B3.

title: GE Capital Acquiring Credit Unit
description: Shifting more of its focus to its core telecommunications business, Northern Telecom Ltd. of Canada has sold its financing arm in the United States to GE Capital, the two companies said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMERON INC., Pasadena, Calif., a construction products concern, has won two contracts valued at about $27 million to build two concrete and steel pipelines in Southern California. AMERIWOOD INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL, Grandville, Mich., a manufacturer of ready-to-assemble furniture, began construction to expand its plant in Tiffin, Ohio, by about 200,000 square feet. The expansion will result in the addition of 150 to 200 jobs.

title: Vaulter Sets Bubka-esque Goals
description: Determined to be a great pole-vaulter, Lawrence Johnson saw his Ukrainian hero on cable television, copied his performance onto videotape and studied it by the hour on his parents' v.c.r. Three years later, he has established a collegiate record of more than 19 feet.

title: William Horowitz, Official for Charities And Bank Chief, 86
description: William Horowitz, a Connecticut banker who was also a leader in his state's educational, religious and civic affairs, died on Monday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. Mr. Horowitz, who lived in Branford, Conn., was 86.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MFG. CO. (MMM,N)
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 7.3 percent after it took a $35 million pretaxcharge to settle breast-implant litigation. The company reported net income of $306 million, or 72 cents a share. The earnings would have totaled about 77 cents a share without the charge. Per-share amounts reflect a 2-for-1 stock split last month.

title: AMR COMPLETES PURCHASE OF CANADIAN AIR STAKE
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, completed its long-delayed $177 million purchase of a 25 percent stake in the PWA Corporation's Canadian Airlines. PWA, based in Calgary, Alberta, and AMR, based in Fort Worth, initially announced the agreement in December 1992. The signing had been jeopardized by a battle between Canadian Airlines and its domestic competitor, Air Canada, over Canadian's plan to transfer its accounting and flight-dispatching functions from the Gemini computer reservation system to AMR's Sabre reservation system. Air Canada abandoned its fight to block Canadian's move to Sabre earlier this year. Another challenge to the transaction was settled only this week when an arbitrator ruled that the pact did not violate American Airlines' contract with pilots.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY U.S. Turns Back Norway in Italy Team USA overcame an early two-goal deficit, coming back to beat Norway, 7-2, yesterday for its second straight victory at the world championships in Alba di Canazei, Italy. After Norway took a 2-0 lead after one period, the United States came back with four goals in the first nine minutes of the second period by Patrick Neaton, who played last season for the Pittsburgh Penguins in the National Hockey League, Quebec's Craig Wolanin, Bob Beers of Edmonton and Danton Cole of Tampa Bay. Wolanin and Beers scored on power plays. Shjon Podein of Edmonton added two goals in the third period and Tim Sweeney of Anaheim scored on a give-and-go from Craig Janney, a new addition from St. Louis. (AP)

title: Currents; Where Bauhaus and Richard Serra Intersect
description: Maybe it's the recession and the lack of toothsome commissions. Or the absence of a compelling new theory since deconstruction. Whatever the case, architects and designers seem to be getting comfortable with history again. Examples of "new but old" style -- contemporary with a retro twist -- abound. What might be mistaken for a look backward could be the beginning of something new.

title: Cause of Plane Crash in Japan Still a Mystery to Investigators
description: After their first day of investigation, the Japanese authorities said tonight that they had not figured out the cause of Tuesday night's crash of a Taiwan airliner that killed almost all of the 271 people on board.

title: Helping Teachers and Schools to Nip Sex Bias in the Bud
description: WHEN a few of the first-grade boys at the City and Country School, a private school for 2- to 13-year-olds on West 13th Street in Manhattan, began to taunt the first-grade girls by calling them "sexy babes" and saying things like "Let's do sexy" to them over several weeks in January, it ignited a furor among parents. They were disturbed both because their daughters were upset and because the girls were advised by their teacher simply to ignore the boys.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ANTHONY D. MARSHALL was a boy, it would have been hard to predict that he would someday write a book called "Zoo," a guide to 102 zoos and aquariums in the United States.

title: Autodesk Founder Saddles Up and Leaves
description: The reclusive founder of the nation's largest maker of design software for personal computers quietly resigned last week, saying that his interests were diverging from the company that was once described as a "theocracy of hackers."

title: Seven Killed In Fiery Crash Of Airplane
description: A chartered passenger plane returning from Atlantic City crashed into a fence while landing in foggy weather at Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, Conn., last night, killing seven of the nine people on board, officials said.

title: 'Northern Exposure' Is Target of Protest
description: The Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, whose crusade against television programming he considers unsuitable has led some advertisers to shun episodes of various series, is protesting an episode of the CBS hit "Northern Exposure" in which two male characters get married.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILL MAULDIN, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist who endeared himself to World War II soldiers with his memorable depiction of the sad-sack infantrymen Willie and Joe, regaled some 200 members of the National Press Club in Washington with his wartime experiences at a luncheon on Tuesday.

title:
COMPANY REPORTS;
Flagstar to Sell Vending Business
description: The Flagstar Companies said today that it would sell its Canteen food and vending businesses to Compass Group P.L.C. for $450 million to focus on its core restaurant business, which includes the Denny's chain.

title: Books of The Times; An Intricate Plot About Hollywood
description: The Book of Dreams By Craig Nova 321 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $22.95.

title: Christopher Asks Arab Lands To Extend the Iraqi Embargo
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to the Saudi capital today to rally several oil-producing gulf states behind extending the trade embargo against Iraq, seeking a counterweight to the growing number of countries who want to see the embargo eased.

title: Venezuela Proposes Opening Oil Industry to Private Investment
description: Breaking a 20-year taboo, Venezuela's new Government today proposed opening its oil industry, Latin America's largest, to private investment.

title: Rangers Relaxing Before Taking On Caps
description: Craig MacTavish sounded almost apologetic.

title: Accounts
description: * Dean Foods Vegetable Co., Green Bay, Wis., to Young & Rubicam San Francisco, to handle advertising for its newly acquired Birds Eye line of frozen vegetables. The agency previously handled the account when the brand was owned by Kraft General Foods. Though billings were not disclosed, they had previously been estimated at $3 million.

title: St. Pierre Journal; A Seagirt Sliver of France Fears for Its Lifeline
description: Twelve miles off Newfoundland's southern coast, a French official in a blue military shirt stamps passports "Port de St. Pierre," and Renaults and Citroens edge up the cobbled streets.

title: Vitamin Study Showing No Benefit Was Flawed; A Carcinogenic Dye
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Plane Crash Kills 7

title: Essay; RN Off the Record
description: "Guns are an abomination," said Richard Nixon in one of our long talks last year. He added, "You can use that now."

title: Wrestling Promoter Fights Steroid Charges
description: When a professional wrestler thinks he's gotten a bum deal, he snarls into the nearest camera and promises to wreak havoc on his opponents. When Vincent McMahon Jr., owner of the World Wrestling Federation, appears tomorrow before a Federal judge in Uniondale, L.I., he will doubtless be more soft-spoken but every bit as determined.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Azalea Companions

title: Calendar: Outdoors And In
description: Cherry Trees in Brooklyn Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: 'Take Our Daughters' -- A Media Photo Op
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Sign Princeton Back
description: KEITH ELIAS, the career leading rusher at Princeton University, is going to join the Giants. Elias, passed over in the National Football League draft despite setting 21 school records and 4 N.C.A.A. Division I-AA marks, has reached an agreement on a free agent contract, a source close to the team said yesterday.

title: Music Notes
description: Marketing a Concept

title: Mariners Donate to Yankees' Walkathon
description: If it had been a Little League game, the opposing managers might have agreed to interrupt play and begin hitting the ball off a tee. They might have rescued the erratic pitchers who could not throw strikes. But this was a major league game so Seattle's Lou Piniella did not have that option. He had to watch the sloppiness escalate, watch the walks accumulate and watch the Yankee runs effortlessly cross the plate without hits.

title: Harper's Maxim: Last Shall Be First
description: For Derek Harper, the hardest part of being traded was telling his three children. The deal took place on Jan. 6, forcing Harper to leave his family in Dallas until the children finished the school year.

title: A War-Weary Serbia Dares to Hope
description: The spring weather is splendid in Serbia's capital, and as residents stroll through parks and sip coffee in downtown cafes, they dare to hope that the war in neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina may finally be approaching an end.

title: THE 37th PRESIDENT: BOB DOLE; 'The Largest Figure of Our Time Whose Influence Will Be Timeless'
description: Following are excerpts from the eulogy delivered yesterday by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, at the funeral for former President Richard M. Nixon, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Merck to Add To Generic Line of Drugs
description: Moving aggressively to expand its sales of low-priced drugs, Merck & Company said yesterday that it would begin marketing generic versions of widely used products originated by other big drug makers.

title: Review/Pop; A Party With the Gap Band
description: In about his third or fourth song, Charlie Wilson, the lead singer of the Gap Band, repeated the phrase "I feel all right" eight times. A few were relaxed warm-ups; the rest crackled with signs of passion as Mr. Wilson's vocal textures changed from nasal and dusty melismas to a low, huffing howl. Then after a virtuosic display of how the emotionalism of gospel music can be applied to almost anything, Mr. Wilson went on to turn the show into a party.

title: Currents; Pain-Free Office Chairs
description: Maybe it's the recession and the lack of toothsome commissions. Or the absence of a compelling new theory since deconstruction. Whatever the case, architects and designers seem to be getting comfortable with history again. Examples of "new but old" style -- contemporary with a retro twist -- abound. What might be mistaken for a look backward could be the beginning of something new.

title: Ban on Employees Who Smoke Faces Challenges of Bias
description: A growing number of private employers around the country are refusing to hire smokers as a quick-and-easy way to hold down health care costs. But just as swiftly, state legislatures are coming to the smokers' defense, passing laws that prohibit hiring practices that discriminate against them.

title: Sports of The Times; Classic Duel Between Hot Goaltenders
description: THEY resemble no other athletes. Halloween masks hide their perspiring faces. Flak-jacket vests impede their torsos. Pads bigger than sofa pillows weigh on their legs. With a thick flat glove, they grip a bulky wooden stick. With their other glove, they try to snatch the puck as a first baseman would. And with all of this ponderous equipment, they must guard a 6-by-4-foot net while spinning, sliding and sprawling on ice.

title: Topics of The Times; Hands Across the Hudson
description: Not often are Republicans in charge of both New York City and New Jersey, and when they are they flaunt it. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman did a joint TV "town hall" the other night. It was more love-in than confrontation over issues that normally divide a big city and its suburbs. But Democrats in those offices have rarely been so openly friendly, or publicly confessed they need each other.

title: Gooden's Fadeaway Is Not a New Pitch
description: How long ago 1984 seems.
